Military Medal Citation
Normandy
On 6 June 1944 Sergeant Ford and his men landed with the assault battalions of 69 Infantry Brigade.   Despite heavy mortar and machine gun fire he gathered his party together and fearlessly carried out his allotted task of marking the track being made through the beach minefields.   His coolness and leadership were an outstanding example to his men who successfully completed the marking and establishing a vital route forward.
Awarded an immediate MM.   Recommended by Captain W R Hunter OC 50 Div Pro Coy.  National Archive WO 373/48.

Military Medal Citation.
Normandy
On 6 June 1944 Sergeant Jacklin and his party landed in LE HAMEL some distance from the beach on which they were to operate.   Sergeant Jacklin without hesitation organised his party and led them to the correct beach.   Despite heavy fire he organised the beach exits and went forward to recce the route and mark the roads allotted to him.   Sergeant Jacklin completely ignored danger and was successful in completing all he set out to do.   He displayed remarkable coolness and devotion to duty which was an outstanding example to his party.   The successful completion of his task was the means of saving many casualties amongst the infantry assault troops.   
Awarded the MM.   Recommended by Captain W R Hunter OC 50 Div Pro Coy.   National Archive WO 373/48.

Military Medal Citation.
Kohima, Burma
For leadership, initiative and gallant conduct. This NCO was detailed to assist in the evacuation of casualties from the KOHIMA GARRISON on 19 April 1944.   On his own initiative he proceeded to the forward control post where he personally directed the turnaround of ambulances and assisted in the loading of patients.   He remained at his post until the evacuation was complete.   During the evacuation his post was under constant sniping and mortarfire.   One of the ambulances was hit by a mortar bomb, set on fire and the patients all killed or wounded within 10 yards of this NCO who immediately took steps to rescue the patients and clear the road block formed by the burning ambulance.   It was largely due to the high standard of traffic control combined with personal example that this NCO showed, that all the casualties of the KOHIMA GARRISON were successfully evacuated.
Sergeant Tozer in addition has remained in charge of this TCP (Traffic Control Post) for the last month, and during the first two weeks was daily subjected to shell and mortar fire, and accurate sniping.
By his efficiency, initiative and personal example coupled with a complete disregard of his own safety, Sergeant Tozer has ensured that supplies and ammunition reached the garrison and that casualties to personnel and vehicles were kept to a minimum on the stretch of road for which he was responsible, which was in full view of the enemy.   He has maintained throughout an example of devotion to duty and leadership in keeping with the traditions of the Corps of Military Police.
Recommended for DCM awarded  an immediate MM.   Recommended by Brigadier J F Shafland Commander 6 Inf Bde, 2 Div.  National Archive WO 373/33.

Military Medal Citation.
Escape and evasion Italy
REDHEAD was captured on 29 Jun 42 near FUKA and was sent to a working camp at CICCIANO attached to Camp 82 (LATERINA).
During the afternoon of 11 Sep 43 the whole of the P/W in this working camp went into the nearby mountains, where REDHEAD remained until he was recaptured by Fascists.   Taken to FORTRESSA DI BASSO, he found six other P/W already there, and , under cover of loud singing they removed the mortar of the brick wall of their cell.   When this was completed five days later, they got out of the cell and negotiated the outer wall by climbing on to the roof of an adjoining building and letting themselves down the other side by means of a rope made from a blanket.   With three others, REDHEAD then went into the mountains and joined a rebel band at CAMERINO.   On 15 Mar 44 REDHEAD was again arrested and taken to MACERATA Civil Goal, but six weeks captivity was terminated when the 13 P/W overcame their five guards during an air raid alarm.
Remaining hidden in the vicinity of FERMO, REDHEAD was included in an evacuation scheme organised  by 'A' Force, and reached TERMOLI on 25 May 44.
Citation ref WO 373/96
ESCAPES FROM CAMP 82 (LATERINA), ITALY
RECOMMENDATIONS FOR AWARDS

(1) After the Armistice with Italy had been signed the Senior British Officer of the camp advised P/W to remain there, but did not actively prevent their escaping.   There was a mass breakout by some French Foreign Legion troops, who were fired on by Italian guards, and a certain number of British P/W escaped during the confusion.   The majority, however, remained in camp and were captured by the Germans when they took over.
A number of sub-working camps were attached to Camp 82 and most of the P/W in them seem to have had little difficulty in getting away after the Armistice.
(2) I recommend the following other ranks for the awards shown, brief particulars being given in the enclosures stated opposite their names:-
(a) Recommended for M.M.
3130602 Cpl BURGESS, Harry
                         1Bn. Para. Regt., 1 Para Bde     1A
5951812 Sgt. Hood, James
                               16 D.L.I., 46 Div.                1B

7685171 L/Cpl REDHEAD, Thomas
                          C.M.P., attd. 150 Bde., 50 Div.  1C

1 Aug. 44.                                                                                                                           D.M.I.
National Archive WO 373/96.

Military Medal Citation.
Cassino, Italy
During the night of 11/12 May 1944 the above named NCO went forward with the infantry to assist with traffic control at mr 868184 Italy, in the assault crossing of the RIVER GARI (also known as RAPIDO).   On the night of 12/13 May 1944 he was the only CMP on duty near the river, the remaining NCO's being casualties.   He remained on duty at AMAZON BRIDGE (class 30 bridge south of Cassino) with only 5 hours break until relieved at 1200 hours 15 May 1944, a period of approximately 4 days.   Upon arrival of reliefs he was ordered to a point further back but asked that he may be permitted to remain at the river as he was fully conversant with the duties required, regardless that it was still under heavy shellfire.   He showed exceptional bravery in the face of almost continuous enemy fire, giving confidence and setting an outstanding example.
Awarded an immediate MM.   Recommended by OC 4 Div Pro Coy.  National Archive WO 373/8.

Military Medal Citation.
River Rapido, Italy
During the initial stages of the river crossing of the RAPIDO on 11/12 May 1944 the above named NCO was in charge of CMP in the forward sector of 28 Infantry Brigade.   When the crossing failed, heavy shelling and mortaring occurred and this NCO showed  great courage and bravery not only in keeping his own section of men together but also all other personnel in the vicinity.   One Traffic Control Post under his control failed to report in after all other TP's had left the area and the river crossing and he went forward through heavy mortar fire to locate them.   During the morning of 12 May he also volunteered to go forward to attempt to recover vehicles which had been sent forward to raft the river and had been held up with shell and mortar fire.   Although he was unable to recover the vehicles he cleared the area of troops, searching very diligently for wounded in spite of being in view of the enemy.   During the ensuing days of 13,14 and 15 May this NCO was forward on the bridges the whole time, and by his courage and personal disregard for safety kept his section together when under mortar and shellfire.
Awarded an immediate MM.   Recommended by OC 4 Inf Div Pro Coy.   National Archive WO 373/8.
Normandy.   Citation not found.

George Medal Citation 2609338 WOI (RSM) H S NOBLE CORPS OF MILITARY POLICE
Burma
On the 13th May 1944, in Burma, shots were heard coming from the direction of a Line of Communication signal lines. Shortly after, a message was received to the effect that a man had run amok with a rifle and ammunition and was firing at everybody and everything.   Sergeant-Major Noble went over to the signal lines armed with a Tommy gun, meeting an officer on the way who showed him the location of the man who had run amok, who it appeared had got into a Quartermaster's store, as shots were coming from the store rather rapidly.   After about half an hour of manoeuvre and during which time firing was continuous, Sergeant-Major Noble and a number of others closely surrounded the store, where about 1700 rounds of ammunition and a dozen or so rifles were stored.   Sergeant-Major Noble, who was covering the only doorway waited for a chance to fire at the man inside in order to disable him;  the chance arrived, and on attempting to fire, he found that his Tommy gun had become jammed.   Showing  great presence of mind and total disregard for personal danger, Sergeant-Major Noble rushed into the store, disarmed the man and after a short struggle held him securely to the floor.   Sergeant-Major Noble said afterwards that when he got inside the store he found it to be darker than outside, and that he was unable to see, but after stumbling about, suddenly felt somebody on the floor, so he jumped on him.   National Archive WO 373/68.

United Kingdom.   Citation for BEM:  Sergeant Ridsdale was walking in a field adjacent to a camp at Eastham, when he was approached by an elderly clergyman who asked him if he could swim as a girl had fallen into the River Mersey and the current had taken her out to about twenty yards from the bank.   The girl had already gone down twice and Sergeant Ridsdale at once divested himself of his tunic and dived into to resuce her.   After a struggle during which the girl pulled Sergeant Ridsdale under the water, Sergeant Ridsdale managed to get her to the bank where with help they were pulled ashore.   The river at the particular point is very treacherous owning to swift flowing tides and currents and, owing to it being high tide at the time, the rescue was carried out under extreme difficulties.
National Archive WO 373/68 Pt.2.

Regimental number on citation reads 5457104.   Italy.   Citation for BEM:  On February 26th. 1944 in response to continued requests for Military Policmen, Cpl. Hockaday L. was despatched to Molfetta for the purpose of taking charge of a body of Regimental policemen and organising picquets to quell local distrubances among the Troops.   The distrubances had been increasing in number and were becoming a serious problem.   Through this N.C.O's untiring efforts and devotion to duty, the discipline of the Troops has improved to such an extent that very few incidents have since occurred.   Lieut. Col. Lloyd, Officer Commanding Troops in Molfetta has the highest opinion of this N.C.O., and of the results his work has achieved.   This opionion is shared by the Commanding Officers of various Special Service Units stationed there.
Capt G. F Hunt E Lancs Regt OC 230 Pro Coy.   Brig G V Palmer Comd 6 Base Sub Area.   Maj Gen Comd No2 District.   National Archive WO 373/72.

Italy.   At NAPLES on the 6th May 44 Sgt RH MUGGERIDGE was engaged on an enquiry concerning a larceny for which two soldiers had already been apprehended when he observed in a cafe a third soldier who was suspect.   On being beckoned to come outside, the soldier drew a revolver and advanced towards Sgt. MUGGERIDGE who remained blocking the door.   When ten feet away the soldier fired his revolver at Sgt. MUGGERIDGE who dropped to the ground and avoided being hit.   As Sgt MUGGERIDGE jumped to his feet the soldier fired again, this time narrowly missing  MUGGERIDGE's head.   As Sgt MUGGERIDGE continued to advance upon the soldier, the soldier ran into the street and down a side alley.   Sgt MUGGERIDGE immediately gave chase and caught up with the soldier after some 400 yards, who turned and commenced to back up some steps.   Sgt MUGGERIDGE being unarmed, picked up a stone and slowly mounted the steps, the while calling to the soldier to come down.   When having advanced to within some 4 or 5 feet of the armed soldier, a shout raised below momentarily distracted the soldier's attention.   Sgt MUGGERIDGE leaped forward at this opportunity and after a struggle succeeded in disarming the soldier of the loaded pistol and taking him into custody.   The action of Sgt MUGGERIDGE in arresting an armed felon, having been fired upon at point-blank range, and knowing him to be dangerous and likely to resist at all costs, the fact that he achieved this himself unarmed, constitutes an act of extreme courage and displays the highest devotion to duty.
Maj APM HQ 57 Area.   Brig J G Bruxner-Randall Comd 57 Area.  Maj Gen Comd 8 District.   National Archive WO 373/72.

Citation to bar for MM
Lower Garigliano, Italy
In Italy in January 1944, this NCO with No1 Provost Section was attached to 138 Brigade at
' HARROGATE'  (supply dump). He was responsible for the marking, taping and policing of the mule tracks from 'HARROGATE' to 'CHESHIRE' (supply dump).   Throughout the months of January and February 1944, this NCO peformed excellent service, occasionally under shellfire, in ensuring that the supplies by mule were hastened up the mountain during the hours of darkness, which frequently necessitated him making the long and difficult journey between the two dumps two and three times a night.   This NCO has always been outstanding by his leadership and courage, particulary in difficult situations or under shellfire, and his exemplary behaviour in such situations has often been the subject of admirable comments by his subordinates.
Recommended by Captain T P Noon OC 46 Div Pro Coy.   National Archive WO 373/9.
No Citation found.   Listed as Royal Artillery (now CMP) in London Gazette.
WWII OC Southern Area Pro Coy, Singapore.

Military Medal Citation.
In ITALY on the 5 March 1944 about 1600 hrs this NCO was in charge of the Provost Section policing 'SKIPTON DUMP' when an ambulance from 185 Field Ambulance was secured to give medical attention to a civilian girl who had been wounded.   At 16.55 hrs this NCO was assisting the driver  to remove the girl from a house near the dump when 6 or 7 enemy shells dropped within the immediate vicinity of the dump wounding the driver 10672022 Bann 185 Field Ambulance, and also Captain Spide-Sproof of 359 Mulepack Coy, the latter seriously.   Coloured mule drivers were killed and wounded and a slight panic broke out with the mules becoming frightened.   This NCO collected the wounded, got them into ambulances, restored order and discipline among the mule drivers and had the roadway cleared of dead mules, despite the fact that shells were still falling near the dump.   Although not having driven an ambulance previously, this NCO drove an ambulance of wounded to 185 ADS(advanced dressing station) where his action was very favourably commented upon by the OC and Medical Officer.   On many other occasions while 'PATELY BRIDGE' across the river Garigliano was under shellfire this NCO by his own example of coolness and appreciation of the situation, displayed courage without regard for his personal safety and was an inspiration to junior NCO's.
Recommended for MM by Captain T P Noon OC 46 Div Pro Coy CMP.   National Archive WO 373/9.

Military Medal Citation.
River Garigliano, Italy
The above named NCO has throughout the Italian campaign shown the highest standard of courage and devotion to duty.   His consistent courage and cheefulness have undoubtedly proved an example to all present.   The incident cited below was particularly outstanding.   During the night 16/17 January 1944 he recced a track to the RIVER GARIGLIANO over which 8RF (8 Royal Fusiliers) were to pass during the night of 17/18 January.   At dusk on 17 January accompanied  by two Lance Corporals he taped this track in preparation for the assault crossing.   On 18 January 1944 after the  attack had commenced and the battalions of 167 London Infantry Brigade were across ther river he left CASTRESA to sign route to SAN LUCIA where it was intended to establish Brigade Tac HQ.   Having reached the river he encountered heavy shell and mortarfire and was badly wounded.   Although in great pain he insisted on handing over all info and duties etc to his junior NCO's before allowing himself to be evacuated to a dressing station.
Awarded a periodical MM.   Recommended by Captain A Mercer APM and OC 56 Div Pro Coy.   National Archive WO 373/9.

Military Medal Citation.
Italy
Lance Corporal Boulton during the Battle for Cassino from early February to end of March 44 was assigned the task of maintaining Pro communications and patrolling the divisional axis and forward tracks into the hills, a vital telephone communication between VILLA TP and CAIRO TP operated so as to allow vehicles to proceed safely through the circuit only when enemy shelling had temporarily slackened.  Lance Corporal Boulton repaired cuts in the line and kept this communication in working order only by complete disregard for his personal safety.   His unflinching steadfastness during day and night patrolling enabled him to get word back to the Recovery and so clear knocked out vehicles and to request RE assistance to fill in shell holes in quick time.   On 12th March he assisted in policing a column of tanks from MICHELE to MADRAS circus and although heavy shellfire came down on the route he reached his destination and succeessfully completed a dangerous Provost Operation. He faced death on numerous occasions pressing home his jeep patrol on the CAIRO circuit and forward tracks, knowing full well that the enemy shelling was accurately arranged on his portion of the Div axis.
Recommended for the BEM awarded a periodical MM.   Recommened by Capt L C Cook OC 4 Indian Div Pro Coy CMP(I).  National Archive WO 373/9.

Military Medal Citation.
Normandy
Preparatory to the attack by the Division at ESCOVILLE on the 18 July 1944 four gaps had been cleared in our own minefields through which the entire Division were to pass.   To facilitate the passage of  personnel and vehices a CMP pointsman was placed on duty at each gap.   From the time the attack started at 0745 hours until late that evening the four gaps were subjected to incessant and accurate mortar and shellfire.   During the course of the morning the three other Provost Lance Corporals who were on duty became casualties from this fire.   Lance Corporal Thomas however, remaind on duty throughout the day amidst a continual hail of missiles.   Never once did he falter in the discharge of his duties, and throughout the period he showed the greatest keenness and interest in his job and was at all times able to convey information of great importance as to which units had passed through the gaps.   This NCO's gallantry and complete disregard for his personal safety, even after all his comrades had been wounded was a source of great inspiration to all who saw him.   The efficient way in which he controlled the traffic and in which he sent back information was of the greatest assistance to the Division; and the fact that the whole Division passed through the gaps without a single traffic jam occurring, must be largely attributed to this NCO's coolness and personal discipline under fire.   Lance Corporal Thomas's conduct throughout the day was worthy of the highest praise and was in accordance with the finest traditions of the Corps of Military Police.
Awarded an immediate MM.   Recommended by OC 3 Div Pro Coy.   National Archive WO 373/50.

company_id: 11 L of C Provost Unit EACMP
citation:
Tanganyika.   Citation for BEM:   Whilst i/c Det at TABORA TANGANYIKA TERRITORY he not only carried out his duties exceptionally well in every respect but on his own initiative and by touring the surrounding districts he was solely responsible for the arrest of some 150 absentees and deserters who might otherwise  have been still at large.   His visits to the outlying districts not only produced better relations between Tribe Chieftains and the Army but brought about a great improvement in the behaviour of Africans on leave.   Excellent reports have been received from Administrative Officials.   Tour of duty Sep 43 to Feb 44.
Capt DAPM Tanganyika Sub Area.   Commander Tanganyika Sub Area.   Maj Gen Comd Southern Area.
GOC in C East Africa Command.   National Archive WO 373/157.

Military Medal Citation
North West Europe
On 28 June 1944 during the action in which 15 (s) Division was engaged in securing the crossing over the RIVER ODON No6198473 Sergeant Gadsden, with his section of 15 (S) Division Provost Company, was on traffic duty in CHEUX and the roads leading south.   During the evening of that date when the enemy threatened a breakthrough in this sector, Sergeant Gadsden held his section together and personally directed traffic over a period of several hours, although subjected to heavy fire from enemy snipers and shelling.
During the period 15 - 18 July 1944, when 15 (S) Inf Div was engaged south of the RIVER ODON, Sergeant Gadsden and his section of 15 (S) Div Pro Coy was again on duty controlling traffic over the river on 4 bridges.   During this period the river crossings were subjected to considerable shelling and mortar fire.   In spite of numerous casualties amongst personnel of his company Sergeant Gadsden visited all his men on all the bridges encouraging them in their work and actively assisting in the control of traffic.   By his example he ensured  the smooth flow of traffic at all times over the river and inspired his men in the execution of their duties.
1 Sgt (Gadsden) 1 Cpl (Thomas) killed by mine.   War Diary WO 171/476.
Awarded the MM.   Recommended by APM 15 Div.  National Archive WO 373/50.

Chester.   Citation for BEM:  Since July 1940 to date this Sjt. Has been Chief Clerk to the D.P.M. Western Command.   By his efficiency, conscientiousness and maticulous attention to detail he has set an example that has resulted in the smoothest possible running of all office branches of the C.M.P. in this Command.   His devotion to duty and his loyalty as a confidential clerk are quite outstanding.   He has served under two former D.P.Ms. In this Command, both of whom have frequently expressed to me their appreciation of the excellency of his work.   During the period of his appoitment as Chief Clerk, the C.M.P. in this Command has risen from a few detachments to a peak of over 2,000 personnel.   He has been chiefly responsible for the spade work in this constant reorganisation and has at all times carried out his work with efficiency, cheerfulness and foresight.
Lt Col D.P.M. Western Command.   Lt Gen GOC in C Western Command.   National Archive WO 373/157.

CMP(I).
Iran.   Citation for BEM:  During the past 10 months this NCO has been in charge of a detachment of Indian Military Police at TABRIZ (Iran).   He has worked throughout in this isolated place almost entirely without supervision: nevertheless he has maintained his detachment in a high state of discipline, has carried out his provost duties strictly and impartially, and has maintained a friendly spirit of co-operation with the many Russians with whom he has come in contact.  He has throughout shewn himself to be possessed of exeptional powers of command and sense of responsibility, where an error in judgement might easily have created friction with our Russian Allies.
H. E. the Commander-in-Chief India.   National Archive WO 373/157.

United Kingdom.   Citation for BEM:  Sjt CARTER has served in the 38 (W) Inf Div Pro Coy since 15 May 1942.   I have known him since Sep 1942 and during this period he has carried out his duties in an exemplary manner.   He was promoted to the rank of Sjt on 7 Mar 43.   The manner in which he carried out his duties on the following exercises HINDUPUR (May 43), GALLOP (Aug 43), CREDULOUS (Oct 43), DILAPIDATE (Nov 43), TAFFY (Dec 43), ESKIMO (Dec 43), BRASSO (Jan 44) was of the highest order.   I received highest praise from all offrs who came in contact with CARTER during the said exercises for the excellent way in which the PROVOST SECTION under his command executed their duties.   He has a very thorough knowledge of all phases of Provost Duties.   Since 13 May 44 he has been in charge of a detached section on the IOW.   He has carried out the additional duties imposed on him to my entire satisfaction and has shown tact, detrmination, loyalty and excellent judgement at all times beyond that normally associated with the rank of Sjt.   The Civil Police IOW have recently stated that the co-operation and most valuable assistance received from CARTER at all times has been outstanding and greatly appreciated.
APM 38 (W) Div.   Lieut Gen Commander in Chief Southern Command.   National Archive WO373/157.

BEM Citation.  South Coast of England, Operation Overlord 1944
This NCO has worked in the embarkation area before and during Overlord.   His leadership and sense of responsibility has at all times been outstanding, without thought for himself.   He has worked long periods in all conditions of weather, helping to bring mixed personnel into a workable team.   The smoothness in which traffic moved to the hards and docks was due in no small measure to his untiring devotion to duty.

United Kingdom.  Citation for BEM;  This NCO has been with the Provost Marshal's Department since its formation in 1940 and helped with great zeal and efficiency to organize and supervise the department single handed through its initial difficult stages.   Serjeant Marshallsay served in the last war from September, 1914 until disembodied in February 1919.   He was wounded in France in April, 1917.   His loyalty and devotion to duty cannot be too highly praised.   Previously recommended in September, 1943 and March 1944.
Maj Gen Mellor Provost Marshall.   Maj Gen Director of Personal Services, War Office.   National Archive WO 373/157.

202 Pro Coy.  Greek Mutiny Egypt.   Citation for BEM:  This NCO was doing duty at the FPC Ikingi, which was being used as a first reception cage for the mutinous Greek Brigade personnel, with ten junior CMP NCOs under him.   4,000 mutineers were received and caged between 1130 hrs and 1600hrs on the day the Bde. surrendered and in addition, 1,500 loyalists were sorted, segregated and removed to another camp by 2000hrs on the same day.   Sgt Meaking worked the whole day without respite and by his extraordinary display of discipline, tact and patience, contributed in no small way to the successful handling of a situation which at times assumed very ugly proportions.   During the seven days the mutineers remained in the FPC, this NCO, by his appreciation of the situation and tactful handling of the Greeks, succeeded in not only ensuring a complete freedom from incident between the various factions in th camp, but also disciplined them to the extent of organising them into their original units, providing their own working and fatigue parties and preparing their compounds daily for inspection by the Camp Commander.   Having regard to the attitude of the mutineers on arrival at the camp after surrendering the work of this Sergeant deserves the highest praise.   He also provided valuable assistance in the identification and segregation of the leader of the mutiny Pte ANDRIOTES.
Lt Col H N Whiehead MBE DPM 16 Area.   Lieut Gen R G Stone GOC BTE.   General C in C MEF.

Italy.   Citation for MID:  This N.C.O., joined the 182 Company (Ports) on 30 January, 1943, on orders to Mobilize.   The Company arrived in Algiers on 9th March, 1943, and throughout the North African Campaign, carried out Port duties at Algiers - Bone - Phillipville, Sousse & La Goulette, arriving in ITALY, on 27th October, 1943.   During the above period he has been Chief Clerk throughout.   His keeness and devotion to duty has done much to ensure the smooth and efficient working of the unit.   At all times he has sacrificed leisure and personal conveniences in the interest of his work and that of the Company.   When the Company was on the move he always carried out instructions fully, so that there was no delay when arriving at a new Port to commence opertions.
Recommended for periodical BEM, awarded MID.
Maj W C Baglin 182 Pro Coy (Ports).   Col L J Woodhouse Comd 71 Sub Area.   Maj Gen E P Nares Comd No2 District.   National  Archive WO 373/90.

Military Medal Citation.
North West Europe
Sergeant Fewings has been i/c of the Pro Section attached to 146 Infantry Brigade for 18 months.   In England, he did sterling work in keeping up interest and efficiency of his section.   Since arrival in France, he had continually been out on the roads, signing routes, carrying out route recces and visiting point.
After the capture of FONTENAY-LE-PESNEL, he led his section forward to mark routes for ambulances and other priority vehicles under aimed  MMG and mortar fire, and it was largely due to his enterprise that these vehicles got through.
As the main weight of the enemy artillery has been on the roads he has continually  had to work under shellfire.   He has always been cheerful and tireless in his work and has been an inspiration to his section, the work of whom has been outstanding.
Awarded the MM.   Recommended by Brigadier J F Walker Commander 146 Inf Bde.  National Archive WO 373/50.

Citation for M.B.E.   RSM BEER has served with this coy since its formation in May 1939 during which time he has taken part in campaigns in FRANCE 1939/40 where he assisted with the traffic control at the evacuation from DUNKIRK, WESTERN DESERT 1942/43, SICILY 1943 and FRANCE 1944.   During the planning period for the invasion of FRANCE he was given the added responsibility of making the detailed arrangements for the collecting and guiding of Div HQ as well as assisting with the arrangements for 151 Bde.   Landing with the Assault Tps he supervised the marking of routes for 151 Bde and Div HQ by which personnel and vehicles were guided to their locations in an orderly manner thus avoiding and chaos or disorder which might have hindered operations. Throughout the campaign he has on many occasions operated in areas which were being shelled and mortared but has always shown a complete disregard for his personal safety and completed his task.   By  his conduct and example, encouragement has been given to those with him.   He has at all times shown enthusiasm for his tasks and a devotion to duty.   On occasions in the absence of his senior officers he has made decisions and taken action as the emergency required thereby assuimng responsibility above his rank and beyond that normally demanded of him.   He is always an example to others in conduct and appearance .   
Capt W R Hunter OC 50 Div Pro Coy, Maj Gen Comd 50 Div,  Lieut-Gen Comd 30 Corps.
National Archive WO 373/83.

Military Medal Citation.
Italy
On the 14 July 1944 Lance Corporal Nicholson was directing the traffic at the Bailey Bridge at CASTIGLIONE E FIORENTINO.   Very accurate shellfire was opened on the bridge but Lance Corporal Nicholson continued to direct traffic, ignoring the danger.
The drivers of a number of lorries approaching the bridge and seeing the bursts, took cover.   This Lance Corporal appreciated that these lorries were on an exposed stretch of the road and that a serious block in full view of the enemy would ensure their destruction.   With great calmness Lance Corporal Nicholson went down the road and ordered each driver to return to his vehicle and proceed on his way.   In this way he got the whole column moving again.
By his example and total disregard for danger, he kept the traffic flowing and  undoubtedly prevented a situation which might have resulted in serious loss of life and transport.   The bridge remained under fire almost continuously throughout the tour of his duty.
Awarded an immediate MM.   Recommended by the APM 6 Armd Div .  National Archive WO 373/9.

CMP (I).
Military Medal Citation.
Burma
Nov 17 1943 - May 14 1944   Throughout the divisonal campaign in the ARAKAN, this NCO has worked with untiring vigour, personally escorting convoys by day and by night over the NGAKYEDAUK PASS, especially during the later months of 1943, when the pass was in its initial and most dangerous stage.
When the unit lines in the Div HQ area at LAUNG CHAUNG were attacked by the enemy on 6 February 1944, Corporal Ellis at considerable personal  risk, carried a wounded signaller from the area, and drove him away to hospital in the Admin Box.   Later at 1730 hours the same day he returned with the OC unit in a jeep to assist in warning the last tanks to cover the withdrawal of the medium guns.   During the period the jeep was subjected to enemy machine gun fire and the three occupants could not break cover from behind it.   To get to safety Corporal Ellis started the jeep with his hand; jumped into the seat, and drove it to safety whilst the others hung on , on the sheltered side.   On the following day 7 February when communications by phone were out in the NGAKYEDAUK PASS, he proceeded together with the OC unit and Lance Corporal Bailey, in a carrier, to a point half way down the pass, which was in a few hours, cut by the enemy.   Throughout the three weeks seige which followed, this NCO worked continuously without relief, and was an outstanding example to the rest of his unit.
Awarded the MM.   Recommended by Major W C Boyle APM 7 Indian Div.  National Archive WO 373/35.
Lance Corporal Bailey was also awarded the MM.

CMP (I).
Military Medal Citation.    
Burma
PLAU, ARAKAN.   After the evacuation of the Div HQ Area on 6 February at 17.30hrs this NCO accompanied the OC unit back to the unit lines to assist in the withdrawal of the medium guns.   On that occasion he proceeded to the unit MT area to attempt to save a vehicle, although the area was occupied by the enemy;  and he only returned when the fire was heavy.   On 7 February he proceeded to the centre of the GNAKYEDAUK PASS, with the OC unit and Corporal Ellis, in three carriers.   The carriers returned and Lance Corporal Bailey was instructed to remain behind and bring back a party of BOR's (British other ranks) on foot, as the carriers were full.   After the departure of the carriers the road was cut by enemy fire between him and his destination.   Other personnel turned back but Lance Corporal Bailey took his party forward at considerable risk, made a detour through the jungle and returned to his unit several hours later in the admin box, although he had every excuse under the circumstance for returning to a safer place.
On 19 March when the enemy again attacked the box, and when they held a position on a high feature at the entrance to the east end of the box, this BOR under great personal risk rode his Motor Cycle out into the open paddy fields in view of the enemy and underfire, to inform the commander of 3 tanks to return to the box.
Recommended for MM by Major Boyle APM 7 Indian Division.  National Archive WO 373/35.
North West Europe.   Certificate not found.

Military Medal Citation.
North West Europe
On the night of 2 October 1944 Lance Corporal Murphy was on duty on the southern end of the NIJMEGEN pontoon bridge.   His task was to direct traffic and to ensure that vehicles of 69 Brigade Group who were crossing the bridge from north to south were directed to their concentration area.   Throughout the night the bridge and bridge approach were shelled and bombed, and many of the nearby houses set on fire.
He maintained a close watch in his area for craters and falling masonry which might block the road, and cleared away the rubble if necessary.   The guiding lamps had been rendered useless and as his voice was drowned by other noises, he had to jump on vehicle after vehicle to direct the driver.   In the general excitement of the situation many vehicles went in the wrong direction.   These he ran after and corrected. 
On one occasion blast from a bomb which burst neaby lifted him off his feet and threw him against a wall of a burning house several yards away.   Although severely bruised, cut and badly shaken he immediately returned to his task, with complete disregard for his personal safety,  and remained on duty until he was relieved three hours later when the last vehicle had passed.
Due to his energy and untiring devotion to duty, chaos, which would have led to the loss of vehicles and lives, was averted and the column was able to reach its destination without casualties.
Awarded an immediate MM.   Recommended by Captain W R Hunter OC 50 Div Pro Coy.  National Archive WO 373/52.

Greece.  Gold Medal of George I with swords (Greece).   Memorandum to: Commander in Chief, Middle East Forces.  From War Office, London, WII dated 30th March 1945. These awards were published in the London Gazette on 15th March 1945.
Lieut Gen Military Secretary.   National Archive WO 373/110.

North West Europe.  Citation for BEM:   During the period under review this NCO has been in command of the Provost Section attached to Main HQ.   It was his repsonsibility to mark the Div Centre Line during the advance through France & Belgium into Holland, usually ahead of Div HQ.   Sgt Lindridge never failed in this duty the importance of which cannot be exaggerated.   He has set a fine example to his men by his untiring devotion to duty and is strongly recommeded by me for the BEM.
Maj APM 7 Armd Div.   Maj Gen Comd 7 Armd Div.   Lt Gen Comd 12 Corps.   Liet Gen Comd Second Army.

Military Medal Citation.
North West Europe
During the period 1 August 1944 to 17 October 1944 W/Corporal F R Bunting has at all times shown a complete disregard to personal danger.   He assisted in the traffic control at BEERINGEN Bridge over the Albert Canal (Belgium) and the lamping and signing of BEERINGEN during consistent enemy shell fire on September 7-8-9 1944.   He also on 20-21 September assisted in lamping and signing the Guards Divisional centre line through NIJMEGEN, including the NIJMEGEN BRIDGE, again during consitent enemy shellfire.   His work has at all times, even during the most difficult circumstances been carried out extremely well.
Recommended for a periodical MM by APM HQ Guards Armoured Division.   National Archive WO 373/53.

Italy.   Citation for BEM:  On 15 Jul 44 L/Cpl Ball was on duty at 2 RSD 557 AOD accompanied by WAR DOG 2117/4977 "BLACKIE".   At approximately 04.20 hours, he entered a warehouse and surprised eight Italian civilians in the act of filling sacks with WD clothing.   He called on them to surrender, but on seeing that he was alone they attacked him with iron tent pegs.   L/Cpl BALL released his dog, which knocked one man to the ground and held him by the back of his neck.   L/Cpl BALL  struck one man on the head with the butt of his pistol, and kicked another in the stomach; both these men were temporarily stunned.   The others then tried to escape, but L/Cpl BALL managed to hold two of them, and the other three were arrested in the yard outside by another policeman.  As a result of the sense of duty and disregard for his own personal safety shown by this NCO, eight civilians were arrested and the theft of a large quantity of WD stores prevented.   Maj J S Potts 'B' Dog Pro Coy.   BUS Cripps Brigadier, Comd 56 Area.   Maj Gen G Lammie, Comd 3 District.   National Archive WO 373/72.

Italy.   Citation for BEM:   CSM MACCALLUM P W has at all times given the highest satisfaction and has received the praise of congratulations of numerous high ranking officers, with whom he has come in contact, as a result of investigations he has made.   From 20 Oct 43 to 
March 44 he was in charge of a Detachment located at GIOIA, where he was responsible for a large area.   An appreciation of his services was received from Major HAIG, APM 1st Airborne Div.   MACCALLUM has since been stationed at TARANTO and BRINDISI and he has continued to carry out his duties in the most exemplary and efficient manner.   He personally has been responsible for the recovery of many thousands of pounds worth of WD property.   On 29 Jul 44 at the scene of a petrol fire at Brindisi Docks MACCALLUM showed great courage and initiative in organizing and leading a party of 3, who succeeded in salvaging 200 casks of petrol, whilst the firemen played hoses on them.   MACCALLUM is a model of what a member of the S.I.B. should be, and is outstanding in every way.
Maj Bond APM HQ 52 Area.   Brigadier Comd 52 Area.   Maj Gen E P Nares Comd No.2 District.   National Archive WO 373/72.

Italy.   Citation for BEM:  During the early part of May, prior to the launching of the Cassino offensive 105 Provost Company was responsible for bringing the armour to the forward Army boundary.   This was done on tracks by night.   Sjt Burg was responsible for the greater part of this work, and to the outstanding manner in which he carried out his duties of track lighting and escorting over rough country without regard to personal fatigue and discomfort over long periods, the smooth and efficient way in which the armour was fed forward could largely be attributed.   On 4 Aug 44, when British troops entered Florence, Sjt Burge took his section into the city.   He was the senior NCO of a police detachment which went in in the early hours of occupation.   During the first ten days, when the city was not completely in Allied hands, Sjt Burge showed great coolness and efficiency during a most trying period.   The area was under shell and mortar fire and there were many cases of civilian disturbances and sniping.   The excellent example set to his men, his efficiency and devotion to duty, enabled his detachment to do invaluable work in establishing and maintaining order, keeping up civilian morale, controlling and preventing civilian and refugee movements.   At this time our line in the city was lightly held at the river;  had any of these factors assumed undue proportions, military operations in and around the city might have been severley hampered.   Sjt Burge has had charge of a section of this Company throughout the Desert, Sicilian and Italian campaigns.   His example to his men, and devotion to duty, have at all times been outstanding.   He has been twice mentioned in despatches. Lt Col J R Archer-Burton DPM 8 Army.   Brig DAQMG 8 Army.   National Archive WO 373/72.

North West Europe.   From Glasgow.   RSM 3 Div Pro Coy.   Citation for MBE.   RSM BAMBOROUGH has been RSM of 3 Div Pro Coy for the last two years.   For a long period and particularly during the last three months he has proved to be a Warrant Officer of exeptional ability and character.   Throughout these operations he has supervised the work of the Provost, particularly in the most forward areas always showing a fine example and being and inspiration to those under his command.
His long experience in CID work has proved invaluable: his success in dealing in crime ranging from murder to petty larcenty has been outstanding and due in great part to his patience and perseverence.   He is well known throughout the Division and unit commanders request his services when crime and looting is suspected.  Army Form. W.3121, WO 373/84

North West Europe.   MBE citation:  RSM WAKEFIELD has performed his duties exceptionally well since landing in NORMANDY in June 1944.   His personal smartness, keeness and energy have been a spendid example to the Provost Company, who have greatly benefited therefrom.   During the difficult times of the crossing of the river ORNE, RSM WAKEFIELD visited his MP posts continually and, by his coolness and cheerfulness, encouraged his NCO's, who were under sporadic shell fire a good deal of the time.   On many occasions when the officers have been away from Coy HQ, he himself has taken decisions and carried out difficult tasks most thoroughly.   By his splendid example of keeness and enthusiasm, he has done more than his share in making 110 Provost Coy and extremelty efficient unit.   From June till December RSM WAKEFIELD has never spared himself, and has set an unusually high standard for smartness, efficiency and hard work.   Lt-Col APM 8 Corps.   Lt-Gen Comd. 8 Corps.   Lieut-Gen Comd Second Army.  National Archive WO 373/84.

Military Medal Citation.
North West Europe
On 16 September 1944 during the operation of crossing the ESCAUT CANAL Sergeant Cox and his section were detailed to control traffic on the enemy side of the two newly built bridges.   The river banks from which it was necessary to control traffic were under observed fire.   Despite fire from the enemy Sergeant Cox remained on the bridge sites and by his coolness, fine example and constant supervision of his section, ensured the smooth flow of traffic.
On 18 October 1944 he again displayed courage and devotion to duty in the liberation of VENRAIJ
In his handling of refugees, thus keeping the roads clear for urgent operational traffic.   During this period he was under heavy shellfire and mortar fire but showing complete disregard for his own safety encouraged his section to carry out their work.
These examples are but a few intances of coolness and devotion to duty shown by this NCO during battle.
Awarded a periodical MM.   Recommended by Captain Durbin OC 3 Div Pro Coy.  National Archive WO 373/53.

Greece.   Citation for BEM:  The above named NCO has been attached to HQ 3 Corps, now HQ  Land Forces and Military Liaison, GREECE, and under my direct command for five months, during which time he has performed his duty with outstanding zeal and ability.   On arrival in GREECE, he took charge of Security at the entrance of HQ building, together with the task of handling surrendered enemy PW and repatriates, on his own inititative at all times of the day and night.   He voluntarily investigated and conducted searches for enemy personnel known to be in the area, a task in many cases known to be dangerous, and was responsible for many arrests.   When hostilities were declared against the rebels, his duties became increasingly arduous.   On the 10th Dec 1944 he was wounded by shell splinters, but continued with his duty without complaint.   By his efficiency, cheerfulness and devotion to duty, he has been an outstandign example to all with whom he has been in contact.
Capt DAMP LF & ML (G).   Brig Da & QMG HQ LF & MLG.  Liet Gen Scobie Comd Land Forces & Mil Liaison Greece.
National Archive WO 373/75 Pt.2.

Italy.   MBE citation:  Following the arrest of a soldier for absence, all the places where he had been living were checked up by CSM PROCTER, involving searching, enquiries in houses in SALERNO, CASTELLAMMARE and the FUSCALDO  Area, where the proceeds of robberies committed by this man in company with others were discovered.   One of his accomplices was found in a bedroom dressed in military uniform and another, dressed in civilian clothes hiding in a sack.   Further enquiries led to the arrest of two more deserters, one of whom was an American, in the possession of a stolen Jeep, but only after a struggle in the course of which, the latter was disarmed of a Browning Automatic pistol.   In their possession was a considerable sum of money and quantities of jewellery were found in the houses of civilians who had been harbouring all five men.   These civilians have since been arrested.   From evidence to hand it became evident that these men were responsible for several armed robberies in the environs of AVELLINO, which had begun some ten months previously.   Many of the victims of these robberies have now been traced by CSM PROCTER and their property identified.   Once these men had effected a hold-up on one road they would immediately switch to another part of the country.   On occasion they would represent themselves as Military Police.   Operating in the dark, identification by their victims was made extremely difficult.   By CSM PTOCTER'S diligence, patience and initiative a set of very clever criminals who worked with method and who always covered up their tracks, has been apprehended.   Lt Col DPM 3 District.  Maj Gen Comd 3 District.  National Archive WO 373/73.

Italy.   Citation for BEM.   During the four months from Sept to Dec 44 in the Divisional battles in ITALY, from the time of the capture of OSPEDALETTO to the final battles for FORLI, Sgt Armstrong was committed with his section with the fwd Brigades.   At CORIANO this NCO had to deal with traffic circuits that were particularly difficult to maintain and control but despite the many difficulties of movement, mostly by night, all the convoys routed through this town proceeded under CMP escort and quidance smoothly and without delay.
 At BERTINORO and CESANA, Sgt Armstrong displayed the same thoroughness and devotion to duty in his dealing with the Police control of these two towns and he was largely responsible, in the early days of the occupation, for maintaining the high standard of good order and discipline that existed amongst the British troops there
Sgt Armstrong has further enhanced his reputation by his skilful control of the Div PW Cage in GREECE, where he was responsible for the reception and evacuation of some two or three thousand of ELAS prisoners.
In the execution of his duties, often under the most trying conditions, this NCO has earned the highest praise for his control and initiative.   This exemplary conduct has undoubtedly been a source of inspiration to his men and has earned him the complete confidence of all Officers with whom he has worked..   Army Form W. 3121.  WO 373/73.
Italy.

Italy.   Citation for BEM:   On the evening of 22 Jun 44 no. 30503 Sjt C V EDMONDSON was on patrol with a Provost Officer and an Interpreter, when they had occasion to check two soldiers in a Jeep at SAN FERDINANDO.   Both soldiers abandoned the Jeep and ran away.   A few minutes later both men were seen driving another Jeep towards TRINITAPOLI at a fast speed and Sjt EDMONDSON gave chase.   The pursuit continued at a high speed until the leading vehicle crashed into a bridge, the occupants being thrown out.   One man escaped, but the other an armed deserter, was arrested by Sjt EDMONDSON.   Another Jeep driven by a deserter then arrived on the scene.   This man was in possession of a loaded T. M. G.   and a loaded Beretta pistol.   Sjt EDMONDSON arrested and disarmed this man.   Sjt EDMONDSON continued enquiries for a period of three weeks and was largely responsible for rounding up a complete gang of eight deserters who had been operating for six months in Eastern Italy, stealing and selling WD stores and equipment.   As a result six vehicles, 410 drums of oil and miscellaneous WD property and approximately 800,000 lire were recovered.   By Sjt EDMONDSON's disregard for his own safety during the incidents on the night 22/23 Jun 44, and the efficiency with which he conducted his investigations, the rounding up of a complete gang of dangerous criminals has been successfully effected.
Lt Col DPM 3 District.   Maj Gen Comd 3 District.   National Archive WO 373/73.

CMP(I).  Italy.   Citation for BEM:   Franks first proved himself a gallant and staunch supporter of his section when in action at CASSINO, Italy during the precarious and hazardous weeks in Feb 1944.   This NCO was a member of a forward section of Provost working with Brigade HQ in the much shelled villages of CAIRO and VILLA.   For five weeks he unselfishly worked under great strain in all kinds of weather without tiring, often under heavy enemy shell and mortar fire, patrolling the various traffic circuits, assiting broken down vehicles and reporting serious blows to the Engineers.   While at Jeep head in this area he assisted muleteers to get rations and ammunition to forward areas, and stretcher bearers to evacuate our wounded.   When the Gothic Line was breached at MONTE GRIDOLFO Franks again showed himself an outstanding leader.   Always cool and calculating he set the finest example of steadfastness and courage to his comrades.   His devotion to duty and utmost cheerfulness has given the confidence of all drivers of this division and is in accordance with the highest traditions of the Corps of Military Police (India).
Maj APM 4 Indian Div.   Maj Gen Comd 4 Ind Div.   National Archive WO 373/73.

Italy.   Citation for BEM:  No5730671 Cpl Edward Charles THOMPSON has served as a section Cpl in this company since joining on the 5th December, 1943.   His work during this period has at all times been of a very high standard, whether in the forward or rear areas.  On various occasions he has been called upon to take over the duties of section Sgt, when his capabilities and adaptability proved themselves beyond doubt.   His personal courage and efficiency, combined with calmness, has frequently been illustrated particulary during the period when the Division was in the CASSINO area, and during the advance beyond the GOTHIC LINE.   On the night 14/15th December 1944 he gave an example of his reliability by leading a party from his section to the scene of a fire in CASTEL DEL RIO map ref: 008167 ITALY 1:100,000 sheet 99 FAENZA, and organised the dispersal of vehicles whilst the village was still under shellfire.   His energy, efficiency, courage and enthusiasm has at all times been an example and credit to this company.   By his example he has assisted in maintaining a high morale  amongst all the junior NCO's, who have had the good fortune to serve under him.
Capt N Bentham Cmdg 78 Div Pro Coy.   Maj-Gen GOC 78 Div.  Maj Gen H Murray Comd 13 Corps.   National Archive WO 373/73
Italy.

10 TC Coy CMP War Diary, WO 169/13243.   Italy on the 1/10/1943 an armed gang rushed into the villa of Commenator Vinici of Cercola, threatening members of his family with pistols and plundered his house.   They also repeated this at other houses in the vicinity.   The Commandant of the Military Police was informed and immediately took action to round up the gang.   On the night of 16/10/1943 RSM Leaney H. J. C.M. Police with confidence and boldness, after obtaining the addresses of the gang from the Maresciallo of Gercola, arrested the larger part of the gang, who are now detained in the jail of Pomfioeale awaiting trial.   War Diary WO 169/13243 10 Traffic Control Company CMP.

Italy.   Citation for MID:  This C.Q.M.S. has done consistently excellent work since joining the Divisional Provost Coy. in December of 1944.   He started at the very bottom and by dint of extraordinary patience, unflagging energy and week after week of selfless hard work which entailed extremely long hours has built his part of the Company organisation into a sound healthy, and efficient department.   His work has been particularly praiseworthy in connection with Indian soldiers of whom he had no previous knowledge.   In particular he has proved himself to be most able during mobile operations.
Maj G W Jones APM 10 Indian Div.   Brig L J B MacDonald Comd. 10 Indian Div.    National Archive WO 373/90 Pt.3.
Recommended for periodic BEM, awarded MID.

6457492 WS/Cpl. Charles Clements.  8 Indian Division Pro Coy.
Citation:  This NCO has been in charge of a sub section of 8 Indian Div. Pro. Coy since May 1944.   During this period he has shown a high standard of leadership and devotion to duty.   On the R. GARI from May 11th to May 15th, Cpl Clements' men were on duty at track junctions or on bridges which the enemy regularly shelled.   He was always visiting them and encouraging them with his cheerfulness and cool disregard of danger.   Later, during the pursuit near PERUGIA, Cpl Clements had to take charge of the whole section owing to the illness of his section Sjt.   He again showed great fortitude and kept his men in good heart whilst manning points of considerable danger on the road to RIPA.   Cpl Clements cheerfulness and read assumption of responsibility have been a very great asset to the Company, and a fine example to the men serving under him.
Recommended by: Maj. H M Knee, APM 8 Ind. Div.   GOC 8 Ind. Div, Lt. Gen 13 Corps.
Reccommended for BEM awarded MID.

Italy.   Citation for BEM:  On the 22nd February, 1945, at a Petrol Depot near NAPLES, a Driver was caught obtaining petrol by false indents.   The unit telephoned for the Military Police and Lance-Corporal Gent and another NCO arrived in a jeep just as the prisoner had made his escape from the unit escort.   They both pursued him and he turned and fired several shots from his revolver at them.   After crossing a field on to the main road, he went to a 15cwt truck which was waiting and forced the driver out of the cab at the point of his pistol.   The other NCO ran towards the left hand door of the truck, but when a few feet away, he saw the prisoner pointing his revolver at him, and threw himself to the ground just as the shot was fired.   Meantime, Lance-Corporal Gent, who had been the driver of the jeep and was a few yards behind in the pursuit, saw all this taking place, including, as it appeared to him, the shooting of the NCO.  He ran to the right hand side of the cab, and after a struggle, succeded in knocking the revolver from the man's hand and with the help of the other NCO overpowered him and took him into custody.   By his utter disregard of his personal safety, and knowing he was tackling a desperate character, Lance Corporal Gent exhibited outstanding bravery.   National Archive WO 373/69.Pt.1.

Germany.   Citation for BEM:   On the 31st March, 1945, a Royal Engineer Sergeant and Sapper detonated an enemy mine at SUCHTELN, GERMANY.   The Sapper was killed and the Sergeant seriously injured.   Lance-Corporal Hunter, who was on duty at a post on a nearby road ran through an area known to be mined, ascertained that the Sapper was dead and dragged the injured Sergeant out of danger.   He then commandeered a WD vehicle and conveyed the Sergeant to hospital.   Lance -Corporal Hunter's action showed great courage and complete disregard of personal danger, and his prompt and courageous action was largely instrumental in saving the wounded man's life.   Two further mines were found within three yards of the site of the exploded mine.   
National  Archive WO 373/69 Pt.1.

Military Medal Citation.
Escape and evasion Italy
SAWYER was captured near TOBRUK on 14 Sep 42 together with other survivors of a small raiding force.   At the time of the Italian Armistice he was at MONTURANO (Camp 70) and after leaving without difficulty on 15 Sep 43 he went to SAN VITTORIA.   A month later he was caught by Fascists as he was returning from an unsuccessful attempt to reach Allied hands by sea.   On 15 Dec 43, SAWYER and an American cut the wire over his window and escaped from MACERATA (Camp 53).
Reaching TOLENTINO, SAWYER remained in that area until he accompanied a partisan band to MONASTERO.   Although he was recaptured by Fascists, he managed to slip away while awaiting transport and went to SAN GINESIO.   Early in May 44 he traveled North in the hope of reaching YUGOSLAVIA but gave up the attempt at MONTE MARCIANO.   After being guided over the GRAN SASSO, SAWYER and two officers were betrayed to the enemy.   On this occasion SAWYER was sent to LATERINA and on 17 Jun 44 he escaped during the evacuation of the camp.
SAWYER hid near TRAMUSCANO until he met British forces on 24 Aug 444.
Recommended for the award of the Military Medal.   National Archive 373/64.

India.   Citation for BEM:  At Barrackpore on 26th May, 1945, this NCO was riding as a passenger in a Jeep when an American bomber crashed near the road and immediately caught fire.   Lance-Corporal Telford at once ordered his driver to make for the scene of the accident, leaped out of the vehicle and regardless of personal danger ran straight to the aircraft, which by this time was burning fiercely,   He located two of the crew, both severley injured in the nose of the plane and succeeded in picking one of them up and carrying him clear of the plane.   The airman unfortunately later died of his injuries.   Lance Corporal Telford then attempted to reach the second man, but as he approached the plane for the second time an explosion in the aircraft scattered blazing petrol over a wide area and made his task impossible.   
National Archive WO 373/69 Pt.1.
26 May 1945 L/Cpl Telford CMP reports witnessing air plane crash in vicinity of Ishapore.   Success in extracating one of the crew.   Unit War Diary WO 172/6962.

Italy.   MBE Citation:   In July 1944 counterfeit Allied Military Currency in denominations of 500 and 1,000 Lira appeared in ROME.   Soon it became apparent that considerable sums were being circulated amongst Allied personnel and civilians and that the situation was becoming extremely serious.   WOII TUBBY L. was assigned to the task of locating the source of these spurious notes, which was thought to be in ROME, and to arrest the offenders.   From the day he received his orders until March 1945, when he had arrested 15 civilians, now known to be cunning and determined criminals, this Warrant Officer visited all military and civil organisations where such money might be passed and all were regimented to tender information spontaneously.   He sifted, compared and examined hundreds of spurious notes; checked and re-checked the stories of absentees and deserters until finally, through his own untiring efforts he single handed tracked down and seized the printing presses on which the notes were made, together with all the paraphernalia for counterfeiting.   He recovered 2,500,000 Lira in counterfeit Allied Military Currency which must have, otherwise seriously threatened the currency now in use.   Finally he presented such a weight of evidence that the first two counterfeiters to be tried by an Allied court chose to plead guilty.   In the midst of these investigations, he also successfully solved the reported murder of an allied soldier in FROSINONE in which no corpse could be found at the outset.   He located, retrieved, and identified the body as that of a Canadian soldier, for the murder of whom he arrested and brought to trial four Italian civilians.    Lt Col G White DPM Rome Area.  Alban Low, Brigadier British Troops Rome,  Lt Col Geoffrey White PM.  Major General Commander No2 District.   National Archive WO 373/73.

Greece.   Citation for BEM:  During the Civil War in GREECE, December 1944 to January 1945, L/Cpl BRENNAN was stationed with his Section in PIRAEUS where it was principally engaged in the control and feeding of refugees of which there were many thousands.   Throughout this period this NCO frequently displayed great initiative, energy and unlimited patience and tact in organising rations for the kitchens, assisting the aged and infirm to obtain medical treatment, arranging accommodation; and in general performing, in a highly meritorious and most praiseworthy manner, duties that were superior to those required of a junior NCO.  He gave his time and energy unstintingly to the performance of these duties, the greater part of which  were carried out voluntarily after he had completed tasks for which he had been detailed.   His unselfish devotion to duty in extremelty trying circumstances was quite beyond praise.. He undoubtedly contributed in a large measure to the successful feeding and housing of  the many refugees who locked into the area for which his Section was responsible and his work was frequently subject of favourable comments from officers of other branches and from civilian officials.   Thus, he did much to enhance the prestige of his Corps in particular and the service as a whole.
Maj Gen Comd 46 Div.   Lt Gen Scobie Comdr Land Forces, Greece.   National Archive WO 373/73.

Italy.   From London SE5.  RSM 112 Pro Coy.   MBE citation:  During the Italian Campaign from CASSINO to the PO VALLEY, this WO has been an inspiration to the remainder of the Company.   On one occasion he came on the scene of a burning lorry, which was endangering all the vehicles stopped in the vicinity.   Without thought for his own safety, he jumped into the lorry and drove it off the road out of danger of the other vehicles.   Although necessitating long hours of duty, his work in connection with the control of traffic on the mountain roads has been an example of his powers of organisation within the unit.   His quick grasp of the difficult problems enabled him to deal immediately with many situations produced by the severe winter weather.   The personal example shown by RSM WRIGHT has been an inspiration to all ranks of the Corps Provost Company.   Lt-Col APM 13 Corps.   Lt-Gen Commander 13 Corps.

Regimental number on citation reads 6769169.  Italy.    
Citation for BEM.  The above named NCO has, over a long period, continually distinguished himself by his high sense of duty, perseverance, and hard work, showing a great degree of bravery under difficult and unusual circumstances.   His cheerful character, together with the above remarks, have inspired other members of this section, and has led to the arrest of many dangerous criminals, both Service personnel and civilians.   In my opinion, he merits and award of the BEM.   One example of his work in the Special Investigation Branch is as follows:  Many offences had been committed by a gang of armed deserter-thieves in this Area during the later months of 1944 and it became know that certain deserters, well know to this Section, were responsible.   Extensive enquiries were made and certain plans adopted.   On 28 Nov 44, two members of this gang were arrested.   They were armed with Italian pistols.   The known ringleader and other members of his gang were still at large.   On 5 Dec 44., information was received that these men were in a public square in Bari.   Sgt. Hearn and two other SIB men, accompanied by a CMP Patrol went to this square.   The CMP Patrol could not be actively employed in the search for the deserters because of their conspicuous dress and were told to watch the movements of the SIB men.   Sgt Hearn and the other two SIB men then went into the crowded square and commenced to look for the deserters.   It was well known that they would be armed and they would resist arrest.   As he neared four men (3 British deserters and an Italian criminal) they opened fire with automatic pistols and ran quickly away, firing at the Sgt and other SIB men as they did so, but without hitting them.   Sgt Hearn chased two of the men towards the CMP patrol.   On seeing the patrol one of the two men (the ringleader) opened fire on them.   A CMP Cpl returned the fire and shot the deserter, who was then arrested.   Sgt Hearn continued after the other man and eventually arrested him.   The remaining two deserters escaped in the large crowd that gathered, but good work by Sgt Hearn led to their arrest the following day.   Subsequent on this incident, Sgt Hearn brought about the arrest of no less than 24 Italians who were charged with being concerned with the deserters in larceny and receiving stolen property.   Property to the value of over 4,000 (W D vehicles etc) was recovered against the ringleader alone.   It is considered that the arrest of this gang had a great deterrent effect on other less dangerous deserters who might then have been in this Area and the good work of Sgt. Hearn enabled this Section to concentrate on other pressing work.
Recommended by: DAPM 62 SIS.   Maj APM HQ 54 Area.  Brigadier Comd 54 Area.   Maj Gen Comd 3 District.   National Archive WO 373/73.

Italy.   Citation for BEM:  Duiring the period Oct 44 to Feb 45 armed highway and other violent robberies affecting Allied interests and attributable to deserters and civilian desperadoes were rife in Southern Italy, terrorising the civilian population.   SGT ORDWAY was engaged on special duty with a selected Police squad to combat this grave threat to law and order.   His opponents were notorious gunmen both military and civilians who used their arms without hesitation.   He personally effected the arrest of many of these gangsters.   This NCO's conduct was an outstanding example of courage, tenacity and devotion to duty which involved shooting affrays and physical violence.   The efforts of SGT ORDWAY were far beyond the demands of his normal duty and were responsible to a great extent for the successful liquidation of these terrorist gangs.
Lt Col H V McNally DPM 3 District.   Maj Gen Comd 3 District.   National Archive WO 373/73.   His number is shown as 7692841 in National Archive item.

Italy.   Citation for BEM:  For outstanding example and devotion to duty as RSM of the Provost Company, during the period 1st Jan to 31st Mar 45.   This WO throughout the period, has done exceedingly good work.   He has put in exeptionally long hours often under the most severe winter conditions and over the worst possible country from the point of view of communications.   It is in a large measure due to his constant cheerfulness, example and almost continual work that the roads were kept clear and vital transport reached its destination in the hills.   In addition he has been largely responsible for the complete re-organisation of the Provost Coy during the period.   His example has at all times been a source of inspiration to those under him.
Maj Jones APM 10 Indian Div.   Maj-Gen Comd 10 Ind Div.   Maj Gen Harding Comd 13 Corps.
Recommended for periodic MBE awarded Periodic BEM.
National ArchiveWO 373/73.

Military Medal Citation
Escape and evasion Italy
RAYNER was taken prisoner in N.Africa on 27 May 42.   At the time of the Italian Armistice he was a prisoner at MONTURANO (Camp 70).   Contrary to the orders of the S.B.O. he left this camp on 12 Sep. 43, forcing his way past the English and Italian sentries.
Travelling to the ASCOLI PICENO area RAYNER found shelter with Italian civilians.   From the beginning of March 44 until June 44 RAYNER did excellent work in distributing to other P/W supplies dropped by parachute and in collecting P/W into parties for crossing the lines.   In addition, he assisted in partisan activities for 5 months, being wounded during a rain on CASTIGANO on 12 Jun.44.   Six days later he entered ASCOLI PICENO with the partisans and assumed command until the arrival of Allied forces.   RAYNER continued to work for AMGOT for another month before he went to the Repatriation Centre.
Awarded the Military Medal.  National Archive WO 373/64
