United Kingdom.   Citation for BEM.   Since Sgt Sargent was posted to the 80 Div Pro Coy on 25 Feb 43 he has as an instructor, devoted long hours to the training of CMP personnel in Field Force work for overseas.   He has shown untiring energy and by his devotion to duty has produced excellent results.   At a recent Provost Marshal's conference at the War Office Lt. Col Mark-Sykes DPM AF HQ said "Some excellent Drafts have been received from 80 Division".   From my observations of Sgt Sargent's work I feel that it is principally due to his diligent and consicientious work that such results have been obtained.   In view of this I feel it is fitting that he be recommended for an award.
OC 80 Div Pro Coy.   Lt General GOC in C Western Command.   Maj Gen Comd 80 Division.   National Archive WO 373/156.

Military Medal Citation.
Italy
On 28 February 44 Sgt Andrews of the Provost Wireless Traffic Control Section received orders to connect VILLA TP to CAIRO TP by telephone and to lay the wires anywhere.   This communication was vital in  order to warn vehicles approaching the CAIRO circuit of enemy shelling, and to allow vehicles to proceed safely through the circuit only when shelling had temporarily slackened.   The circuit is a vital link for maintenance of forward troops.   He commenced work at about 0900 hours and had completed laying the line during the morning, but owing to heavy shelling the line required continuous repairs.   For 3 days Sgt Andrews tested and repaired many cuts in the line under constant shellfire. With complete disregard for his personal safety he kept this vital communication in working order.
On the 2nd day whilst running a new section of wire from his jeep he was blown up by a mine and though considerably shaken by concussion kept up his patrol of the circuit and repairs to the telephone line that day and insisted on continuing his work next day.   He was soon after posted to command 5 Brigade Pro Unit so that, in his own words "I could keep my eye on the CAIRO circuit" and on 17 March he was seriously wounded in the vicinity of VILLA.   He was an inspiration to all those who worked under him.
Awarded an immediate MM which was recommended by  Captain  L C Cook OC 4 Indian Div Pro Coy CMP(I).   National Archive WO 373/6.

Citation for Croix de Guerre 1940 with Palm:   Pte. Mcmillan, who disembarked with the unit in France in Sept 44, acted as Company runner in all the actions in which the Bn., was engaged until the cessation of hostilities in May 1945.   His total disregard for his own personal safety and utter fearlessness under fire were always evident, but never more so than at HALLDEREN, HOLLAND IN Oct. 44., when for four days his Coy was in close contact with the enemy in dug-in positions and subjected, in addition, to sustained and accurate mortar and artillery fire.   Throughout this period, he repeatedly made his way to Bn HQ with important intelligence when all other forms of communication were disrupted, and on his own inititative, constantly visited the foremost defences, encouraging his comrades, assisting with the evacuation of wounded and impressing all who saw him with this cheerfulness, indomitable courage and concern and consideration for his fellow men.   It was undoubtedly largely due to the fine example of gallantry and selflessness that the morale of his Company remained so consistently high.
Lt Col E l Percival Comd 6th HLI.   Maj Gen E Hakewill Smith Comd 52nd (Lowland) Div.   Lieut Gen G I Thomas.
National Archive 373/111/2/Bundle 2.

Belgium.   Citation for the Belgian Croix de Gurre 1940 with Palm:   RSM STOCKTON has served with the 11th Armoured Division throughout the French, Belgian and German campaigns.   His initiative and standard of work for the whole period under the most trying conditions has been exeptional.   During the rapid advances through Belgium to Antwerp, his efforts to maintain traffic control largely contributed to the free and directed movement of both troops and supplies.
Capt OC 11 Armd Div Pro Coy.   Maj Gen Comd 11 Armd Div.   Maj Gen Roberts GOC 8 Corps District.  National Archive 373/111/2 Bundle 1.

Italy.   Citation for US Bronze Star:  The rapid movement of men and supplies on forward maintenance tracks of the Divisional Axis was of paramount importance in assuring the success of the battles in the hills.   The task of police road patrol was assigned to Corporal Redbond.   For a period of over a month (15th February to 20th March) Corporal Redbond patrolled the PORTELLA, VILLA, CAIRO circuit day and night.   This circuit underwent constant enemy shelling, but with complete disregard for his personal safety, Corporal Redbond policed vehicles through the circuit, kept shell holes on the road filled in by prompt messages passed to field engineers, and successfully recovered damaged vehicles by calling up the workshops recovery.   The two policemen under his command, who helped him in his task, were killed by enemy shelling and Corporal Redbond had to complete his task on his own.   His bravery was an inspiration to all those who came in contact with him on his arduous work.
National Archive WO 373/148

New Year Honours.   Major (temporary) Bertram Frederick William White (202083), Royal Army Service Corps.
Citation:-   Major White has been Assistant Provost Marshal in Vienna since July 1946.   For four years he has carried out his duties in an Exemplary manner, displaying exceptional ability, judgement and tact in dealing with the many incidents involving British Troops, Austrians, or members of other Occupational Forces.
He displayed these qualities in a marked manner on 22 August 1949 when, in a British Sector of the city, a hostile Austrian crown was about to attack a Russian Vehicle in which an Austrian subject was being transported against his will.   His firm handling of the situation not only freed the Austrian but dispersed the crown and thus prevented a serious incident.
Again between 24th and 28th February, 1950, his firm and tactful action prevented Soviet attempts to search the British European Airways omnibus proceeding to and from the British Airfield.
He has rendered service of a high order for a long period under difficult conditions;  throughout which he has retained the confidence and respect of all nationalities and ranks.
Recommended by Brigadier C Knowles, Commander Vienna Garrison and the C in C & High Commissioner for Austria.

Police Review 1916:It has been officially reported that Lance Corporal Brace of the Military Police has been awarded the Military Medal for bravery in the field.   We understand that Brace, whilst carrying a wounded officer, was badly hit by shrapnel in the neck, a serious operation being afterwards necessary.   This occurred "Somewhere in France" last November.   Brace has quite recovered, and is now at Aldershot.   The Chief Constable (Portsmouth) has sent a telegram of contratulations to the worthy recipient.   Police Review 29/9/1916, page 407.

Extract from the Essex Newsman 3 February 1917.  TWO BRAVE M.M.P.'S.   MILITARY MEDALS PRESENTED AT CHELMSFORD.
Corporal Buck:  This N.C.O. and another were on duty near Bellevue Farm, Albert, on July 19, at cross-roads important to traffic, the post was heavily shelled.   About 4 p.m. a shell exploded a bomb store.   The above mentioned N.C.O., despite the continuous shelling of the road near the post and the explosions of bombs, succeeded in diverting the traffic and regulating it without accident, casualty or congestion, they also cleared the road of unexploded bombs, which might have caused injury.

Despatch of Lt Gen G F Milne CB, DSO, Commanding British Salonika Army:  I take this opportunity to bring to notice the excellent work performed by the Military Police.   In an unaccustomed situation with troops of five allied nations, in addition to a mixed population their work has been very heavy and varied in character. company_id: VI CYCLIST BATTALION ARMY CYCLIST CORPS
citation:
France.   Citation for Military Cross:  For conspicuous gallantry and devotion to duty in action near Borissois on 10th November, 1918.   A cyclist patrol which was going from Borissois to La Folie Farm was in danger of being cut off by a party of the enemy.   Realising the danger of the patrol, he went out across country to find it, and bring it back by another route.   Although exposed to heavy machine-gun fire, he succeeded in reaching it, and brought it back safely.   The vigorous and boldness with which he has handled patrols have been a great asset throughout.
Initial award shown in London Gazette 31266, page 4325 dated 2/4/1919.

MFP.  France.  Sergeant acting Sergeant Major.  MSM for Gallantry, Citation, Boulogne Base, L of C Area, dated 24/3/1917, schedule No. 87277.   On the 10th September 1916 whilst a railway van was being unloaded at the Base Port and was about two-thirds full a shell exploded killing one man, wounding several others and setting the ammunition boxes on fire.   A chemical fire engine was quickly brought to the scene, but it was necessary for someone to enter the burning van with a hose to extinguish the fire.   This S/M CHARLESWORTH did on his own initiative thereby averting what could probably have been a very serious disaster.   Additional pension of 6p per diem recommended should he be ultimately discharged to pension.
Base Commandant, Boulogne.   GOC L of C Area.   Maj Gen W E Payton Military Secretary For Commander in Chief.   GHQ 12/5/1917.

The particulars of these acts of gallantry and devotion to duty are as follows: At Coxyde on 5 Sept 1917 Pte A Scott was on duty at cross roads when his post was being heavily shelled, one shell throwing the roof of a house onto his post and telephone wires were also cut and being actually entangled round the soldiers legs.  He assisted to collect the debris and the wires, at the same time as directing and controlling traffic.   During this period the horse in an ambulance bolted and he assisted in stopping it.   Shelling was continuous during the whole period on the same occasion Cpl's Diffley & Pollard came to Pte Scott's assistance voluntarily and they assisted him in clearing up the debris, collecting the wire and stopping the runaway horse.

On the morning of 16th October, 1951 L/Cpl Head was on duty in Ismailia during the civil disturbances in that town.   He stationed himself in the NAAFI Families' Shop in which a number of British women and children were situated when the disturbances broke out.   Throughout the incident, with commendable resolution and resource, L/Cpl Head protected these families from violence at the hands of the mob.   General Officer Commanding the British Troops in Egypt wishes to place on record his appreciation of the courageous conduct of this NCO.

During operations N.E. of YPRES on October 31st, 1917, this N.C.O. was on duty at the Divisional Advanced Prisoners of War Collecting Station. he displayed great courage and devotion to duty for over 24 hours, in controlling traffic, assisting in unloading ammunition from broken limbers, assisting in the removal of a broken wagon which was impeding traffic, in addition to his duties at the Collecting Station, whilst under heavy shell fire.   He also gave valuable assistance to the staff of the Advance Dressing Station at the same place, by aiding in the evacuation of wounded, and controlling the traffic in such a manner under shell-fire, that the working of the ambulances was not interfered with.

War Diary WO 95/409 4 dismounted Traffic Control Unit MFP.  30/11/17 Received orders for HQ and 2 Grouop to move to Hermies to undertake Traffic Control duties on Canal Road. moved 4 pm, arrived Hermies 6pm and took over posts on canal road.   2/12/17 Road under shellfire, 4995 Pte Woodward wounded and evacuated.   4/12/11 4.30 pm Received orders to withdraw from Canal Road at dawn, 5.30 am 5/12/17.    21/12/17 Received notification that No. 13011 L/Cpl Shackleton F and No. 90503 Pte Richardson W J, Army Cyclist Corps  have been awarded the Military Medal for work on the Canal Bridge.

MMP.   From Oxford.  Italy.    DCM Citation.
673 CORPORAL (ACTING SGT)  M BROWN 
MILITARY MOUNTED POLICE
For conspicuous gallantry and devotion to duty.   On many occasions prior to and during attacks, he went over ground which was being heavily shelled, posting his men at various points of vantage, and bringing down prisoners, collecting stragglers, and guiding walking wounded.   During a congestion of traffic, caused by hostile shells as troops were passing, he took control, guided troops forward, cleared away the dead and wounded, and repaired the damage, so that the traffic was delayed for fifteen minutes only.
MMP.   Notification of DCM.   Italy.   Sgt.

MMP.   France.   26 Division.  From Guilford.   Later A/SSM.  On the 28th, 29th and 30th March, 1918, for thirty-six hours continuously, the above mentioned NCO's rendered invaluable services in keeping in the line and taking back into the line, stragglers of several Divisions, scattered by heavy shell fire coming down at the time.
This work was carried out at great personal risk, under very heavy shell fire and exceptionally difficult circumstances, with an untiring energy and devotion to duty which were above all praise.   There is no doubt that by their bravery and energy A/SSM Lelliot, Sergts. Taylor and Ashdown kept the line before Domart supplied with valuable reinforcements, which may have averted very serious consequences.
Recommended MM by APM 20th Division.   (Page 86 The History of the Office of the Provost Marshall and the Corps of Military Police, By Capt A Vaughan Lovell-Knight, July 1943).

France & Flanders.  The Police Review, 17/5/18 page 156.   The following has been received from her husband by Mrs McKay, wife of L/Cpl McKay, of the Hull City Police:-  On the morning of the 9th April I was on traffic control duty, when the road in the vicinity of my post was being heavily shelled by enemy artillery.   The traffic at the time was heavy with all kinds of troops and transport.   Although two shells burst - one behind and one in front I am thankful to say I am no worse for my experience.   After the second shell burst a soldier who was on horse back was hit and thrown to the ground.   I immediately went to his assistance, but found he had been killed instantaneously.   I then removed him to the side of the road  clear of the traffic and then resumed my duty at my post.   On the 13th inst. I was recommended for the Military Medal.   Police Review, 17/5/1918, page 156.

P/80 SERGEANT A H TAYLOR
20 INFANTRY DIVISON MILITARY MOUNTED POLICE
On the 28th, 29th and 30th March 1918, for thirty-six hours continuously, the above mentioned NCO rendered invaluable services in keeping the line and taking back into the line, stragglers of several Divisions, scattered by heavy shell fire coming down at the time.   This work was carried out at great personal risk, under very heavy shell fire and exceptionally difficult circumstances, with an untiring energy and devotion to duty which were above all praise. MMP.   18 Division.   From Liliput.   Military Medal Citation.
P/8088 ACTING SERGEANT C M  MORRELL
18 INFANTRY DIVISION MILITARY MOUNTED POLICE
On the 21 March 1918, was in charge of a forward stragglers collecting station at Reiz (north of Channy, Aise).   This NCO worked very hard and under very trying circumstances and under heavy shell fire.   Collected stragglers and made them into formed bodies, returning them to their units.  It was due to his untiring efforts that the line was reinforced.

Recommended for MM by APM 18th Division.

MMP.    18 Division.     From Kettering.   Military Medal Citation
P/8093 PRIVATE ACTING LANCE CORPORAL L ROBINSON
18 INFANTRY DIVISION MILITARY MOUNTED POLICE
On the 21 March 1918, while in charge of a stragglers' post at Remigny (near Channy, Aise) did excellent work in collecting stragglers under heavy shell fire and returned them to their several units.   He remained at his post until ordered to reture owing to the advance of the enemy.   It was entirely due to this NCO's bravery and example that these men got back to the line so quickly.

Recommended for MM by APM 18th Division

Italy:  In ITALY from October 43 to April 44 and particularly during the period January to April 44.   Has maintained an exceptionally high standard of work for prolonged periods. MFP.    DCM Citation.
P/862 LANCE CORPORAL (ACTING CSM) A SIMPSON
MILITARY FOOT POLICE
At Amiens, from 23 March to June 1918, he performed his difficult duites under continuous shell and bomb fire with a complete contempt of danger.   He rendered valuable assistance in the direction of traffic on the night of 23 March, when an ammunition train was blown up at Longueau, while on the night of the great air raid on 26 March he visited all the posts and patrols, showing a fine example of courage to him men.   The efficiency of the Amiens detachment during months of almost constant shell and bomb fire was largely due to his coolness and untiring devotion to duty.
Shown as 5383 A/Sjt H Sutton D Gds in this LG.

MMP. DCM Citation.
P/3155 LANCE CORPORAL T WATTS
34 DIVISION MILITARY MOUNTED POLICE
For consistent devotion to duty during the period 26 February to 16 September, 1918, and particularly at St. Leger during the enemy attack in March, where he did most valuable work in collecting stragglers and assisting wounded, while in charge of three stragglers' posts.   The cool courage, judgement, and endurance which he displayed on this and other occasions under heavy shellfire have been most marked.
MFP.   L/Cpl (A/CSM) Town Commandant Arras.   Notification of DCM.

MFP.  DCM Citation.
P/1373 LANCE CORPORAL (ACTING CSM) R H YOUNG
ARRAS DETACHMENT MILITARY FOOT POLICE
During the British offensive in the latter part of August 1918, when the traffic through Arras was abnormally heavy, he largely contributed to the excellent result that there was not a hitch anywhere, remaining on duty as much as twenty hours a day, in spite of frequent shelling and bombing, thus maintaining and improving the reputation he had earned for conscientious work under conditions of danger during the two and a quarter years that he has been in Arras.   He has never spared himself, but has invariably set a fine example of devotion to duty and self-sacrifice.

France & Flanders.  For Gallantry, (with pension).   Pte (A/Cpl).
Citation: Detective Corporal Joseph Coxon, (Already in possession of MSM).
At PARIS on the 12/3/1919 this NCO in company with No. P7932 L/Cpl WEBSTER, B, MFP had a desperate affray with two deserters.   One of the latter used a revolver freely, tow of the shots taking effect on L/Cpl Webster and causing his death.   COXON showed the greatest of gallantry and it was solely owing to his exertions that these two men were eventually arrested.   His action was all the more meritorious as although wounded in the arm he nevertheless pluckily continued the chase although being fired at freely.
     This is not the first occasion on which this NCO has shown great courage and coolness in face of danger.   He has frequently been in very awkward positions but has always emerged with the utmost credit to himself.
He is fully deserving of a high award.
Col. OC Troops, Paris.   E O'Brien, Col. Hon, Brig-Gen, President FGCM, GOC Central Area L of C, awarded bar to MSM and extra 6d per day pension.

MMP.  DCM Citation.
P/3 SERGEANT S W HALLAWAY
25 DIVISION MILITARY MOUNTED POLICE
On the night of 7 October, 1918, he was on duty near St. Martin for seven hours under constant shelling.   It was due to his coolness and disregard of danger that the flow of the traffic was not impeded, and he was further instrumental in saving many casualties by his intelligent control.   He has consistenly carried out his duties in an exemplary manner.

Citation for MM:  Australian Corps HQ, France.   On August 14th 1918 a dump of gun ammunition caught fire.   This NCO with great presence of mind and gallantry removed the camouflage and put out the fire though not before two of the cartridges had exploded.   His gallant act was the means of saving considerable quantities of ammunition and possible casualties.
Routine Order No44 by Lieut Gen Sir John Monash KCB.

MFP.   DCM Citation.
826 CORPORAL (ACTING CSM) H GAFF
1 ARMY MILITARY FOOT POLICE
He showed marked gallantry under heavy shell fire at Armentieres in 1917 and early in 1918, when the town was deluged with gas.   He carried out more than his duty, absolutely fearlessly until, in the end, he himself became gassed.

MMP.   Italy.    DCM Citation.
P/10738 LANCE CORPORAL (ACTING SGT) A JACKSON
MILITARY MOUNTED POLICE
During the advance over the Piave (Italy) and on the night of the 26/27 October 1918, he maintained his position on the Maserada Bridge throughout a very heavy bombardment by shells and bombs.   The great coolness he displayed, and the careful handling of the troops prevented a panic which would have led to a loss of life.

MMP.   From Dublin.   DCM Citation.
472 SERGEANT (ACTING SSM) M HEALY
MILITARY MOUNTED POLICE
For conspicuous gallantry and devotion to duty.   He showed great efficiency in the performance of his duties, extending over a period of two years.
Acts of Courage Extracted From The Corps Order Books.
472 ACTING/SQUADRON SERGEANT MAJOR M W HEALEY
MILITARY MOUNTED POLICE
Extract from V Corps Routine Orders dated 13/2/18.
The Corps Commander wishes to express his appreciation of the following act of courage on the part of No. P/472 A/SSM M W Healey, MMP.
On the morning of the 10th inst, a pair of horses attached to a wagon bolted down the road.   A NCO made an attempt to stop them but failed, A/SSM Healy with great promptitude and at much personal risk dashed in and seized the reins of the near horse and hung on until he had brought the runaways to a standstill.   The road was used by a considerable amount of traffic and the prompt action of this Warrant Officer averted what might have led to a  serious accident and damage to a pair of Government horses and the limber.   A record of the above will be made in the Regimental Conduct Sheet of this Warrant Officer in accordance with para 1919 (XIV) of King's Regulations.

Provost Officer. Korea 1 July to 31 December 1952.   DAPM 1 Commonwealth Division 1952-1953.   Major Anthony Clive Rawlings (64576) The Buffs, Royal East Kent Regiment.
Citation:  Major Rawlings became DAPM 1 Commonwealth Division in Feb 1952,   During the whole time he has held the appointment he has spared no effort to ensure that discipline within the Division has been maintained to a high standard.
     He has been faced with many difficult situations due to the different disciplinary codes of the Commonwealth contingents.   By his tactful handling and his own high standards these difficulties have been overcome.
     By close personal liaison he has established excellent relationships with the America authorities.   This aspect has been of the greatest importance in the maintenance of discipline.
     Many of the Provost personnel have been young and inexperienced, but by his own determination and drive he has succeeded in moulding them into a smart and efficient company.
     His personal example and devotion to duty under difficult conditions has been outstanding and fully merit recognition by the appropriate reward.
Recommended by AA & QMG 1 Commonwealth Division, GOC 1 Commonwealth Division, C in C British Commonwealth Forces, Korea.

France.   Pte (A/Sgt).   Name on medal card George Henry Hooten.  Citation:  On the 28th March, 1918, this NCO was in charge of a battle stragglers' post at Cayeux.   He kept his post there until it became necessary to withdraw successfully to Ignscourt, Demuin, Hangard and Domart.   Sergt. Hooton was told to decide when it was necessary to withdraw his post and he showed a high sense of duty in remaining on in each place until shelling made it practically impossible to deal with stragglers.   This NCO did very good work and handed over several hundred stragglers each day to Brigade Headquarters.
Recommended for MM by APM 66th Division.   Corps History 1942, Lovell-Knight.

MMP.  France & Flanders.   DCM Citation.
607 PRIVATE G ROYLE
MILITARY MOUNTED POLICE
For conspicuous gallantry and devotion to duty.   He has performed consistent good work throughout, and on one occasion displayed great courage in controlling traffic under heavy shellfire.
France & Flanders.

C in C's Commendation:   During the night 26/27 Nov 61 Cpl Lee was called to Caithness Barracks, Verden, where there was a soldier on the roof threatening to throw himself off.   Cpl Lee gained access to the roof through the trap door of a small wooden structure which stood about seven feet high above the roof.   From there he could see the man lying about twenty feet away astride the roof.   He was unable to use his hands and appeared to be in great danger of falling off.   Without hesitation Cpl Lee sung himself over the edge of the wooden structure and was lowered to the roof.  He then inched his way along to the man.   When Cpl Lee reached him the soldier tried to put his hands on Lee's shoulders and looked as though he would grapple with him.   With extreme calmness Cpl Lee put the soldier's hands back on the roof, gave him a cigarette and sat talking to him.   After a few minutes Cpl Lee dragged him back to the wooden structure, got himself behind the man and hoisted him up the side of the box so that he could be pulled in through the trap door.   The roof was sixty feet high and only six inches at its apex.   It had been raining hard, the roof was very cold and slippery.   By showing complete disregard for his own safety and great courage Cpl Lee averted an almost certain tragedy.   The Commander-in-Chief directs that an entry should be made in the Regimental Conduct Sheet of the above named in accordance with Queen's Regulations paragraph 1633 (0).
Extract from B.A.O.R. G.R.O. Issue No. 416 (6488-6508)

MMP.  Albert Medal Citation.
CORPORAL JAMES SMITH
MILITARY MOUNTED POLICE
The King has been pleased to award the Albert Medal to Lieutenant (acting Major) William Revell Smith, MC, RFA, Sergeant Alexander Gibson, Royal Engineers, and Corporal James Smith, Military Mounted Police, in recognition of their gallantry in endeavouring to save life at Wizernes in January last.   On the 17th January, 1919, a fire occurred at the brewery at Wizernes.   In the engine room a Frenchman, whose cries for help could be heard, had been entombed by a fall of masonry which completely blocked the entrance.   The upper part of the building was blazing fiercely, and the only entrance to the engine room was by a small hole in the wall which carried the machinery belting.   Major Smith, Sergeant Gibson, and Corporal Smith succeeded in making their way through this hole into the room, and worked for three quarters of an hour before they exposed the head and shoulder of the entombed man, who was found to be dead.
They undoubtedly risked their lives in endeavouring  to save life, for a further collapse of masonry (which appeared imminent) would have completely cut off their exit.

France.   Citation for French Croix de Guerre with Bronze Star:  On the night 4/5 Jul 44 Cpl Guest was visiting Provost points on the lateral routes NORTH OF PERIERS SUR LE DAN 0756, with complete disregard of enemy shelling.    At 2330hrs he reached a well known danger spot - X-rds 067775 - and found the pointman suffering from shell blast but trying to check the severe bleeding of a R Sigs DR who had been twice hit by shell splinters at that point.   Cpl Guest at once took charge, rendered intelligent first aid, and, appreciating that the wounds needed immediate Medical attention, drove the DR to the nearest RAP, through continuous shelling.   The MO's later report left no doubt that Cpl. Guest's cool and prompt action saved the DR's life.   The DR had said that the messages he carried were of great importance, and Cpl Guest took them and drove forward again through shell fire, and delivered them to their destinations.   Cpl Guest landed in France soon after D Day, and his record throughout the campaign for devotion to duty under all circumstances has been exemplary.
OC 102 Pro Coy.   APM 1 Corps, Lt-Gen Comd 1 Corps.   National Archive WO 373/186.
Award not found in London Gazette.

France.   Citation for French Croix de Guerre with Bronze Star:  On 21 july 1944 a Provost Section of which L/Cpl PARRY was a member was engaged on Traffic Control duties in the area of LA MARIQUET (map ref 117734 Sheet 78/2).  At approximately 18.00hrs the Military policeman, who was on point duty where tanks were crossing the main road EAST of RANVILLE, was killed on his point.   L/Cpl PARRY was detailed to take over this point.   In spite of intense enemy shelling L/Cpl PARRY proceeded to control the traffic as though the situation was perfectly normal.   There is no doubt that the steadfastness and impeturbability of this L/Cpl was an source of inspiration to the drivers of all passing vehicles and his courage enabled a considerable congestion of vehicles at this point to be avoided.
Maj APM Gds Armd Div.   Maj Gen Comd Gds Armd Div.   National archive WO 373/186.
The NCO killed on this point was 1441182 L/Cpl Stead J Gds Armd Div who is buried in Ranville War Cemetery.

Normandy.   Citation for French Croix de Guerre with Silver Star:   WOI MARSTON was RSM of 113 Pro Coy CMP (P) (30 Corps) and as such landed in France on the 9 June 1944.   During the whole of the period from the original landings until the liberation of France he took and active part in the operations of 30 Corps.   He showed great energy and efficiency in the execution of his duties, which was several times carried out under heavy fire.   The outstanding powers of organisation and command shown by him in carrying out the important work of the RSM of the Corps Pro Coy undoubtedly contributed to the liberation of France.   David Melville, APM 30 Corps.   Maj-Gen Thomas Commander 30 Corps.   National Archive WO 373/186.

Citation for C de G with Bronze Star:  At dawn on 26 June 1944 the battle of FONTENAY was in full progress, with the EAST end of the village still in enemy hands, the WEST held by our own troops.   It was therefore decided to push a Bn of the reserve Bde through the WEST side of the village at dawn on the 27 June to seize a commanding feature SOUTH of the village.   On the morning of 26 June Sgt ALSOPP was detailed to set out with an officer of the Bde concerned to recce a route across country through FONTENAY by which the Bn could move up.   This recce was carried out successfully as far as FONTENAY, but the battle was raging in the streets and it was impossible to continue through the village to the SOUTH side.   At 20.00hrs on the evening of 26 June Sjt ALSOPP set out once more to mark the route with coloured lights,   The whole of the area was being heavily shelled and mortared, and FONTENAY itself was on fire.   Unperturbed, Sgt ALSOPP marked the route right up to the village, and was then faced with the task of completing the route through FONTENAY and to the SOUTH, over the ground he had been unable to recce that morning.   The village was under extremely heavy enemy shelling and mortaring, and spandaus were firieng down the street.   Enemy tanks were known to be operating.   With complete disregard of his own personal safety, Sjt ALSOPP moved forward by bounds over completely unknown ground, marking the route through the orchards surrounding the houses until he reached the objective given.   Then, realising the extreme likelihood of the lights being extinguished either by shell fire or enemy patrols Sjt ALSOPP did not return to his HQ, but for the rest of the night moved along the route he had marked, checking and rechecking the lamps,  heedless of the enemy mortaring and the extreme danger that accrued from the proximity of enemy fighting patrols.   Three hours before dawn the Bn for which he had marked the route moved up in complete darkness, without a man straying from the route.   At dawn the Bn had reached its forming up area and soon after the attack went in.   The success of that extremely difficult night move across unknown country was almost entirely due to Sgt ALSOPP's bravery and selfless devotion to duty in marking and maintaining the route despite the most difficult and dangerous conditions.   Date of Citation 19 Dec 44.
Maj Gen Comd 49 Inf Div.   National Archive WO 373/186.
War Diary WO 171/4240 49 (WR) Division Pro Coy   April 45 The OC heartily contratulates 3384928 Sgt G Allsop on being awarded the Croix de Guerre with Bronze Star.   Name spelt Alsop and Allsopp in citation, award not found in London Gazette.

Normandy.    Citation for Croix de Guerre with Bronze Star:   The above NCO with his section of Military Police was detailed under a Provost Officer, for duty with the 4th Armd Bde when that Bde had crossed the ORNE and was pushing south towards FALAISE.   During this period when his men were for the first time serving under dangerous conditions, he continued to visit and encourage them.   One of the NCO's was posted at a cross roads which was subjected to more frequent shelling and mortaring than other points..   He repeatedly visited his NCO and eventually returned to the point and remained there until orders were given for the pointsmen to be withdrawn    Later Sjt SIMMONDS was attached with his section of Police to a Bde of 15 (S) Div when it was about to cross the river SEINE at LE MUIDS.   It was necessary to post two Military Policemen at different points on the banks of the river on the night before the crossing was made.   One of these points had been under sporadic enemy small-arms fire during the preceding day, and both points were isolated for several hours during the night.   Sjt SIMMONDS again displayed a keen sense of duty in visiting these pointment, constantly until it was evident that the positions had ceased to be dangerous.   Circumstances had placed this NCO on some of the most dangerous assignements which the company have had to perform and he has on all these occasions shown a devotion to duty which were of the highest traditions of the Corps of Military Police, and which has proved an excellent example to those serving under him.
DAPM 108 Pro Coy.   Lieut-Gen Comd 12 Corps.   National Archive WO 373/186

CMP (I).  Military Medal Citation.
Burma   
In the Arakan on the evening 17th February 1944 a congestion of vehicles was caused at Briatco Bridge through the area being under heavy fire and from approaching enemy patrols No 2322088 L/Cpl J Macdonald was on MP patrol in the area.   Ignoring the fire completely he assisted in the driving away one at a time 8 ambulance cars of wounded to 15 CCS.   After evacuating the wounded he showed great courage and determination in returning on several occasions to the area under fire to recover supply vehicles containing rations.  This NCO's courageous action saved many valuable vehicles and enabled a number of casualties to reach a CCS.
Awarded an  immediate MM  recommended by Captain J Glover OC Pro Unit 5th Indian Division and Major C P Kaye APM 5th Indian Div.   National Archive WO 373/32.

Singapore.  1 Jan 1949 - 30 June 1949.  Citation for BEM:  This NCO was for a long time in sole charge of the S.I.B. Detachment, Malaya - by his efforts crime in that Area was capably and efficiently dealt with.   He carried out many very involved and complicated enquiries, and most of them were brought to a very satisfactory conculusion.   Some of these enquiries took this N.C.O. into the backlanes of Malaya, into areas which are now being patrolled by Civil Police and Military, but this Sgt. Always put his job first and himself and his safety second.
Maj R B Sexton APM SIB.   Col Godfrey Fawcett PM FARELF.   Maj Gen GOCV Singapore District.   National Archive WO 373/128

Malaya 1 January 1949 - 1 June 1949.   Citation for BEM:  As a result of allegations made in the local press that relations between the Chinese population of KUANTAN and the Coy of 2 Malay Regt, KUANTAN were in a very bad state due to the bad behaviour of the latter, a small Detachment of RMP were sent by air to KUANTAN on 16 Dec 48.   Included in this party was 22212008 SGT WALFORD D. S. (then a L/Cpl).   This NCO had received instructions from me that he was to assume the role of a civilian and to circulate the town with a view to obtaining first hand opinions of a cross-section of the Community.   Under arrangements made with the local police, SGT WALFORD assumed the indentity of a visiting free-lance journalist, and was accommondated at the local Rest House.   KUANTAN is a notorious bandit area, and to carry out his task this N.C.O. had to visit many places which were both isolated and dangerous.   In the duty this N.C.O. had to carry out dressed as a civilian, it was deemed unsuitable that he should carry arms.   He was therefore at all times completely unarmed.   SGT WALFORD has a very wide knowledge of the inhabitants of this area and as a result he submitted a report of a very high order which cast much light on the cause of this trouble.   This was having serious repercussions on the relationship between the Army and Civilian population.   The report was full and detailed and contained many constructive criticisms and suggestions which were of extreme value not only from the point of view of the Disciplinary aspect of the case, but had a direct bearing on the successful continuation of operations in the area.  At the conclusion of his investigation I received high praise on his behalf, from the District Commissioner and also the Officer Commanding the Police District.   His report was submitted to the G.O.C. Malaya Dist who considered it to be extremelty valuable.   The G.O.C. commended WALFORD personally for his work.   This N.C.O. during the whole of his tour of duty shewed great initiative and drive, working without any outside assistance under conditions of considerable danger and difficulty.   As a result he produced a report which resulted in greatly improved morale in the KUANTAN area.   During the whole period of the emergency this N.C.O. has shewn great initiative and keenness and has consistently proved to be outstanding both as a policeman and a N.C.O.   I recommend that his name is submitted for the B.E.M.
Maj G.S.B. Palmer M.C. APM Malaya District.   Maj Gen C.H. Boucher GOC Malaya District.   National Archive WO 373/128.

Northern Ireland.   Citation for BEM:   Sgt BROWN has served in the Regular Army for over 16 years.   He enlisted in the Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, afterwards transferring to the Corps of Military Police.   He has served as a Sergeant in 173 HQ Pro Coy, RMP since Oct 1944.   During most of this period he has been the Senior Sergeant in the Company;  he has therefore on numerable occasions and for considerable periods, had to undertake the duties of RSM and CQMS.   Both these duties he has carried out very satisfactory at all times.   Sgt BROWN is an NCO with a pleasant personality and his imperturbable good humor and willingness to turn his hand to anything has had a great influence in maintaining the efficiency of the Unit.
Maj A E Winghold APM & OC 173 HQ Pro Coy.
E V Lang Col AQ I have known Sgt Brown for a long time. He has many times undertaken duties of ranks superior to his own and carried the out really well.   He has been largely responsible for provost arrangements on a number of public occasions and has to my personal knowledge given exceptionally loyal and devoted service.
Lt-Gen RFS Denning GOC NID.
National Archive WO 373/158.

United Kingdom.   DPM/SIB Sherwood Foresters.   DPM SIB London.   Citation for OBE:  Lt Col F Elliott has been the senior officer of the Special Investigation Branch of the RMP for the last 2 years during which time the many difficulties caused by changes from war to peace conditions have been very apparent both in administration of his own branch and the investigation of crime in the army.   Throughout this period, Col Elliott has manintained the highest morale in his branch, and by his personal example has done a great deal to counter crime, also his branch have saved the WD large sums of money, and material.   He is 39 years of age and has spent 9 years with the Civil Police, which included 7 years CID experience in the Metropolitan Police and at Scotland Yard and 10 years with the RMP.   The nature of his duites brings him into contact with many Senior Police Officers and also Senior Army Officers and his tact has played a big part in the good relationships that exists with the Civil Police.   He never spares himself, and by his devotion to duty he has kept up and in fact enhanced the good record of the SIB.
Brig L F E Wieler Provost Marshall.   Maj Gen DPS War Office.   National  Archive WO 373/158.
Now Maj.   Now RMP.
RMP.

United Kingdom.   Northern Command SIB.   Citation for BEM:  Sergeant Rogers has been employed in SIB, Northern Command since April 1948.   During this time his untiring efforts in the detection of serious cases of crime have been most marked.   His ability is of the highest order and his techincal and practical approach on the investigation of offences is outstanding.   As a Detachment Commander he has continually performed the duties normally assigned on a WOII.   As a result of his exeptional qualities which were devoted to many prolonged enquires a large number of offenders have been brought to trial.   This NCO's excellent work has undoubtedly enhanced the high reputation of the SIB in both military and civilian circles.
Lieut-Col WA Burford DSO DPM Northern Command.   Lieut-Gen CMFWhite GOC Catterick District: Sgt Rogers is well know to me and has carried out invaluable services to the Army withing my District.   He is outstandfing in his ability and devotion to duty and has great moral and physical courage which has proved of immeasuarable value to the Service.
Nationa Archive WO 373/158.

Malaya  21(Guard) Unit RMP Singapore.  April 49 - Nov 50.   Citation for MBE:  This Warrant Officer has been greatly responsible for the standard and smartness of this unit and to its state of discipline due to the nature of the unit he has had very little assistance and has proved himself to be a first class  drill instructor and disciplinarian.   Despite his youth he has handled NCO's of considerably greater experience, firmly and fairly and as a result has earned their respect and co-operation.   He has a very hight sense of duty and has time and again shewn himslelf outstanding as a Warrant Officer.   He takes a keen interest in the welfare of the M.O.R. NCO's and has always gone out of his way to guide and help them.   By his bearing and personal conduct he has proved an outstanding example to all NCO's  and men of this unit.
Lieut-Col G S P Palmer MC CO 21 (Guard) Unit RMP.   Maj-Gen GOC Singapore Base District.   C in C Far East Land Forces, Singapore.  National Archive WO373/129.

North Africa, Egypt.
Medal shown as Territorial Decoration in Corps Journal 4/4/1951.

Nairobi.   Feb 49 to Apr 51. Citation for BEM:   Sgt ALLAN arrived in Nairobi at a time when losses in stores due to thieving were costing the public many thousands of pounds annually.   He immediately set to work to combat this menace and as a result of his tenacity and devotion to duty many arrests have been made and the activities of the thieves noticeably reduced.   The nature of his duties entail periods of considerable strain, often the loss of sleep and at times of personal danger but he has not spared himself  nor has his efficiency been impaired or his enthusiasm flagged.   Not only has he shown himself to be an outstanding investigator but his foresight and acumen have on many occassions been instrumental in anticipating and preventing crime.   He has maintained the closest collaboration with the Civil Police CID to the mutual benefit of both Services and has been commended by the civil authorities for his valuable contributuion in bringing to a successful conclusion a number of extremelty difficult investigations.   To all those with who his work brings him in contact Sgt ALLAN is an inspiration and an example.
Major G C Wadsworth APM SIB.. Remarks of Brigade Commander  I can testify to the excellent work that Sgt ALLAN has done during the 18 months that I have known him and strongly recommend this application.   His initiative and devotion to duty are outstanding.   Lieut -Gen A A B Dowler GOC East Africa Command.   National Archive WO 373/159.

United Kingdom.   Provost Marshal's Branch, AG (PM) War Office.   Citation for BEM:  S/Sgt Clapham is a regular soldier of eleven years' exemplary service.   He has served as Chief Clerk to the Provost Marshal, and for AG (PM) Branch of the War Office, for the last three years.   During this period the Branch has had to be completely re-organised in order to accept responsibility for MPSC as well as RMP and work has steadily increased owing to planning for mobilisation, and the increase in size of RMP, Active, TA and SR.   The provision of junior clerical staff from RMP has always been extremelty difficult and resulted in many changes.   Throughout the period he has shown great ability in controlling this changing staff and in training them to give good willing work.   Had it not been for S/Sgt CLAPHAM'S energy, organising ability and devotion to his task which often meant long hours of voluntary extra duty, the work of the office would have been seriously impaired;
Col P Godfrey Fausett Col A & G (DPM) to DDPS (PM).   National Archive WO 373/159

Egypt.   Citation for BEM:  No 6977676 Sjt KERNAGHAN has been in Egypt in 203 Pro Coy RMP since December 1949.   The whole of the year 1950 was a very difficult one for the Company, owing to frequent changes of officers and senior NCOs.   During the whole of this period Sjt KERNAGHAN's behavious was exemplary and he continued to maintain the highest standard of discipline whether at Company Headquarters or when commanding a section on detachment.   During the early months of 1951 the Company was left for two months without a CQMS,   Although he was not the senior Sarjeant in the Company Serjeant KERNAGHAN was chosen to fill the post.   In spite of having had no previous experience of the job and although the very scattered nature of the Company added to its complicaitons Sarjeant KERNAGHAN carried out the job with every satisfaction until a CQMS could be sent out  from home.   His devotion to duty and example have been outstanding.
Maj R H A Knox OC 203 Pro Coy.   National Archive WO 373/159.   Name spelt Kermaghan on National Archive sheet.

Nigeria.   Corps of West African Military Police.   Citation for BEM:  WOII POORE has been in sole charge of the CWAMP Detachment at KADUNA  for two years.   During this period he has been carrying out the duties of an officer, since the Detachment Commander is shown on Establishment as an officer, but owing to shortage of officers none has been posted.   The standard of turn-out, discipline and efficiency of the Detachment have consistenly been of the highest order, owing to WOII POORE's keeness, energy and unremitting devotion to duty.   It is strongly recommended that the outstanding manner in which he has carried out the duties of an officer over a long period be recognized by the award of the BEM.
Lieut-Col L W G Hamilton OBE Commander North Eastern Sub-District, Kaduna, Northern Nigeria.   Brig Comd Nigeria District Lagos, Nigeria: I know this Warrant Officer personally, and consider he has done outstanding work at Kaduna.   I strongly recommend the award of the BEM.   National Archive WO 373/159.

Korea.   Citation for US Bronze Star:   Major ALBERT W. EVANS, 355863, Corps of Royal Military Police, as Provost Marshal, 29th British Independent Brigade, First United States Corps, performed outstanding meritorious service during the period 2 November 1950 to 1 June 1951 in support of military operations against the armed enemy in Korea.   Through his knowledge of traffic control and general police matters, Major EVANS, on numerous occasions, assisted materially in the successful movement of I Corps traffic over an inadequate roadnet undere adverse conditions.   His personal efforts in controlling conflicting traffic during the withdrawl across the Han River in January 1951, were instrumental in maintaining a constant flow of traffic through the City of Soul.   His speldid cooperation with other United Nations military police, working jointly during Corps movements, has resulted in a most desirous degree of teamwork.   Maj EVANS' attention to duty and tireless efforts were of material assistance to the success of the operation, and reflected great credit on himself, his organisation, and the United Nations Forces.
HQ 1 (US) Corps 8 August 1951.   National Archive WO 373/119.
Camerons.   (now CRMP (SR).

Egypt.   Temp Lt Col Irish Guards, DPM BTE Egypt.  For action in riots in Ismailia 17 - 18 November 1951.   Citation for OBE: This officer was the APM and it was therefore his duty to keep in touch with the Civil Police.   On 17/18 November a very difficult sitiation built up in Ismalia.   He heard of the trouble and a request to escort a doctor to a casualty.   He immediately decided to escort the doctor personally and see what the trouble was for himself.  He found the town in confusion with the Egyptian Police completely out of hand and firing in all directions.   He made contact with the RAF Police and certain Egyptian Civil Authorities and between them organized a party with a lound speaker which brought firing under control.   On the following day (18th November 1952) he was prominent in bringing the situation under control in a firm and common-sense manner.   In a situation of great tension he was able to inspire Egyptian Police Officers to a sense of duty at a time when they were reluctant to do anything.   He set a splendid example to all officers and men of the Corps of Royal Military Police.
RMP Journal 3rd Quarter 1952.
Italy.
For Gallant and Distinguished Conduct.

United Kingdom.   Chester.   Citation for BEM:  CSM Angel has been with the 165 (HQ) Pro Coy for 4 years, during which time he has carried out his duties in an exemplary manner, and his  loyalty and devotion to duty have been an example to all ranks both in this unit and outside it.   He is highly efficient, takes the keenest interest in all the activities of this unit and is always well informed on all matters.   He lives in Quarters at Company HQ and, at his own request, is called upon to answer any problem which may arise outside normal working hours.   In a Military Police Unit, this is no small undertaking, but CSM Angel allows no personal for family considerations to interfere with his efforts to maintain the efficiency and good name of his unit.   He maintains a high standard of discipline and will not tolerate any form of carelessness or laziness in work or behaviour.   His loyalty to the Service and to his Officers is exemplary.   Before joining this unit, CSM Angel held the local rank of RSM in order to instruct the RSM's of successive "Z" Reservist Provost Companies in their duties.   He carried out his additional duty with tact and efficiency and all the Officers Commanding commended him for the excellent instruction and assistance he gave.   CSM Angel is an expert on the practical side of all police duties, and had distinguished himself on numerous investigations.   In 1950 he was commended by the Provost Marshal for his work in arresting a soldier who was masquerading in Naval uniform.
Maj E V Crombie A & SH DAPM 165 (HQ) Pro Coy.   Brigadier ? Manchester:   I see this WO quite often and strongly support his CO's recommendations.   National Archive WO 373/160.

United Kingdom.   RQMS London District Pro Coy.   Citation for BEM:  RQMS Moffat is a Warrant Officer of over ten years standing and is a most experienced, loyal and hardworking man.   He has served the Corps of Royal Military Police faithfully with an unbroken service of over 16 years and has done much to enhance the reputation of both the Corps and the Army by steady and unstinting loyalty to duty during his service.   He was a prisoner of war in Japanese hands in the Malai Camp, Singapore for over 3 1/2 years but the privations that he endured during that period have not detracted from his unswerving attention to his duties in the Military Police.   As RQMS of this unit which is instrumental in dealing with the discipline of all troops in and around London, he is responsible for the accurate accounting, clothing and accommodation of 171 Other Ranks, the supervision of maintainance in two large barrack blocks and married quarters.   Expert in all unit 'Q' matters he carries out the duties which are normally performed by a Regimental Quartermaster and he does them excellently, never sparing himself.  He expects and receives the best from his subordinates, and handles them well.   They, in their turn respect him for his efficiency, bearing and conduct.   A good reliable leader in all branches of Provost duties, he has contributed in no small manner to the reputation enjoyed by the Corps of Royal Military Police for resourcefulness, good military discipline, smartness of turnout, and helpfulness.
Maj R C H Pilcher Welch Guards OC  London District Pro Coy.   Maj-Gen W P Oliver GOC in C Eastern Command Hounslow.
National Archive WO 373/160
For gallant and distinguished service.

Hong Kong.   Citation for BEM:  Sergeant Burke arrived in the Colony of HONG KONG in 1949 as a L/CPL, through extreme hard work and conscientious application at all times to duty he rose to the rank of  A/SGT as a merit promotion NCO, by November 1950, since this date he has been chosen to fulfill all the difficult tasks allotted to a Provost Company, for a period of five months he acted as Regimental Sargeant Major without pay or rank and performed these duties diligently and well, maintaining a high standard of discipline, administration and training.   He has been responsible for training the RMP Escort for visiting VIP's, Commanding Generals and His Excellency The Governor, for which commendations have been received.   He sets an extremelty good example by his personal turnout, military bearing and diligent, conscientious and reliable attitude to duty, his willingness at all times to tackel and bring to a successful conclusion a difficult task makes him an NCO worthy of merit.
Maj Albert Paul OC 40 Div Pro Coy.   Brigadier Comd Hong Kong & Kowloon Garrison.   Maj-Gen R C Cruddas Land Forces Hong Kong.
National Archive WO 373/160.

For duties in Japan in connection with Korean war.  Citation for BEM:   Sergeant GOYMER has served in the Korean Theatre as Chief Clerk and Investigator, Headquarters Special Investigation Section since June, 1951.   He has been largely responsible for organising Special Investigation Branch Administration throughout the Theatre.   His application to this task has proved to be outstandingly effective.   It is largely due to his efforts that co-ordination with the American system of Police Investigation has been accomplished with satisfactory final results in many important investigations.   He has also made himself responsible for the establishing of the Special Investigation Photographic Laboratory in Pusan,   Which again has considerably increased the efficiency of Section Investigations.   In the absence of the Deputy Assistant Provost Marshal, Special Investigation Section for quite long periods of time, Sergeant GOYMER has been in charge of the co-ordination of Theatre Side Administration and has frequenly handled important information with outstanding efficiency.   His leadership and personality has proved to be and example and inspiration to his Section.   He has applied himself to his work with a zeal far beyond expectation, to the stage when his health was likely to be affected.
Lt-Col A G Locksley APM HQ BCFK.   Brig R H Batten Kure (Japan)
National Archive WO 373/120.

Gibraltar.   July 49 - Feb 53.  Citation for MBE:  (Warrant Officer Class II F T WELLER is recommended for the award of the MBE).   For the past three and a half years he has performed the duties of CSM of the Royal Military Police Gibraltar.  He is outstanding in the manner in which he preserves discipline and in the example which he sets to others.   He is at all times loyal and tactful and is always ready to give assistance based on the experience of his many years service in the Corps of Royal Military Police.   He never spares himself and his zeal and devotion to duty are of an exceptionally high order.
Maj G L Dolman DAPM Gibraltar.   Brig OC The ??? Gibraltar,   Governor and C in C Gibraltar.

Coronation Honour.  Citation for BEM:  Sergeant DIMOND has held the acting rank of WO I in the Royal Military Police for over seven years.   For the last three years he has been the Regimental Sergeant Major of 247 Pro Coy RMP in BERLIN.   In this capacity he has shown outstanding zeal, tact and loyalty to a degree not formally expected, or found, in a soldier of his rank.   He has on many occasions been called upon to handle delicate situations involving RUSSIAN military personnel or EAST GERMAN Peoples Police, where great firmness, tempered with tact, was an essential if a serious incident was to be avoided.   Although on many occasions the presence of a BRITISH officer would have been desirable, this was not always possible due to the location and unexpectedness of the event;  nevertheless RSM DIMOND's careful handling of the situation has undoubtedly, and without any loss of prestige, prevented a serious international incident.   Through example and skillful leadership he has raised the standard of efficiency of his company to a level which has elicited praise and admiration from senior officers serving with his Corps and from members of other units of a similar type elsewhere.   The standard of discipline which he has maintained within the unit by example and within the garrison by his industry and zeal has, also, been on many occasions the subject of praise from his superiors in all arms of the service.   When called upon to work long hours he has always responded without complaint, and has, voluntarily and because of his natural enthusiasm for his work, devoted most of what might fairly have been regarded as leasure time to the particular task in hand.   By his fine example, industry, tact and loyalty he has, in BERLIN, considerably enriched the reputation of his Corps and increased the respect of members of other nations and armies for his own.
Maj P D Witty OC 247 Pro Coy.   Brigadier Berlin.   Maj Gen GOC  British Sector Berlin.   Col A H Gillmore PM HQ Northern Army Group.
National Archive WO 373/161.

Coronation Honour.  203 Pro Coy NCO I/c Moascar Garrison Sections CMP Egypt.  Apr 52 - Jan 53.  Citation for BEM: 203 Pro Coy sections have been almost entirely responisble for the policing of Ismilia and Moascar Garrison.   Sgt Dodd has, by his untiring efforts, in supervising the duties of these NCO's during the troublesome period when Ismailia was 'Out of Bounds', and then later when it was placed 'In Bounds' ensured that efficient control of the area has been maintained and that any "incidents" have been avoided.   He has been on duty continually for practically the whole of this period, both by day and night, and although handicapped by shortage of NCO's somehow arranged to produce sufficient to meet any demand.   His devotion to duty is of the highest, and he is a most loyal consciencious and hardworking NCO.
Maj D Cresswell DAPM Moascar Garrison.   Brigadier Moascar Garrison.  Maj Gen Sir F W Festing KCB CB DSO GOC BTE.
Nationa Archive WO 373/161.

Citation for BEM:  Staff Sergeant Gillmore, who has recently been released after 8 years service as a Regular soldier, was personal assistant to successive Provost Marshals,   He set a fine example of efficiency, hard work and cheerful enthusiasm, and went out of his way to help all and sundry.   He was a thoroughly good influence and his work as a personal assistant was outstanding..

Korea.   Citation for OBE:  Lt Col LOCKSLEY has been Assistant Provost Marshal Headquarters British Commonwealth Forces KOREA since 8 February 1952.   At the time that he assumed his appointment the integration of the Commonwealth Military Police resources was commencing with consequent problems of command, control, operation and administration.   The implementation of the Japanese Peace Treaty created an entirely new set of policing problems in Japan.   By firm leadership and ability Lt Col LOCKSLEY succeeded in dealing with the many and varied difficulties arising from the changed circumstances.   The Provost organisation throughout the theatre is now first class and a model of efficiency.   Relations with the Japanese police are excellent and combined policing has reached a high standard of co-operation.   Lt Col LOCKSLEY's personal determination, tact, and honesty have had a decisive effect upon relations with the Japanese police and magisterial authorities.   He is personally respected and liked and this has undoubtedly resulted in lack of friction in dealing with the difficult problems of Japanese jurisdiction over Commonwealth personnel.  Lt Col LOCKSLEY's experience and advice have been of the greatest value to the staff during a period of considerable difficulty and his services have been of a very high order.   He has performed his duties with zest and diligence and has successfully borne responsibility well in excess of that normally placed upon and Assistand Provost Marshal.
Brig J C D'A Dalton Chief of Staff HQ BCFK British Commenwalth Forces Kure Japan).
National Archive WO 373/120

Malaya   1/1/1953 - 30/6/1953.   OC Singapore Guard Regt then part of RMP.   Wiltshire Regt.   Jul 52 - Jun 53.   Citation for OBE:  Lt-Col C F READ took over command of the SINGAPORE GD REGT (RMP), a Malayan Unit, in Jul 52.   In less than a year Lt-Col READ, by his outstanding example, devotion to duty, and an exceptional display of personal leadership, has transformed the unit into the most efficient and contended in the District.   This fine achievement was accomplished in the face of most adverse circumstances in British personnel, material, unit accommodation and a heavy guard commitment.   Quite apart from producing an efficient and happy unit in such a short time, his personal attention to all and every detail of management of Malays, his care for their individual welfare, and the cheerful and determined way in which he personally first mastered the Malay language then associated himself with Malay customs, and thus brought out the best qualities in the race of which his unit is composed, has set a standard almost without parallel in this District.   An example which has been an inspiration to other Commanders and staff who are faced with the general problems of Malayanization of the Army in the Colony.   For this outstanding achievement, example and devotion to duty, I consider that Lt-Col READ is worthy of the highest award.
Brig E J Montgomery CB, CBE Brig IC Adm Singapore Base District.   Maj Gen GOC Singapore Base District.   C in C Far East Land Forces.
National Archive WO 373/132.

Malaya.   1/1/1953 - 30/6/1953.  Singapore.   Citation for MBE:  He has been under my command for four years, two in Berlin and two in Singapore, and during this period has dealt successfully with hundreds of serious crimes from murder to larceny.   There are no other SIB officers in Singapore and during my absence on tour he has virtually run the Singapore unit, and he is largely responsible for its present state of effiiciency.   He is consistent, and over the period has served SIB beyond the normal calls of duty.   I strongly recommend that his devotion to duty be rewarded by an award.
Maj R R Hutchinson MBE black Watch OC 91 Sect SIB.   GOC Singapore Base District.   C in C Far East Land Forces.

Malaya.  Singapore.   Citation for MBE:  1/1/53 - 30/6/53.  Capt VERLIN has been 2 IC of 200 Provost Coy (RMP) since November 1951.   During this period three Commanding Officers have succeeded one another with an interregnum of up to a month between them.   On Capt VERLIN therefore has rested to a great extent the onus of keeping up the standard of the Unit, which has been and is extremely high.
In the circumstances, it is fair to say that had it not been for his example, enthusiasm, determination and cheerfulness the Unit - nearly always understrength - and the ideals of the Corps he is serving could not have been maintained.
During the past eighteen months, in addition to routine duties, on Capt VERLIN has fallen a greater part of the Provost duties for the military Ceremonials in the Colony in connection with the Queen's Birthday Parade 1952, the visit of Her Royal Highness The Duchess of KENT IN 1952, and the Coronation and Queen's Birthday Parade in 1953.   The Company has tackled all these problems with notable success, a success to which Capt VERLIN's personal example has undoubtedly contributed.

Korea, 1/1/1953- 30/6/1953.   Sergeant WILLIAMS has been an SIB investigator in KOREA since November 1951.   Although young, he has maintained the confidence placed in him, and his investigations usually meet with considerable success thereby maintaining the good name of his organisation.   He has been untiring in his efforts to achieve success and he never considers time or personal comfort when investigating a case.   His devotion to his duty, the success he has achieved in his investigations have been outstanding and his personal example has been an inspiration to his Section.
L/Col H C L Dimsdale OBE  MC WG Commander Britcom FMA.   Brigadier Commander British Commonwealth Korean Base.   H Wells C in C Brit Commonwealth Forces Korea.   National Archive WO 373/117/

Didsbury Manchester, 9 Aug 1949 -7 July 1953.  Section Corporal.
Corporal GARRATT is a man of exemplary character and conduct.   His devotion to his duty is quite remarkable.   Since he joined my unit on 9th Aug 1949, he has never missed a Drill night or week-end exercise unless prevented by his employment, which is very seldom.   Corporal GARRATT joined the T.A. in 1938, and served in M.E.F and B.N.A.F.   In addition to his normal drill nights, he puts in very many hours work at the Drill Hall voluntarily and without being asked.   Hi is a tower of strength to the PSI's since he will tackle and job, however heavy or arduous.   The M.T. is always in an excellent condition, primarily due to the hours of hard work put in by Corporal GARRATT on maintenance.   He carries out all these tasks, because he so obviously considers it his duty,   He seeks no reward or limelight, but always remains quietly in the background.   As a Military Policeman hi is like a rock,   His size - he is 6' 3" and weight s nearly 18 stone = helps undoubtedly, but with all his strength he is gentle, and one of the most tactful policemen in the Company.   He is a man on whom one can depend, even in the utmost adversity.
Maj R K Mills OC 42 Div Pro Coy,   Commander 42 Inf Div.   Lt Gen C F Loewen C in C Western Command.    National Archive WO 373/161.

Egypt.   May 1951 - July 53.   NCO i/c WRAC Provost.
Sergeant MANSELL has served in the ATS and WRAC since 1941, and has been in Egypt for the past two and a quarter years, as NCO i/c WRAC Provost.   She has performed exceptional service by her outstanding efficiency, and example, not only to those she commands, but to the Corps of Royal Military Police in Egypt as a whole.   On several occasions she has taken over the duties of Company Commander in my absence.   This has necessitated contact with Senior Officers, and the success with which her efforts have been crowned is due to her tact, common sense and understanding.   During the difficult period, after the Abrogation of the Treaty, Sergeant MANSELL was mainly responsible for setting up and working an Information Room at H/Q. B.T.E. manned by WRAC provost.   it was a great success owing to the efficiency in which information was collected, collated and distributed.   Sergeant MANSELL was largely responsible for this due to her keenness, organising ability and drive.   Sergeant MANSELL is quite outstanding and is mainly responsible for the high morale of the WRAC Provost in the Canal Zone, her qualities and her exceptional service should be recognised by the award of the B.E.M.
Lt Col APM HQ BTE.   GOC HQ MELF.   C in C MELF.   National Archive WO 373/161.

Austria, Vienna.   12/8/1950 - 29/6/1953.   Warrant Officer supervising Vienna Detachment RMP.
Regimental Sergeant Major SMITH served in VIENNA for three years, during which time, by his energy, tact and exceptional gifts of leadership and the capacity for setting an example at all times, he has made a very great contribution towards the maintenance of a very high standard of discipline, efficiency and smartness in the Military Police.   Since RSM SMITH has had to deal, not only with the American and French Forces, but also those of the Soviet in the International military Police Patrol in Vienna, he has performed services far outside the normal scope of his duties in the Military Police and he has achieved an outstanding success in all that he has done.
Maj G D Pillitz DAPM Vienna Garrison.   Brigadier Vienna, BTA.   Maj Gen GOC in C Austria.   
National Archive WO 373/161.
Italy.  6/8/45 Maj A Marriott to be mentioned in recognition of gallant and distinguished service in Italy.   Unit War Diary WO 170/7032.

Advance Base (British Forces) Belgium.   Sept 1952 to Jan 1954.  Provost Sergeant 6 Section 103 Pro Coy.   Citation for BEM:   Sergeant MATTHEWS has commanded No 6 Section 103 Provost Company since its arrival in the Advanced Base, Belgium in September 1952.   Being detached from his Company he has had to rely largely on his own initiative; this he has done with outstanding success.   his co0operation with the Belgian Gendamerie and Police has been excellent from the first:  this has played a considerable part in preventing untoward "incidents" thus furthering our good relations with the local population.   He has used his small resources over a wide area to the best advantage with a marked effect on this discipline of the troops.   In spite of the extent of the area he very quickly came to know it intimately and has acted as guide without hitch or mistake during a number of tours by important visitors notably Canadian and Allied Senior Officers, members of the Government and Parliament, including the Under Secretaries of State in the Ministries of Defence and War, the Press and British Senior Officers including the Quartermaster General and the Commander- in-Chief, Northern Army Group.   He has had to contend with considerable administrative difficulties owning to lack of accommodation which for many months had to be improvised;  these difficulties he has overcome cheerfully and efficiently and has, in spite of them, maintained a very high state of morale in his section.   His duties have been more onerous and more varied than would normally be expected of an NCO in his position;  he has carried them out in a highly meritorious manner.
Maj C W Brooke OC 103 Pro Coy.   Col. Emblem, Belgium.   Maj Gen Commander Rhine Area.   C in C HQ Northern Army Group.   National Archive WO 373/162.

B.T.A. (British Troops Austria).   Beginning of 1950 to Jan 54.   Specially employed.
Sergeant Pargeter's duties have entailed long hours of hard and dangerous manual labour, and called for a high degree of efficiency.   On one occasion his life was endangered and by force of circumstances he was left to find his own way out of the situation.   He has at all times displayed great initiative, and throughout the whole period and in the face of many adverse conditions has shown an inspiring cheerfulness and devotion to duty.
Col B E L Burton DDMI6 os War Office.   Strongly recommended his services have been invaluable Maj Fen DMI War Office.   National Archive WO 373/162.

Sek Kong, Hong Kong.   5 Aug 53.   Duty NCO RMP.
On 4th August 1953 at SE KONG, HONG KONG two soldiers absented themselves from their barracks, taking with them a sten gun and ammunition which they has stolen from the arms store.   They engaged a taxi and rode in it into the country.   On a lonely stretch of the road they held up the taxi driver at the point of the loaded gun, struck him, bound and gagged him, stole his watch and money, and threw him out of the vehicle.   They then took the taxi and drove away in it.   Lance Corporal CUTHBERT was aware that these two soldiers were absent without leave, were armed and that they had already used the gun to obtain possession of the taxi.   On the evening of 5th August 1953 Lance Corporal CUTHBERT was on motor cycle patrol accompanied by another Military Police NCO, Corporal ESSON.   The two NCOs were searching the countryside for the missing men and the taxi.   At 2120 hrs a car answering the description of the stolen taxi passed them going in the other direction.   Both immediately turned their motor cycles around and gave chase.   Corporal ESSON managed to stop the can and when Lance Corporal CUTHBERT joined him they both quickly drew their revolvers and Corporal ESSON grabbed the sten gun which was found to be loaded.   The two NCOs then ordered the men to get out of the taxi and afterwards marched them some 500 yards to the nearest Military building.   L/Cpl CUTHBERT , a keen young National Service NCO showed outstanding initiative and presence of mind in dealing with an armed man.   L/Cpl CUTHBERT displayed great courage and disregard for his own safety in effecting these arrests.   It is considered that his conduct in this incident was of the highest order.
Maj G C D S Lowe TD, DAPM HQ Land Forces Hong Kong.   Col J A Hopwood IC Admin Land Forces Hong Kong.Maj-Gen GOC land Forces Hong Kong.   C in C Far East Land Forces.   National Archive WO 373/122.
Also shown in Corps Journal 3rd Quarter 1954.

40 Div Pro Coy Sek Kong. Hong Kong.  5 Aug 53.  
On 4th August 1953 at Sek Kong, Hong Kong, two soldiers absented themselves from their barracks, taking with them a sten gun and ammunition which they has stolen from the arms tore.   They engaged a taxi and rode in it into the country.   On a lonely stretch of the road they held up the taxi driver at the point of the loaded gun, struck him, bound and gagged him, stole his watch and money, and threw him out of the vehicle.   They the took the taxi and drove away in it.   Corporal ESSON and lance Corporal Cuthbert aware that these two soldiers were absent without leave, were armed and that they had already used the gun to obtain possession of the taxi.   On the evening of 5th August 1953 Corporal ESSON on motor cycle patrol accompanied by Lance Corporal CUTHBERT, the two NCOs were searching the countryside for the missing men and the taxi.   At 2120hours a car answering the description of the stolen taxi passed them going in the other direction.   Both immediately turned their motor cycles round and gave chase.   Corporal ESSON forced the driver to pull into the side of the road.   He noticed that one of the occupants, who was sitting in the back of the car, was holding a sten gun.   He therefore engaged the drive in conversation until Lance Corporal CUTHBERT had joined him, when they quickly drew their revolvers and Corporal ESSON grabbed the sten gun which he found to be loaded.   The two NCOs then ordered the men to get out of the taxi and afterwards marched them some 500 yards to the nearest Military building.   Corporal ESSON showed outstanding initiative and presence of mind in dealing with an armed man.   In addition he displayed great bravery and disregard for his own personal safety in effecting these arrests.   it is considered that his conduct in this incident was of the highest order.   Corporal ESSON is a young regular NCO who has in the recent past, been of great assistance to the Civil Police in this Colony in connection with cases which have occurred in which soldiers have been involved.   He has worked very long hours on a number of occasions and has shown outstanding devotion to duty.   Lance Corporal CUTHBERT, a keen young National Service NCO showed outstanding initiative and presence of mind in dealing with an armed man.   Lance Corporal CUTHBERT displayed great courage and disregard for his own safety in in effecting these arrests.   It is considered that his conduct in this incident was of the highest order.
Maj GC DS Lowe TD DAPM HQ Far East Land Force, Hong Kong.   Maj General GOC Land Forces  Hong Kong.   C in C FARELF.   National Archive WO 373/122.  
Aslo shown in Corps Journal 3rd Quarter 1954.
Middle East.

Malaya 1/1/1954 - 30/6/1954 Singapore.   Investigator.
This NCO has served in the SIB/RMP for a period of 61/2 years, during which time he has successfully dealt with many major investigations which have resulted in the recovery of many thousands of pounds worth of WD stores and property, destined for operatonal units in the Federation as well as those destined for KOREA.   As an example of this, in January 1954 S/Sgt KNIGHT investigated a case in JOHORE involving the larceny of a WD vehicle.   This case ended with the arrest of a complete gang of receivers of stolen WD property as well as the recovery of the vehicle concerned.   Although called out at all hours of the day and night, weekday or Sunday, this NCO has always shown devotion to duty and keenness of a very hight order.   The area for which his section is responsible covers not only SINGAPORE, but also the whole of the state of JOHORE.   On numerous occasions S/Sgt KNIGHT has had to travel on highly dangerous roads with little or no escort, in the performance of his duties.   He sets the highest possible standards at all times, and in all respects his conduct and example are far beyond that called for in the course of normal duties.
Maj R B Sexton DAPM SIB FARELF.   Brigadier IC Admin Singapore District.   Maj-Gen GOC Singapore Base District.    C in C Far East Land Forces.   National Archive WO 373/132.

Kuala Lumpur.   Aug 53 - Dec 54.  Citation for MBE:  Captain MACKINNON has commanded the Special Investigations Branch, Royal Military Police detachment, Malaya since August 1953, which has been responsible for Special Investigation work for most of MALAYA Command.   It has been recognised that with only one officer, this detachment is decidedly understaffed and efforts are being made to increase it.   In addition to the normal day to day responsibilities in comparatively minor crime, Captain MACKINNON has carried out a most complicated series of investigations into fraudulent dealings in connection with Army Contractors, involving regular travels over long distances, and including two trips to the United Kingdom.   These investigations involved five major units and a very considerable amount of paper and account work, and brought to light, fraud in the region of 50,000.   His success in these cases has been due to his energy, complete devotion to duty, and his ability.   Although extremely hard worked, and almost invariably on duty over weekends, he has always been cheerful.   I consider without hesitation that he has done outstanding work, far and above the normal call of duty, and in fact beyond the physical capabilities of most officers.
Lt Col C H Howarth MBE TD AAG Malaya Command.   Brig K R Brazier-Creagh Chief of Staff. Malaya Command.   Lt-Gen G K Bourne GOC Malaya Command.   National Archive WO 373/133.
