Queens Birthday Honour.    24090616 Staff Sergeant (now acting Warrant Officer Class 2) John Salmons, RMP.  101 Pro Coy.   RMP.  1 Mar 84 - 6 Oct 84.   Exercise Lion Heart.
Citation:   Staff Sergeant Salmons is the non commissioned officer in charge of the (BR) Com Z detachment of 101 Provost Company RMP, the only in theatre regular RMP on the British Line of Communication.   As such he was responsible for the establishment of effective liaison with the Host Nations' (BE, NL) military and civil police, judiciary and law enforcement agencies, the provision of RMP operational support prior to the arrival of reinforcements and, finally the policing of (BR) Comm Z.
   His work during the exercise planning and preparation stages and throughout LIONHEART operations was outstanding, far above that normally  associated with his rank and service.
     Early in the planning stage, acting on his own initiative, he identified the many Host Nations' police agencies that would be involved in operations.   He mad contact with them and sought out their planning officers, invariably much senior to him, and identified himself as the in-theatre RMP point of contact.   He provided the Host Nations with the detailed information that they required and kept them informed of planning changes as they occurred.   he won their respect and confidence, no small achievement, and made inter-operability and close cooperation between the Host Nations' police and RMP possible.   This was crucial to successful operations in (BR) Comm. Z.
     In the preparation stage S/Sgt Salmons made many constructive suggestions on the organisation of the Convoy Marshalling Area (CMA) and produced the equipment required to operate it.   His ideas were accepted and subsequently proved during actual operations which were greatly facilitated because of this SNCO's initiative.   He was instrumental in the smooth operation of the CMA, the first important link on the line of communication.
     Finally, during LIONHEART operations S/Sgt Salmon's detachment successfully police the (BR) Comm Z dealing promptly and effectively with all police incidents in close cooperation with the Host Nations.   This was due to his leadership and preparatory work.   He also acted at the (BR) Comm Z RMP Operations Warrant Officer, and appointment normally held by a WO I (RSM), assisting the DAPM with the command, control and coordination of a three company group and making a most significant contribution throughout.
     S/Sgt Salmon's actions prior to and during Exercise LIONHEART were in accordance with the highest traditions of RMP and the results that he produced consistently outstanding in every aspect of his many and varied duties.   In view of his rank and service I consider them worthy of official recognition.
Recommended by: OC. 101 Pro Coy.   Maj. Gen. COS HQ BAOR.  Gen. C in C BAOR.
Northern Ireland.  24716736  Corporal Charles Henry Armstrong. RMP.

New Year Honours.   438659 Major Robert John Wyatt, OC 163 Pro Coy RMP (V).  1 March 1973 to 15 June 1981.
Citation:   Brevet Lieutenant Colonel Wyatt assumed command of 163 Provost Company RMP (V), a sponsored company recruited entirely from the Automobile association, in 1973.   Under his inspired leadership the unit flourished, was always fully recruited and earned an outstanding reputation.   During his period of command after one major exercise the Commander of the LSG UKMF commented that the company's performance was the best he had ever seen of a military Police company.   In 1974, when they spent their annual camp in support of RMP in South East District, the GOC remarked that that they were a shining example to the regular army in every respect.   More recently the Commander 8th Field Force stated that the Company's performance during Exercise CRUSADER was simply outstanding.   For a sponsored unit to gain such praise is a truly remarkable achievement.   Their tremendous contribution to the operational efficiency of the Army and their splendid example is testimony to the dedication and leadership of Lieutenant colonel Wyatt.   he inspired a sense of purpose and professionalism into this company which is reflected in their soaring morale and outstanding efficiency.
     Some measure of his achievement in this respect may be judged from the unprecedented action of the Governing Committee who, at a luncheon in his honour, made a presentation to him on his relinquishment of command.
     Brevet Lieutenant Colonel Wyatt's performance as commanding officer of a company of part time soldiers has been a shining example of devotion, outstanding and unselfish service, superb efficiency and absolute professionalism.   Such conduct is far beyond the normal calll of duty and should be recognised by an award.
Recommended by: APM, South.   Lt/Gen. Aldershot.   Gen. C in C UKLF

Former PM.   Late Lincolnshire Regt, now RARO.   Citation for CBE:  Brigadier Oulton has now completed his tenure of 3 years in the appointment of Provost Marshal and Inspector of Prisons - an appointment he has filled not only with success but with distinction.   As Commander of the Corps of Royal Military Police he has proved himself and imaginative and far sighted administrator.   With patience, understanding and tireless determination he has demanded the standard of performance which is now universally acknowledged.   Perhaps his greatest achievements lie in the reforms which have been effected in Military Corrective Training Establishments.   His energy, integrity and vision have transformed the M.C.T.E. Colchester into a high grade training establishment which has won acclaim from Commanders and unstinting approval in Parliament.   His untiring efforts have been bent to the successful rehabilitation of the soldier as a useful member of the Army, and he has not spared himself to achieve this fine purpose.   His fine personal character and his unflagging enthusiasm have been reflected in the spirit of the Military Provost Staff Corps whose duties lie within the Corrective Establishments.   Their morale, their sense of purpose and their efficiency have made tremendous strides towards the goal which Brigadier Oulton had always in sight and which will long survive his term of office.   His contribution to the well being of the Army is worthy of high recognition.
Maj-Gen R F Johnstone CBE Director of Personal Services War Office.   National Archive WO 373/166.

TA.   487722 Major Raymond John Harold Edward Prior. OC 253 Pro Coy, RMP (V).   1964 to date.
Citation:   Major PRIOR has been serving in uniform continually since 1948 until the present day, firstly as a cadet, then as a Regular Soldier for nine years and subsequently as a TA officer and OC of 253 Pro Coy RMP (V).   Throughout these years Major Prior has shown enormous enthusiasm for military life and great dedication to his work as a soldier.
     Since 2964 Major Prior has been serving in 253 Provost Company RMP and has proved to be one of the most popular members of the unit in every rank that he has held.   He was Commissioned in 1969 and has been officer Commanding for the past three years.
     In spite of moving to Eastbourne where he has a responsible and time consuming job in local government, Major Prior hardly ever fails to turn up for a drill night or a training weekend, and often attends the Southampton Detachment training in addition to his normal Company duties at the Headquarters in Brixton.
     Throughout his tour in command, Major Prior has paid meticulous attention to demanding the highest standards from his men;  that these standards have been achieved is in no doubt after his recent performance on Exercise Crusader 80 where his company earned the very highest praise from everyone from the C-in-C to the local farmers.
     His considerable dedication and loyalty to the Corps and to the Service far exceeds that which is required an it is considered that this outstanding contribution to the Service should be recognized with an appropriate award.
Recommended by Lt/Col, APM, East.   Maj/Gen. GOC, London District.   Gen. C in C, UKLF.

New Year Honours.   Lieutenant Colonel Roger John Theis, MBE. (453058). SO1 Police Legal, HQ PM (Army) 
RMP.  05/01/1987 to date.
Citation:   In 1986 RMP recognised the need to continuously improve the operational and cost effectiveness of the Provost Support it provides to the Army world wide and to manage resources to match commitments more efficiently.   The Corps had to change its management approach from a traditional reactive style to corporate planning, so that its activities could be measured, monitored and controlled against planned goals and objectives.   However because this change was innovative it was unclear how it could be effected.
Early in 1987 Lieutenant Colonel Theis joined HQ Provost Marshal (Army) and volunteered to help address the problem in addition to his heavy work load as SO1 Police Legal.   Without losing the momentum of his primary employment he read and consulted widely throughout the Ministry of Defence with Home Office police forces and analagous agencies facing similar difficulties and with centres of management expertise..   Starting from his firm formulation of legal knowledge and wide police experience he gathered a comprehensive understanding of the principle and process of modern management, identifying accurately those which apply to RMP.   He has appreciated the many complex issues involved, including the evolution of a Defence Management Strategy.   His assessment of their inter-relationship and the practical implications of conceptual options enable him to play a key role in designing the Provost Services Strategic Planning Approach (PROSPA).   PROSPA provided the basis for restructuring the RMP management organisation, the development of new control processes, the formulation of the RMP corporate plan and an information technology strategy to support RMP's drive to achieve greater operational and cost effectiveness.
Lieutenant Colonel Theis has acted throughout in the highest traditions of the military police on his own initiative, outside the specification of his own appointment and with a vision beyond his own specialisation has been instrumental in bringing about management development which already enhanced RMP's efficiency and effectiveness, which promises significant savings in the future and which may provide a prototype Defence organisations taking similar appreciation in line with the Govermnment's financial and management initiative (FMI) and service initiatives.
Recommended by PM (Army).  General AGC, MOD London,

Germany.   Hamburg.   Citation for BEM:  July 51- July 52.  CQMS FLAHERTY has rendered outstanding serice under difficult conditions.  He has been charged with the closing down of a large barracks and the taking over of part of another.   His accounting has been done with such meticulous care that no loss of stores has occurred in an account covering thousands of items of property.   In addition to his 'Q' duties he has had to perform the duties of RSM for 6 weeks.   This necessitated his working very long hours to cope with his combined responsibilities.   In spite of his heavy burden he has been constantly on the alert for more work to do and there is no limit to his enthusiasm for work.   The example set by this NCO has been an inspiration to all ranks throughout this period.   He has previously been commended by the Provost Marshal, War Office, for brave conduct when on the night of 11/12 Oct 1948 he, regardless of his own safety, apprehended and disarmed a Pte Ragan who had opened fire on his patrol, and by so doing restored a situation which might have had the gravest consequences.
Maj C E Walker OC 194 Pro Coy.   Brig Comd Hamburg District,   Maj Gen Commander Rhine District Dusseldorf,  Provost Marshal HQ BAOR.

New Year Honours.   Brigadier Norman Charles Allen,  OBE. ADC. (454098). APM & CRMP. HQ Berlin, RMP. 
Jul 77 - Nov 79.
Citation:  Lieutenant Colonel ALLEN has just completed and outstanding two and a half year tour as Assistant Provost Marshal and Commander Royal Military Police in Berlin, during which he has set and maintained the highest professional standards by his un-stinted efforts and personal example.   The excellent performance of his duties has been recognised not only by the British community, but by the British Military Government, which equates to a medium sized embassy, the Allies, the West Berlin Police and the local community.   The special position of the Allies in Berlin produces many unusual situations which require handling with the greatest tact and diplomacy.   He has accomplished this in an exemplary manner, with commendable patience and understanding and having to react frequently to incidents of an international nature day and night.   The tasking of his limited and often overstretched police resources in their daily routine of road access, wall and wire patrols as well as normal traffic and disciplinary duties have been intelligently and sympathetically managed to the benefit of all concerned.   He has also sought and achieved the fullest cooperation with the Royal Air Force, the Allies, The West Berlin Police and has been exceptionally successful in maintaining the best possible relationship with the Soviets on all maters of right an access.
     His chief responsibilities for security and traffic control in the British Sector of Berlin have included the annual Queen's Birthday Parade, the Allied Forces Day Parades and two bienniel Tattoo's, which are major ceremonial functions attended by Royalty, Heads of State and large numbers of local, diplomatic and allied dignitaries.   His foresight, planning and coordination for these large scale events has always been excellent, but he is particularly commended for his part on the occasion of Her Majesty The Queen's visit in May 1978 and President Carter's visit the same year.
     In addition to all this he has managed to play a full part in community life, which has only been possible because of his strong sense of duty and exceptional diligence for which he is commended for special recognition.
Recommended by: COS HQ Berlin.   GOC Berlin.  C in C BAOR,

QCBC In company of Lieut H J Patten.   Citation:  For their calm courage and devotion to duty in dealing with a deranged soldier threatening to fire on anyone attempting to restrain him. New Year honour.   5825132 Sergeant (acting) William Lewis Legg.  4  (Scottish) Port Task Force Pro Coy, Corps of Royal Military Police, TA.   17/1/1956 - 1/6/1959.
Citation:  Sergeant Legge has been the Permanent Staff Instructor with 4 (Scottish) Port Task Force Provost Company, RMP, (TA) since 17 January 1956.   He joined the Company on the completion of his Regular Army engagement of  22 years at a tme when the unit strength of purely volunteer NCO was at a very low ebb.   By dint of hard work, perseverance and enthusiasm, Sergeant Legge was very largely responsible for putting the unit back on its feet and for giving it as strong sense of its importance in, first of all, the Beach Brigade and then, in 1957 the Port Task Force.   The present volunteer strength of 79% of the unit establishment reflects great credit on his efforts.
     In the early days of the unit's re-organization and rebuilding, when trained NCOs were few, Sergeant Legge found himself called upon to do every job in the unit, and, at the same time, to teach the TA NCO's to do these jobs themselves.   Proof of the high standard that he achieved in this task is given in the grading of "Very Good" that the unit has been given on its Annual Administrative Inspections in the last three years, and in the efficiency with which it carries out its duties.   As an Instructor has been excellent: no hours have been too long and no task too arduous and the loyalty he has given has been of the highest order.   
      The Territorial Army as a whole and his present unit in particular owe much to him for what has been no less than his whole-hearted devotion to the interests of the unit, and his unflagging an very successful efforts on its behalf.
Recommended by: OC 4 (S) PTF Pro Coy. RMP TA. ,  Col. Comd 4 (S) PTF (TA).  GOC 21 (L) Inf Div. TA.

Normandy.   Citation for BEM:   On the 14th August, 1944, Corporal Blair was in charge of a traffic post at St. Aignan de Cremesnil.   In the afternoon this area was heavily bombed by our own Air Force.   Corporal Blair, instead of taking cover, immediatley organised his section to deal with this unexpected emergency.   Not only did he continue to supervise the direction of traffic, which naturally became disorganized, but he personally carried wounded men to cover from the exposed area.   By his coolness and complete disregard for the extreme danger, Corporal Blair not only saved the lives of many men, but by his example he encouraged drivers to keep a steady flow of traffic, thereby minimising the danger of the bombs.   Nationa Archive WO 373/69  Pt.1.

BEF.   Citation for MID: Security Officer 51 Division.   At the passage of the River SEINE at CAUDEBEC on 10 June 40, by his clear headedness and personal efforts, organised and maintained a fire-break between the burning mass of vehicles and buildings and the ferry approaches.   As soon as he succeeded in clearing a space it was filled again by French military transport acting independently and without control.   Lt. GRAY, nevertheless, continued again and again to clear the space and effectively prevented the fire from reaching petrol tank lorries and ammunition wagons.   Only when all British transport except the 14 R.A.S.C. lorries for which there were no drivers, had been evacuated did he leave the place.

GALIABAT. 28th January, 1941.   While moving through very thick and difficult country, the armoured carrier section under this Officer's command suddenly became engaged at close quarters with a superior enemy force in position.   2nd Lt Birch, being temporarily cut off from the remainder of his section, sent his gunner to bring them up, and took over his gun.   Regardless of his personal safety, he stood up in his carrier and engaged the enemy over the top of the long grass.   Single handed, he held off his opponents, causing them heavy casualties, until he was put out of action by a direct his from a grenade and two revolver bullets.   The remainder of the section then arrived and put the enemy to flight.   By his quick decision, skill and bravery, 2nd Lt Birch turned what might have been a reverse with loss of valuable material into a victorious action.
Lt Col Rodwell Comd 2 West Yorkshire Regt
A very gallant action which resulted in complete success.   2/Lieut BIRCH was very badly wounded and is unlikely to be able to serve again in a combatant capacity.  I strongly recommend the grant to him of the Military Cross.
Brigadier Comd 9 Indian Inf Bde 28 Feb 1941.
Lieut General W Platt Commanding Troops Sudan.

New Year Honour.   Capt (temporary Major) Alfred Percy Green, MBE (21806), Royal Artillery

Middle East.   Citation for DSO:   Throughout the operations between 23rd Oct and 4th Nov.   this Officer commanded his Squadron of Sherman Tanks with such skill and determination that for the loss of only one of his own tanks through enemy action he caused the destruction of the following enemy equipment as a minimum:  60 German Tanks (including 38 burnt out) 30 A/Tk guns (including a number of 88 & 76mm) and 12 lorries.   At day break on 24th Oct about 4000yards NE of El Wishka his Squadron was placed in the midst of enemy minefields with little room to manoeuvre, little cover from the ground, and faced with fire of several 88mm A/Tk guns.   Major Kaye watched each of the tanks in his Squadron and ordered them to move  individually as they were being ranged upon in turn.   At the same time he spotted each enemy gun or tank in action against him and by his excellent orders preserved his Squadron intact and gradually destroyed the enemy tanks and A/Tk guns.  Major Kaye repeated this type of action on many subsequent occasions and during all the close fighting in enemy minefields continually pressed his Squadron forward in support of our infantry.   One notable occasion of this was on the evening of 24th Oct. when he was able to get his Squadron through a recently cleared gap just in time to beat off an enemy tank counter-attack on 1 GORDONS about 4000 yards due North of El Wishka.   Major Kaye's determination, control of his Sqn and personal example of cool fearless efficiency were certainly a major factor in effecting a breakthrough of the enemy positions on the front of 1st Armd Division.
Maj A D R Wingield MC Commanding 19th Royal Hussars,   H R Alexander Gen C in C Middle East Forces.   Maj Gen R Briggs Comd 1 Armd Div.   Lieut Gen Comd 10 Corps,   B L Montgomery Gen Eigth Army.   National Archive WO 373/23

Middle East.   Citation for the award of the OBE, May-Oct 1942:  This officer as head of the Special Investigation Branch in the Middle East has built up the organisation from nothing since the S.I.B's inception approximately 1 1/2 years ago.   This Branch consists of some 50 officers, 450 other ranks and 250 native informers and trackers, who cover the whole of the Middle East.   During the first ten months of 1942 (1st. Jan - 31st . Oct) the Branch has recovered some 300,000 of W.D. Property.   During the month of October 1942 the Branch carried out over 2,500 Investigations including Thefts, Bribery, Assaults, Deaths, Suicides, Morality etc.    The efficiency of this Branch is due to this officer's untiring drive, initiative, devotion to duty, powers of organisation, and command of men.   His work richly merits reward.
Col F C Bryant PM MEF.   National Archive WO 373/76

British Troops Egypt.   Citation for MBE:  This officer has served as APM 16 Area since 15 Oct 41.   The period under review has been one of exceptional difficulty for Lt. Col Whitehead.   The withdrawal of the 8th Army to the El Alamein line resulted in a vast body of troops and transport coming in or passing through the area, at the same time as reinforcement troops were moving westwards through the area.   The situation produced on the one hand grave traffic problems and on the other hand introduced into the area a large body of troops from many diverse units fresh from battle and in some cases disorganised.   The problems of both traffic and discipline presented many difficulties.   Lt. Col. Whitehead applied his untiring energy and his very intimate knowledge of his profession to the solution of these problems, and the success with which he dealt with them was of high importance both to this area and to Eighth Army.   At the same time the routine performance of his normal duties has given me has given me at all times the highest satisfaction.   I consider that his services, particularly during this difficult period, fully justify recognition.
Comd 16 Area.   Lieut-Gen Brisih Troops Egypt.   National Archive WO 373/76.

North Africa.   Citation for MBE:  This officer who is in charge of the Special Investigations Branch in this theatre has since the initial landing given outstanding work throughout the period under review.   This work was by no means confined to the Army only.   He has carried out all investigations for the Navy and RAF.   Further more he has rendered considerable assistance to U.S. Army on a number of occasions.   He has gained the confidence of the French Police without which it would have been impossible to have achieved such good results.   There can be no doubt that his work and the way  in which he has used his men has made the detection of crime more certain, and as this became known has had a considerable deterrent effect in decreasing such crime.  I recommend that this officer receives recognition by an award as shown or such other award as may seem appropriate for his able administration and unstinting work since his arrival in this theatre, which has, I consider, brought benefit to the whole force.
Lieut Col M Sykes DPM.   Chief Admin Officer Allief Force HQ.   National  Archive WO 373/71 pt.1.

North Africa.   Citation for MBE:  During the Battle of Tunisia from April 22nd to 14 May 1943, the energy and efficiency with which Major Cairns carried out his duties as A.P.M. 5 Corps had a material effect on the success of our operations.   Much depended on the speed with which the great mass of transport, both fighting and adminisrative, could be got across the Merjarda and the very limited number of roads and tracks East of Medjez and the success with which this was achieved was largely due to Major Cairns.   It was also largely due to his tact and hard work that the difficult problem on controlling the large city of Tunis was effected so smoothly from the time of its capture.

North Africa.   Citation for MBE:   Major RALLI has been A.P.M. of 9 Corps and throughout the whole period of the recent opertions from early April to the end of the TUNIS battle he has performed outstanding service.   The organisation of all traffic control, route reconnaissance and the very difficult organisation of reception arrangments for many thousands of prisoners of war have all been carried out with outstanding efficiency and with unstinting energy.   For long periods on end Major RALLI has been unable to get rest or sleep and has maintained throughout a quiet efficiency which has been an outstanding example.
DA & QMG 9 Corps.   Lt Gen Comd 9 Corps.   General GOC in C First Army.   National Archive 373/71 Pt.1.
North Africa.   15/19 Hussars, Maj. (Qr-Mr) G R G Hart, MM (37097).

KOYLI.   PM Army 1948.   Citation for CBE:  Brig Weiler has been Inspector of Physical Training for the last 3 years.   During that time he has been a personal inspiration to the Corps of Physical Training and in spite of many difficulties the Corps is in an extremely high state of efficiency.   He has personally supervised and directed the Physical Training of the Regular Army in practically every station in the world and the results of his efforts have been of the highest order.   He has also carried out tasks far beyond his normal duties to the great advantage of the Physical Training and sport throughout the country as well as to the Army.   It is to a great extent due to his personal keenness, efficiency and energy that the physical training of the Army is in such a good state and that the physical efficiency of the men in the Army is of such a high order.
Maj Gen Director of Military Training.    National Archive WO 373/158.

Sicily.   Citation for Military Cross:   This Officer is in charge of the Provost Section attached to 152nd Infantry Brigade for operations.   On 13th July 1943 he was marking the route to be followed by the Brigade from CASSIBILE to FRANCOFONTE.   Shortly after passing through BUCCHRI he and his Corporal encountered two Italians who they made prisoners but almost immediately found themselves fired upon by two parties each of 6 or 7 men with several machine guns.   Several Italians rushed out to capture them but Lieut. Mackintosh interposed one of his prisoners between himself and the enemy.   The prisoner however attempted to expose Lieut. Macintosh to fire and had to be shot.   Meantime the Provost Corporal was wounded.   Lieut. Mackintosh scrambled away and covered the Corporal's withdrawl to his truck and then followed.   When the Advance Guard reached the scene of their encounter shorly afterwards, it was found that the enemy had bolted.   Lieut. Mackintosh showed great personal courage and it was due to his presence of mind and resoucefulness that neither he nor his Corporal was captured.   There is also no doubt that his bravery at this moment contributed to the hasty withdrawl of the enemy before the arrival of our Advance Guard.
Brigadier Comd 152 Inf Bde.   Lieut Gen GOC 30 Corps.   H R Alexander General GOC in C 15 Army Group.   B L Montgomery Gen GOC Eighth Army.   National  Archive WO 373/3.

Iraq, Tunisia.   Citation for MID:  Major SOFTLY has been APM of this Division since 3 Oct 41 and at all times has shown the greatest devotion to duty.   On the long move by road from Iraq to Northern Tunisia, during the closing weeks of the campaign and on the return journey to Tripoli, his work was particularly onerous and exacting;  always cheerful and quite tireless, his energy, tact and efficiency very largely contributed to the smooth and successful way in which all this movement was carried out.
Maj-Gen Comd 56 (London) Div.   Lieut Gen Comd 10 Corps.   National Archive WO 373/88 Pt.4.
Recommended for OBE changed to MBE awarded MID.
27/11/43 Hons & Awards the following award has been made in respect of the North African Campaign (LG 25/11/43) MID Major W G C Softly APM.   Unit War Diary WO 169/8829.

Sicily.   Citation for the OBE:  As A.P.M., 13 Corps, Lt.Col FITZGERALD was responsible during the planning period for the provost arrangements on the Corps front and for putting them into execution when the invasion took place.   The planning was carried out by him with great efficiency and foresight and to such good effect that traffic control in SICILY was established from the outset on a thoroughly satisfactory basis.   Had this not been the case the success of the operations would have been seriously prejudiced.   Lt.Col FITZGERLAND was confronted with a difficult task:  to maintain a continuous flow of traffic along roads which were narrow and mountainous, often congested with refugees and obstructed at many points by enemy demolitions.   It was mainly due to his personality, leadership and drive that the Corps Provost Company kept the traffic in motion, working long hours under arduous conditions.   This outstanding work by Lt.Col FITZGERALD in SICILY is not an isolated example of the service which he has rendered.   Over a period of thirteen months covering operations in the Western Desert and Cyrenaica this officer has maintained the Corps Provost Company at a high level of efficiency and discipline, and has instilled into all ranks his own qualities of energy, courtesy and good humour.   Lt. Col FITZGERALD has carried out his duties with exceptional ability and has made a contribution of undoubted value to the successful  outcome of the recent operations.
Brig C P H Roberts DA & QMG 13 Corps.   Lieut Gen M C Dempsey Commander 13 Corps.   National Archive WO 373/71 Pt.2.

Sicily.   Citation for MBE:  During the period 25 July 43 to 14 Aug. 43 this officer acted as  A.P.M. and O.C., 78 Div Provost Coy.   During this period the Division was constantly on the move and had to fight their way across two rivers.   The nature of the country made the deployment of the Division extraordinarily difficult.   Throughout the whole of this period this officer was untiring in his efforts to maintain the flow of essential traffic.   On the night 5/6 Aug. 43, during the crossing of the River Salso this officer was constantly under shell fire, and it was largely due to his efforts that troops were got across the river before daylight.   Throughout the campaign in Sicily he has shown untiring energy and drive, and has carried out a very difficult task with great success.   His example has been an inspiration to all his men.
Maj-Gen V Evelegh, GOC 78 Div.   Lieut-Gen O W H Leese GOC 30 Corps.   National Archive WO373/71pt.2.

Italy.   Citation for MC:  During the attack on FOSSACESSIA (MR396046) on 30 Nov this officer was responsible for dealing with a particularly heavily defended part of the village.   Due to Lt. Wilson's leadership the task was rapidly executed despite the fact that he was badly shaken when the first house he entered received a direct hit by a shell.   Two days later on the TREGLIO ridge (MR 3607 Lanciano) Lt. Wilson and his platoon beat off two enemy counter attacks and thus played an important part in holding the ground already won.   This officer later took over command of another Coy, when all its officers had been wounded, and for three tiring days led it with great skill & determination.   He has been tireless & set a high example to all.   I strongly recommend the award of the M.C.

Normandy.   Citation for MBE:  Major Cowie has served continously in the Army for nearly 24 years.   His record of service in the ranks shows outstanding zeal and he was an RSM in the East Surrey Regt before being commissioned in Dec 1940.   He joined the 3 Div Pro Coy in Nov 41 and commanded it from June 42 until May 43 when he became APM.   During his service with this Division his work has been marked by a conspicuous keenness.   He is extremely hardworking and consicentious and it has been due to him that a high standard in the Pro services of the Division has been maintained both during exercises and under static conditions.   His cheerfulness and enthusiams have been an invaluable asset throughout.
Maj-Gen Comd 3 Br Inf Div.   Comd 1 Corps.   National Archive WO 373/156
29/6/44 Maj C B Cowie APM 3 BR Inf Div awarded  MBE & CQMS F C Bands awarded  BEM IN King's Birthday honours List..  PM 1 Corps  Unit War Diary WO 171/281.

Italy.   Citation for MBE:  Major DOBSON has been APM of 5 Div throughout the ITALIAN campaign, as well as in SICILY.   He has carried out his duties with outstanding efficiency.  The advance of 5 Div through mountainous country, along difficult and precarious axes and in the face of numerous demolitions and obstacles, has necessitated the very highest standard of traffic control and discipline.   These standards have always been maintained by the Provost of 5 Div owning to the excellent example and unsparing efforts of Major DOBSON..   The speed of the advance of 5 Div through CALABRIA and Southern ITALY was largely due to his endeavours.
Maj-Gen Comd 5 Div.   Lieut Gen Comd 13 Corps.   National Archive WO 373/71.pt.3.
Number shown as 167120 in citation.

Italy.   Citation for MBE:  Major Jones as APM (Traffic) on the Staff of the DPM at Read HQ Eighth Army in Italy from 3 Sept 43 to 31 Dec 43 and previously throughout the Sicilian campaign has been largely responsible for the co-ordination of the traffic regulations laid down by the Staff and for the successful execution of the smooth move forward of the great volume of the Army's transport throughout completely foreign terrain.   His able handling of the limited CMP Traffic Control resources under conditions never before experienced by this Army necessitated much careful thought and hard work on his part.  Many difficulties have been overcome chiefly on account of the personal touch Major Jones has maintained with the men throughout, often this necessitated his presence on the roads for long periods from 18 to 20 hours daily, frequently under very trying circumstances.   His vigilance has undoubtedly very largely assisted in the maintenance of the forward troops.   Major Jones by his enthusiasm and untiring efforts for Provost has made a great contribution towards the successful traffic arrangements so necessary in the move forward of the Eighth Army from Reggio to Ortona.
Lt-Col J R Archer Burton DPM Eight Army,   Lt-Gen GOC Eighth Army.  National Archive WO 373/71 Pt 3.
Number shown as 129184 in MBE citation.

Normandy.   Citation for MC:  This officer arrived on the Beach at H + 20 minutes when it was being swept by Mortar and Machine gun fire.   He led an attack across the sand dunes, capturing a pill box and six prisoners.   He then attacked and captured a Mortar position.   He later cleared a number of more dug outs, collecting eventually about 30 prisoners.   During the whole of this time he was under Mortar and small arms fire, but he entirely disregarded them and pressed his attack home, showing cool and courageous leadership which inspired the men under him.
Commanding Officer 101 Beach Group, 3 Div.  National Archive WO 373/48

T/Lt/Col. Wilfred Annersley Bickford, 1 Bn. Royal Berkshire Regiment.
Citation for outstanding gallantry and devotion to duty.
     1 R. Berks. was the first Bn. of 6 Infantry Brigade to relieve the original beleagured KOHIMA Garrison.   During the period of three weeks the Bn. held an exposed sector of the front.   Continually sniped and grenaded and twice attacked, the Bn. held on to all its ground.   The Bn. was then withdrawn to re-organize and was, after four days, used to attack F.S.D feature which was strongly held by the JAP 58 Regt.   The attack spread over two days, was completely successful and resulted in the final clearing of the whole of the JAP positions SOUTH of KOHIMA Garrison Hill.
     Lt/Col BICKFORD organized and commanded this troops magnificently throughout the whole period.   His personal bearing at all times has been an inspiration to his fine Bn.
Recommended by Comd. 6 Inf. Bde., C in C 14 Army.

Citation for MC:   This officer was in command of two sections of Militry Police whose duty it was to ensure a smooth flow of traffic in the assault crossing of the river Rapido (Italy) on the night of 11-12 May 1944.   Citation for MC:  This officer was in command of two sections of Military Police whose duty it was to ensure a smooth flow of traffic in the assault crossing of the R. Rapido at MR865172 on the night of 11/12 May 1944.   Although under heavy shell, mortar and MG fire, this officer took control of his TCPs, displaying great courage and complete disregard for his personal safety.   On the morning of 12 May, owing to heavy enemy fire, the TCP personnel were ordered to withdraw behind the railway cutting.   Lieut CLARK reorganised these troops and led them forward again to re-establish the TCP's.   Once these were in a position and he was satisfied that all was in order he continued to visit them in turn under heavy enemy fire and personally to repair the telephone line back to Sector Control.   It was undoubtedly his complete grasp of the situation at a very difficult time that very materially assisted in the traffic control across the R.Rapido.
Capt OC 4 (Brit) Div Pro Coy.   Maj-Gen Comd 4 Brit Inf Div.  Lieut General Commander 13 Corps.  Lt-Gen  GOC Eighth Army.   National  Archive WO 373/8
16/7/44 Spello, Lieut Clark received MC from General.   Unit War Diary WO 170/424.

Citation for the OBE:   This officer has held the appointment of DPM Eight Army since 24 Aug 1943.   During this period the Eighth Army advanced rapidly through the toe and heel of ITALY to its final front on the ADRIATIC Coast, where it remained until early in Mar 1944 when regrouping on the Western Axis began in preparation for the Spring offensive.   The Provost problems during the advance up the East Coast;  during the static period on that front under bitter winter conditions, and later during the complicated regrouping of the Eighth Army on the Western Axis called for Provost work of the very highest order.   The high standard of efficiency maintained throughout all these operations by the Provost of the Eighth Army, and the ability with which the many difficult problems were tackled and overcome is due in large measure to the inspiration and capacity for organisation displayed by this officer, whose personal example at all times, his enthusiasm and untiring energy, and his loyal co-operation with all branches of the Staff and the Services of the Army, as well as with the Allied formations within the Army and those co-operating with the Army, both American and French, has set an example which is reflected throughout the Corps of Provost in the Eighth Army.
Brig F E M Bastyan, DA & QMG 8th Army.   Lt Gen GOC Eighth Army.   National Archive WO 373/72

Italy.   Citation for MBE:  Captain COOPER commands a SIB Section operating in and around BARI.   BARI is the centre of a highly organised and efficient Black Market, and the extensive layout of the military depots combined with the shortage of military guards has resulted in organised pilferage by civilian gangs on a very large scale.   Captain COOPER has tackled the problem energetically and with conspicuous success.   He has succeeded in breaking up the principal gangs engaged in the mail-bag, sugar and flour robberies, and the decline in organised pilferage is directly due to his tirelessness, efficiency and enthusiasm, while on several occasions he has displayed considerable courage when effecting single-handed the arrest of armed racketeers.   He has already recovered property amounting to nearly 12,400.
Brigadier G V Palmer Commander 6 Base Sub Area.   Maj Gen E P Nares Comd No2 District.   National Archive WO 373/72.

He frequently worked under shell and mortar fire but carried on with the work on hand.   By his devotion to duty and determination he was largely responsible for the smooth running of the traffic and, in doing so, setting a fine example to all.
Capt Comd 78 Div Pro Coy.   Maj Gen GOC 78 Div,  Lieut-Gen GOC 13 Corps.   National Archive WO 373/90.   Recommended for MBE periodical awarded MID.

During that period the Division has frequently been on the move over narrow muddy roads, generally in contact with the enemy.   Maj KNEE's tireless devotion to duty under adverse conditions with little rest and often under enemy fire has contributed in no small measure to the success of the operations of the Division, and has been an outstanding example to those working under him.   The efficiency of traffic control under such conditions has been vital to operations and a matter of extreme difficulty.

New Year Honours.   Brigadier Dennis Bossey Rendell, MBE, MC., ADC., (180657). PM (Army), RMP.   28 Mar 74 to date.
Citation:     Brigadier Rendell has been Provost Marshal (Army) since March 1974.   During this time as professional Head of his Corps and continuing emergency in Northern Ireland has made special demands on the Royal Military Police whilst their previously existing tasks have in no way diminished.   Brigadier Rendell has displayed exceptional leadership in directing the activities and maintaining the well-being of his Corps throughout this time.   He has been a tower of strength and nothing has been too much trouble for him;  meanwhile his Corps has responded magnificently to his lead in so admirably fulfilling their massive commitments in difficult circumstances.
     Brigadier Rendell has shown outstanding ability in maintaining the morale and his standards of the RMP.   His common-sense, patience and co-operation with others, have played a vital part in the work of his Corps over the last 2 1/2 years.
     Brigadier Rendell retires from the active list at the end of the year.   he has given splendid service to his Corps and to the Army and Strongly merits recognition.
Recommended by:  Maj/Gen. Vice Adjutant General.   Gen. Adjutant General MOD (Army).

193370 Lieut-Col. Ralph Gwyn Davies, MC.
Citation for OBE.   20/8/1968 to 14/7/1971. APM Berlin.
     Lieutenant Colonel Davies has held the key appointment in Berlin of Assistant Provost Marshal for nearly three years.   In addition to his normal Provost duties, Lieutenant Colonel Davies has been responsible for controlling and supervising all Royal Military Police patrols around the perimeter of the British Sector of Berlin and the Soviet War Memorial.
     In the event of an incident he has made it his duty whenever possible to be the first British officer to arrive on the scene.   As a result he has become known to the Soviet and East German officials as a recognised authority with whom they should deal.   Furthermore he accepts that once involved h cannot expect to be relieved, no mater how long the incident lasts since a change in the lever of representation might be interpreted as a change of policy.
     By his selfless enthusiasm, initiative and sound judgement, particularly in dealing with an incident, Lieutenant Colonel Davies has been able to make an exceptional contribution to the avoidance of tension in Berlin.   He has dealt closely with this Russian counterparts at the Soviet War Memorial and the Allied Check-points.   His opinion and experience is much respected by all members of the British Military Government and his is frequently used to clarify Soviet intentions and to deliver protest to them.   By his bluff good humour, tact and shrewd judgement, often under trying circumstances, he has achieved remarkable results.
     Throughout his tour he has worked in a very close harmony and co-operation with this French and American colleagues and they too regard him with respect and affection.
     His loyalty and conscientious hard work have been far above the normal course of duty.
Recommended by GOC Berlin.

North West Europe.   Citation for the OBE:  Lieut-Colonel DRAKE, As DPM Second Army, has had a task to perform of peculiar difficulty from the beginning of the operation.   It was largely due to his tireless efforts and patient skill that the acute traffic problems in a constricted bridgehead did not strangle the progress of operations.   Later, he has contrived, with limited resources, to maintain the flow of vehicles along an ever-extending L of C.   His own qualities of unselfinshness, tact and high sense of duty have been an example for all ranks of the CMP.   His work has been outstanding throughout the campaign.
Brig AQ Second Army.   Lieut-Gen Commander Second Army.   National Archive WO 373/83.

North West Europe.   Citation for the MBE:  This offr was 2 IC No 4 Cdn Pro Coy from 31 Jul 43, until he assumed Comd on 16 Jul 44.   During that time he showed remarkable ability, initiative and drive, and the manner in which he assisted the Coy Comd was most notable.   During the days of preparation for the assault, his keenness, example and exceptional hard work greatly assisted the Coy Comd in putting into the field an efficient, well equipped team of very high morale.   Since "D" Day this offr's devotion to duty has been remarkable and, since assuming Comd of the Coy on 16 Jul 44, it has been he who, as the example and leader, has been responsible for many fine tasks performed by the Coy and the maintenance of its morale.   This offr, too, through his ingenuity and  forethought, has introduced many ideas into the Pro Service which have very definitely improved the standard of route signing and general infm available to tps on the rds.
Maj W G Lloyd APM 3Cdn Inf Div.   Maj -Gen D C Spry GOC 3 Cdn Inf Div.   Lt-Gen G G Simonds Comd 2 Cdn Corps.   Lt-Gen H D G Crerar GOC-in-C First Cdn Army.   National Archive WO 373/83.

North Africa.   Citation for the OBE:  
This Officer came out with the First Army in the early stages of the operations in North Africa and has shown the greatest ability in dealing with the many Provost problems which faced him in a new theatre.   He has never spared himself and has obtained first class results in all he has done.   His sincerity and tact have made possible real co-operation  between our own provost services and those of our Allies and on that account difficulties in administration of discipline in an inter allied force have been reduced to a minimum.   His services are undoubtedly worthy of recognition.
DAG AFHQ.   Maj Gen Chief Admin Officer Allied Force HQ.   National Archive WO373/71 Pt.1.

Italy.   Citation for MBE:This officer has rendered outstanding work during the past twelve months as Assistant Provost Marshal in the Provost Marshal's Office (AFHQ).   He has materially assisted in the construction of a very comprehensive set of provost instructions, used not only by the whole provost service in this theatre but also with the armies now in France.   A large part of this work was generated out of the recognised office hours.   He has contributed by his great attention to detail to ensure that  all ranks in the Military Police have received their maximum share of their entitlements.   His work during the past year represents the greatest devotion to the cause of this Corps which he has so very much at heart.
Col N C M Sykes Provost Marshall.   General Supreme Allied Commander, Mediterranean Theatre.   National Archive WO 373/75pt.2.

North West Europe.   Citation for MBE:  As APM of the Div, this officer has played a most important part in the big advances which have characterised the last three months.   He has displayed great energy and has successfully dealt with the most difficult problems, involving as they have, long hours and great distances, sometimes through country still full of enemy.
Maj-Gen Comd 7 Armd Div.   Lieut Gen Comd 12 Corps.   Lieut-Gen Commander Second Army.   National Archive WO 373/83.

North West Europe.   Citation for the award of the OBE:  Colonel Basset Wilson has been the Provost Marshal of 21 Army Group since its formation and before that of GHQ Home Forces.   As such he has been responisible for the raising, training and operating of units of the Provost Service particularly in the present operation.   The high standard attained by the Provost Service and their success in operations is a testimony to his ability and efficiency which speaks for itself.   In carrying out his duties he has given unstintingly of his self and I know of no none whom I consider to be better qualified for a Decoration.
Brig DAG 21 Army Group.   Maj-Gen I/c Admin.   National Archive WO 373/83.

Normandy.   Citation for the MBE:  Capt CORBETT commanded 245 HQ Pro Coy in 101 Beach Sub Area until July 44.   He landed on the SWORD Beaches on D Day and was responisible for the organisation and development of traffic control in the Port of OUISTREHAM and the BMA.   For five weeks the beaches and BMA Area including the Port of OUISTREHAM were under fire.   During this period his steadfastness of purpose and quiet leadership was an inspiration to his Company and the Beach Group.   At the end of June and until the end of July he was attached to HQ 101 Beach Sub Area as DAPM.   He entered Caen on 10 July 44, the day after the town fell, and had under his direct command 245 HQ Pro Coy, 2 sections of Canadian Army Pro, and , at varying times, one or two secs of 1 Corps and 3 Cdn Div.   To him fell the task of organising the control of momement through CAEN, the imposition of restrictions of entry and exit, both civilian and military, and the maintenance of discipline in a town so severely damamged by bombing and shell fire that the temptations to looters were countless.   This entailed the early recce of his area of operations and frequent and rapid readjustments in the deployment of his limited resources.   Over 29 control points were at one time necessary in and around the town.   He maintained close liaison with the RE engaged on street clearance, with the Pro of 3 Cdn Div, 2 Cdn Corps, and with the civil authorities.   His posts were under constant mortar and shell fire until the advance continued beyond VAUCELLES;   Capt CORBETT continually visited these posts inspiring and encouraging his men who were at times on duty for periods of 48 hrs without a break or respite.   Capt CORBETT worked quietly and efficiently.   His execution of quick orders and new plans was beyond all praise.   He was largely responisible for the fact that at no time did the flow of refugees cause any embarrassment to the military operations.   For this quiet, efficient and cheerful example of leadership and resourcefulness under the most trying conditions I recommend him for the award of the MBE.
Col E J Montgomery, Comd 101 Beach Sub Area.   Brig H C T Stronge Comd 12 L of C Area.   Maj-Gen Comd L of C.   National Archive WO 373/83.

Normandy.  6/6/44 to 31/10/44.    Citation for MBE:  Lieut MULHEIR landed in FRANCE on D Day, 6 June 44, on the staff of MOON assembly Area.   From that moment he was a tower of strength to the unit.   He was responsible for the traffic layout of the Assembly Area and for traffic control.   His men were all category men and it was entirely due to Lieut MULHEIR's actions that they did their job.   The conditions were very difficult.   The unit area was subject almost nightly to bombing attacks, and it was during this that, with disregard for his own safety, he travelled round to his men, staying with them on their points and encouraging them.   On the night of 9 June 44 there was a particularly bad attack with AP bombs and there were quite heavy casualties in one section of the Assembly Area.   Lieut MULHEIR immediately went to the spot and took command of the situation although he was by no means the senior officer present.   His action steadied the men and he supervised the evacuation of casualties.   On 12 June again he proceeded immediately to the scene of another attack and supervised the evacuation of casualties.   On 12 June 44 it was necessary to reorganise the area for the reception of 8 Corps.   This meant the re-signing of the area in a hurry as the unloading of the Corps was expected to begin at any time.   This re-signing was carried out by Lieut MULHEIR at night through further air raids until the task was finished.   Although the traffic circuits had to be changed, at no time was there any block in the flow of traffic.
Col E Montgomery Comd 101 Beach Sub Area.   Comd 11 L of C Area.   Maj Gen Comd L of C.   National Archive WO 373/83.

citation:
North West Europe 6/6/44 to 31/10/44.   Citation for MBE: This Officer, as APM TRAFFIC L of C has carried out his duties exceptionally well.   He is most conscientious and combines energy with enthusiasm.   He has been responsible for the operational role of the Traffic throughout the whole of the Lines of Communication and has planned that Traffic is controlled right through and along the maintenance and operational routes, the success of which has been due to his untiring supervision.   He has taken a great interest in the fourteen Companies, and their smartness and knowledge of their local area has been the cause of comment.   I cannot speak too highly of this Officer and feel that he deserves recognition.
Lt-Col Cheney, DPM HQ L of C.   Maj-Gen Comd, L of C.   National Archive WO 373/83

Italy.   Citation for OBE:  Has acted as D.P.M. at HQ Rome Allied Area Command since its inception.   He has had direct control of British, U.S. and Allied Police units and has been responsible for the discipline of the first Capital City in Europe to be liberated, a City through which vast numbers of Allied troops have passed on leave.   His firmness, tact and robust commonsense have enable him to meet difficulties as they have arisen and to maintain a high standard.
Brig Alban Low Deputy Commander Rome, Area Commander British Troops in Rome.    National Archive WO 373/72

Italy.   Citation for MBE:  Captain Ingham, as Officer Commanding 105 (Army) Provost Company in Italy from 1 May 44 to 31 Aug 44, and previously as second in command throughout the Desert and Sicilian campaigns, has rendered valuable service to the Corps of Military Police.   This officer has been responsible for the general disciplinary duties, the route signing and policing of TAC, Main, and Rear Army Headquarters, and throughout the forward Army area.  As Commander of the leading Military Police Company it has always been his especial task to establish close liaison through AMG with all civil authorities and in particular the Carabinieri.   These important duties have always been successfully handled by Captain Ingham, and many difficulties have been overcome on account of the personal touch he has maintained throughout.   By his untiring efforts for Provost, Captain Ingham has made a very substantial contribution towards the successful Military Police arrangements so necessary during the advance of the Eighth Army from Cassino.
Lt Col J R Archer-Burton DPM Eighth Army. GOC Eighth Army.  Brigadier AA & QMG 8th Army.   National Archive WO 373/72.

Italy.   Citation for MBE:   Captain Barker, as Deputy Assistant Provost Marshal, Rear HQ, Eight Army, in Italy from 1 May 44 to 31 Aug 44, and previously throughout the Desert and Sicilian campaigns, has served with distinction.   Whilst largely responsible for the administrative work of the Service he has devoted himself wholeheartedly to all aspects of Police Work.   His duties have always been of a highly confidential nature involving all wings of the Corps, throughout he has fully justified the confidence placed in him.  By his untiring efforts for the Corps of Military Police during the past twenty-one months he has contributed very largely to the success the Provost Service has achieved in the maintenance of discipline, the prevention of crime, and the control of traffic in Eighth Army.
Brigadier DA & QMG Eighth Army.  Lt Col J R Archer-Burton DPM Eight Army.  Lt-Gen McCreery GOC Eighth Army.   National Archive WO 373/72.

Italy.   Citation for MBE.:  This officer has been APM SIB at this HQ since last March when a Staff Officer SIB was first allowed on WE.   The strength of the Branch has considerably increased during this period.   By his outstanding initiative and organising abilities he has brought about a complete co-ordination of SIB effort throughout Italy and Sicily, and to a marked degree is personally responsible for the good feeling and co-operation which now exists between the SIB and other Branches of the Provost Service.   By constant supervision and instruction he has put the administration of Special Investigation Sections on to a sound footing, and undoubtedly his enthusiasm and technical ability have been largely instrumental in the rounding up in recent months of the dangerous gangs of "Deserter Criminals" who were operating in Southern Italy and Sicily.
Colonel Provost Marshal AAI.   Maj Gen Chief Admin Officer.   National Archive WO 373/72.

Italy.   Citation for MBE:  Lieut WILLETTS has been senior subaltern of the Div Provost Coy since June '43.   He has been continually responsible for the organisation of the traffic control in the immediate rear of the forward troops.   He has shown great gallantry and determination during these operations and has carried out all these tasks with a skill and speed which ensured success.   This officer has been an inspiring example to the Officers and men in the Div Provost Coy by his initiative, enthusiasm and devotion to duty.   This particular period covered the speedy and successful advance of the Div, over the difficult country from the RAPIDO to LAKE TRASIMENE, from 12 May to 4 July 44, which necessitated very long arduous hours of work and considerable ingenuity on the part of this officer.
Capt N Bentham OC 78 Div Pro Coy.   Brig R K Arbuthnott GOC 78 Inf Div.  Lt -Gen GOC Eighth Army.   National Archive WO 373/72.
16/8/45 Capt Willets referred to as MBE.   Unit War Diary WO 170/4403.

Middle East Nov 41-April 42.    Greece.
North West Europe.

North West Europe.   Citation for MBE: Major PASCALL has been APM of this Division throughout the operations in North Western Europe.   His organisation of the Traffic Control both under the static conditions in NORMANDY and on the long hunt up to HOLLAND has been quite excellent.   He is absolutely tireless in his work and will never rest whilst the Division is on the move.   in spite of his sometimes unpleasant duties, he is universally popular and respected throughout the Division.   His work at the various assault crossings of rivers which the Division has carried out has been invaluable and has ensured the smooth passage of the vehicles of the Division.   This work has necessitated daylight recces of the proposed crossing places whilst they were still in enemy hands, the planning of the various vehicle parks, traffic communications, the guiding of Sector Controls and TP's to the Bridge sites, and finally the continuous supervision of the traffic at the bridges, which naturally become the principal targets for enemy shell and mortar fire.
Maj-Gen Comd 53 Div.   Lt-Gen BG Horrocks 30Corps.  Lieut-Gen Comd Second Army.   National Archive WO 373/84.

North West Europe.   Citation for MC:  T/Major Chittock has been Assistant Provost Marshal of the 15th Scottish Division throughout the campaign.   His work as APM has always been of the highest order.   In battle he has displayed great energy and personal courage, visiting his police in dangerous and exposed places, often under enemy shell fire.   During the advance to HORST on 22nd and 23rd November, 1944, when the Division depended on only one muddy track for both its tactical and maintenance traffic he was forward at the earliest moment supervising the traffic arrangements, and over the two days he spent 14 hours under particularly difficult circumstances and was on three occasions under shell fire.   Again on 3rd December, 1944, during the attack on HLERICK, Major CHITTOCK spent 6 hours personally supervising the traffic arrangements in the Forming Up Place and at the entrances to the lanes through the minefield, here again he was subject to enemy shelling.   His example and personal courage under fire have been a fine influence on the Military Police and other troops.
Maj Gen C M Barber Comd 15 (S) Div.   Lt Gen GOC 8 Corps.   Lieut Gen Commander Second Army.   National Archive WO 373/54.

Italy.   Citation for award of the CBE:   Has held the appointment of PM, HQ AAI (Allied Army Italy), since March 44.   He has shown a through grasp of his duties and has set a high standard of energy, alertness, efficiency and courtesy of conduct for his Officers to follow.   Over a difficult period, faced with many disciplinary and manpower problems, he has exhibited initiative, resource and powers of organisation.   His work in connection with CMP training has been most valuable.   The close touch he has maintained with forward formations has allowed sudden operational problems to be met and solved.   Under his direction the relations between personnel of the CMP and the Staff and Services, Formations under command, and the US Forces have been excellent.   His work has enhanced the credit of the Corps of Military Police in AAI.
Brig C H Paton DAG.   Maj Gen Robertson.   National Archive WO 373/73.
BEF.

Italy.   Citation for MBE:  During the breaking of the GOTHIC LINE and subsequent battles this division advanced over most difficult mountainous country.   Axes never good, often consisted of narrow one way roads and tracks made almost impassable by incessant rain.   Traffic control under such conditions was a major battle winning factor.   Major KNEE as APM of the division worked tirelessly, nearly always under the most adverse weather conditions and often under enemy shell fire to ensure the efficient movement and control of traffic which was essential both tactically and administratively.   That no opertion failed on this score was primarily due to his untiring efforts.   Always cheerful and willing, this officers's unflagging devotion to duty and the outstanding example he has set to those working under him during the whole of the past year have been deserving of the highest praise.
Lieut Col O R C Carey AA & QMG 8 Ind Div.   Maj Gen D Russell Comd 8 Indian Div.  Maj Gen Commander 13 Corps.   National Archive WO 373/73

Italy. 5 Canadian Provost Company.   Capt. Anthony Joseph Scotti.
Citation:   Captain SCOTTIi has served continuously with 5 Canadian Provost Company from January 1943 and throughout his tour of command has performed his duties in a highly satisfactory manner.
     An energetic and tireless worker, Captain SCOTTI is well forward in actions organising and supervising the control of traffic.   Day or night in all kinds of weather, frequently under heavy artillery and mortar fire, this officer constantly visits his traffic posts to ensure a constant flow forward of supporting arms.
     On the night of 30 August 1944, Captain SCOTTI personally made a detailed reconnaissance of approach routes to the FOGLIA River for the GOTHIC LINE attack.   Not content with the information he obtained, he continued across the river and through a heavily mined area until he reached the MONBTECCHIO lateral.   As a result of this reconnaissance which was carried out under heavy mortar fire.   He formulated a sound traffic plan which contributed greatly to the success of the attack.
     The attack on CORIANO during the night 12/13 September 1944 followed two main axis of advance.   Both of the approaches and lateral road five hundred yards SOUTH of the town were under direct enemy observation.   Enemy minefield restricted movement on each road to one way traffic and this necessitated the strictest of traffic discipline and control, particularly in the early phases of the attack.   Captain SCOTTI sited two traffic control posts on the lateral road and throughout the attack personally maintained constant communication with the attacking Brigade headquarter and his traffic posts.   The outstanding coolness and rescurcefulness under fire displayed by this officer were an inspiration to all and the successful movement forward of supporting arms was due entirely to his planning and foresight.
    Under the brilliant leadership and organising ability of Captain SCOTTI, the company has reached such a high standard of efficiency that it has earned the esteem and respect of all ranks of the Division.

North West Europe.   Citation for OBE:  Lt-Col G W Ball has been DPM HQ First Cdn Army throughout the campaign in NWE.   He has as a result had important responsibilities in connection with the maintenance of discipline, law and order in the army area, traffic control, and prisoners of war, refugees and stragglers.   Lt-Col Ball has tackled all the problems which have come his way with exeptional industry and drive and has succeeded in instilling into his corps his own enthusiasm for its important tasks.   In all fields the work of the Provost Corps has been highly efficient.   That this has been so and that the Provost Corps is held in hight repute throughout First Cdn Army is due in very considerable measure to the leadership, organizing ability and example of Lt-Col Ball.
Brig J F A Lister DA & QMG First Canadian Army,   Gen H D G Crerar GOC-in-C First Canadian Army.   National Archive WO 373/84.

North West Europe.   Citation for MBE:  By reason of initiative, leadership and organising ability of Major Wilfred George LLOYD, Assistant Provost Marshal, provost resources with Third Canadian Infantry Division have at all times met the exceedingly heavy demands placed upon them.   This has been most evident during periods of active operations when traffic control on operational routes and the handling of prisoners of war have stretched provost resources to their limit.   On every occasion involving a move of this formation, Major LLOYD has personally gone to the forward areas to ensure that traffic moved in accordance with the plan.   Many times under enemy shell fire, the presence of Major LLOYD, his coolness, fine soldierly example and ability to overcome obstacles, no matter how dangerous the situation, have been the main factor in keeping the traffic moving forward unimpeded.   As a disciplinarian Major LLOYD has imbued all ranks with the high standard which he himself has set.   The excellent standard of discipline, deportment and esprit de corps among provost personnel in this formation are the direct result of the insisitence at all times by Major LLOYD that all ranks not only do their job well but under any and all conditions.   As a soldier and leader of men Major Wilfred George LLOYD has, by his ceaseless efforts, achieved an unrivalled reputation.
Maj W N Wickwire DAAG 3 Cdn Inf Div.   Maj-Gen DC Spry GOC 3 Cnd Inf Div..   Gen H D G Crear GOC-in-C First Cdn Army.   National Arlchive WO 373/84.

North West Europe.   Citation for the MBE:  During the period 1 Nov 44 - 31 Jan 45, this offr has handled the extremely difficult disciplinary problems in this area, particularly the port of  GHENT, in an exeptionally capable manner.   The presence of both rft personnel and personnel on leave from the front, in the same city has created many difficult problems and situations.   Capt WOOD has been extremelty active in dealing with these matters and is most efficient in the discharge of his duties.   The Comd (British) of the L  of C Sub-Area has spoken of the great value to them of the work carried out by Capt WOOD and of the unusually high regard they have for the results he gets.   Capt WOOD has displayed energy, and initiative above average during this period.
Brig G S N Gostiling Comd 2 Cdn Base Rft Gp.   Maj-Gen E L M Burns, GO I/c Cdn Sec 1 Ech, HQ 21 Army Gp.   Gen H D G Crerar GOC-in-C First Cnd Army.   National  Archive WO 373/84.

Inkerman Barracks, Woking.   June 50 - Feb 54.   QM D & T E RMP.
In addition to being a fine Quartermaster, Major Marriott (who has served for 25 years in the RMP, and is the only Regular Officer in the Corps) has given much spare time to the activities of the RMP Depot and of the Corps in general.   He is a fine influence on recruits, takes a real interest in their welfare and is a very active Churchwarden to the Depot Chapel.   I am sure that he contributes a bit share to the good spirit in the Corps, and submit that his services are worthy of recognition.
Lt Col A J J Somerville-McAlester, OC D & T E RMP.   Brigadier Provost Marshall War Office.   Maj Gen Director of Personal Services War Office.   National Archive WO 373/162.

Italy.   Citation for MBE: Major Carter, whilst DAPM (Traffic) on the staff of the DPM HQ Eighth Army in Italy from 1 Jan 45 - 7 Mar 45, and previously throughout the entire Italian campaign, has been very largely responsible for the successful control of traffic in the Army area and for the traffic organisation of all Army road-heads and railheads.   His efficiency and application at all times has been such that many policy and practical decisions of the Staff have been based on his personal advice and recommendations.   But over and above the normal duties required of his appointment, Major Carter has gone out of his way to watch, advise, and inspire all ranks and units of the CMP under Eighth Army in their practical control of huge volumes of traffic.   In all weathers, night and day for long continuous hours, Major Carter has himself been out on the road where conditions were most difficult, and by his own personal example helped to maintain enthusiasm and cheerful co-operations of all concerned in road movement.
Lt-Col J R Archer Burton OBE DPM 8 Army.   Brig. DA & QMG Eighth Army, Lt Gen GOC Eighth Army. National Archive WO 373/73.

North West Europe.   Citation for the award of the OBE:  This officer is DPM, 21 Army Group. BLA.   His work has been beyond praise in all phases of the operation from 'D' Day to the end.   He has shown terrific drive and unusual organising powers.   Through operational necessity he has been continually entrusted with powers and decisions above thos of a G1 level;  and invariably with admirable results.   In particular he has shown exceptional initiative and improvisation in securing many new types of equimpent urgently required by CMP units at short notice in battle.   That these and countless other vital rush-demands from lower formations were invariably met was mainly due to Lt Col STANLEY'S personal efforts and his ability to deal on equal terms with Staff Officers senior to himself.   He has throughout, inspired all ranks with his tireless energy and exemplary devotion to duty.   The success of the CMP in this campaign owes much to Lt Col STANLEY'S outstanding ability and example.
Col Basset F G Wilson PM 21 A/Gp.   Mam-Gen DAG 21 Army Gp.   National Archive WO 373/85

North West Europe.   Gloucestershire Regt.   From Upton St Leonards Glos.   APM 11 L of C 21st Army Group (Brussels).   Citation for MBE:  In every way the best APM that I have come across during my service.   Always correct and tactful, he has the highest possible sense of duty from which nothing can move him.   He knows his job from beginning to end, is intensely loyal and hard working.   During the last four months and indeed since the formation of these Headquarter he has been responsible for discipline and traffic control far beyond the normal of an L of C Area, and has performed every task to my entire satisfaction.   The unceasing devotion to duty and unremitting zeal displayed by this officer have been throughout of a very high order, and his inspiring example has been a marked contribution to provost work on the L of C.
Brig Comd 11  L of C Area.   Maj-Gen G Surtees Comd HQ L of C.

North West Europe.   Citation for MBE:  This officer has had a very difficult task in the last six months in Brussels and he has carried out his exceptionally heavy duties admirably.   The co-ordination of the duties of British Military and Royal Air Force Pro and American and Canandian Pro and their cooperation has been part of his extra responsibility whilst the innumerable raids on Cafes to ensure their closure at the correct hours, the enforcement of curfew regulations in a Capital City and the maintenance of discipline in a city full of resident troops and swoollen by and intake of 30,000 additional troops a week on leave, have been part of his extra responsibilities.   He has been indefatigable in his efforts to check the incidence of VD by hunting down sources of contaminations and the cooperation he has secured from the Civil Police in this respect has been most marked.   Another item of this officer's extra burden has been the heavy extra work in the control of vehs and traffic in Brussels, both military and civilian and the organisation and control of the Official Car Parks where some 30,000 vehs are parked each month and out of which but 5 vehs have been stolen.
Brigadier Comd Brussels Garrison.   Brigadier R H R Parminter Comd 11 L of C Area.   Maj-Gen G Surtees Comd HQ L of C.   National Archive WO 373/85
