North Africa, Italy.   Citation for OBE:  Lieut-Colonel BLAIR has been D.P.M. of North Africa District and No.2 District since July 1943.   His work during this period has been of an exceptionally high order.   Both in North Africa and in Italy he initiated and controlled with great success an organisation to defeat the extensive Black Market traffic which at the time was a considerable drain on W.D. resouces.   In both countries also he organised periodical drives against deserters, and due to his efforts many thousands were apprehended, and others deterred.   The sympathetic though firm attitude of the police under his command and guidance in the maintenance of discipline, and their smart appearance both on and off duty has earned the high respect of the rank and file for the Provost Service in the areas controlled by him.   Lieut-Colonel BLAIR has, by his loyal service and hard work, contributed materially, if indirectly, to the war effort, and I consider his services are deserving of the award of the O.B.E.
Maj-Gen E.P. Nares Commander no.2 District CMF.   National Archive WO 373/74.

Italy.   Citation for MBE:  Major EVATT has been APM of this Division for over a year.   During that time he has been in control of the Provost arrangements for three mobile campaigns and one static campaign.   The control and policing of roads has been of the utmost importance in all these battle.   It is not too much to say that in the recent mobile operation in April 1945, the whole battle has turned on getting formations quickly over bridges and through diversions and defiles.   Under this officer's organisation and control the Provost of this Division have carried out their tasks by day and night, often under fire, with efficiency, enthusiasm and a great devotion to duty.   In the recent campaign, advancing up to 50 miles a day, enormous distances had to be covered and policed.   The arrangements made by this officer never failed and he invariably appeared himself at the most difficult or advanced place.   In all Provost matters his own example and enthusiasm has been as infectious to those under him as it has been sustained in himself.
Lt Col GSO 1 6 Brit Armd Div.   Maj-Gen Comd 6 Armd Div,  Lieut-Gen Comd 5 Corps.   National Archive WO 373/74

Italy.   Citation for MBE:  For outstanding services as APM 13 Corps during the campaign in Italy.   Lt Col SHARP has been APM since 31 Mar 1944 until June 1945, during which time the Corps has been continuously deployed.   The work of the Provost Services of 13 Corps under the direction of Lt Col Sharpe have been outstandingly efficient.   By his drive, energy, tact and unfailing food humour, he has instilled into his men a keen sense of duty and cheerful endeavour, which have earned the praise of all formations in the Corps.   During the advance from CASSINO in 1944, throughout the severe winter conditions in the Appenine Mountains, and in the final battles culminating in the pursuit to TRIESTE, the traffic problems of the Corps have been considerable.   By his resource, initiative and his extreme devotion to duty, Lt col Sharp overcame all difficulties.   He has made a great personal contribution to the success achieved by 13 Corps.   National Archive WO 373/74.

Bar to DSO.   Italy.   Lt Col KAYE has commanded 10H during the April offensive from LAKE COMMACHIO to the River Po.   Throughout this period the regiment has performed very successfully many difficult and hazardous tasks.   In particular, during operation "IMACT" they were called upon to support infantry over almost impossible country, and in the face of strong enemy opposition and A tk guns.   The tremendous support which was accorded on this occasion greatly assisted in the capture of the Div and Corps objectives, earning the greatest praise and credit from GOC 56 Div, Maj Gen J Y WHITFIELD, DSO, OBE.   Throughout all this period Lt Col KAYE by his determination, sound tactical knowledge and true devotion to duty was mainly responsible for his regiment achieving this success.   At all times Lt Col KAYE's presence with the leading troops in close contact with the enemy and under heavy fire instilled the maximum confidence in his men, and he was a magnificent example of courage and devotion to duty to all present.   Previously, during the period from the GOTHIC LINE up to the assault on R. SENIO, the 10th Hussars have except for a period of ten days, been continuosly in the line.   During all this period the regiment, under Lt Col KAYE's command, has carried out invaluable work in close support of many infantry units, whose commanders have all expressed their admiration and praise of this regiment.   The first class co-operation, skill and drive shown by Lt Col KAYE has been at all times and inspiration, and these factors are so largely responsible for the many successful actions in which this regiment has taken part.
Brigadier Comd 2 Armd Bde.   Lieut Gen Commander 5 Corps.   Lt Gen McCreery GOC Eighth Army.
National Archive WO 373/14.
New Year Honour.

North West Europe.   Citation for OBE:  Lt-Col Godfrey-Faussett served with Headquarters 1 Corps throughout the campaign in North West Europe from 6 June 1944 until the 20 March 1945 as APM and from 20 March until the end of the campaign on 8 May 1945 as DPM.   He was responsible within 1 Corps for the provost planning for the assault and for organizing the assembly areas behind the beaches through which all troops following up the assault were to pass.   He himslef landed on D Day and immediatley took charge of all provost arrangements within the beachhead, working without sleep for over 72 hours.   That both units, individuals and vehicles, landing on a strange shore were able to find their way smoothly and without delay to their ultimate locations was very largely due to his powers of organization and to the complete control over the situation which he always possessed.   Later he organized with conspicuous success the traffic control arrangments for operation GOODWOOD, when three Armoured Divisions had to be passed at night on improvised tracks and roadways across the whole of the Corps front in the concentrated beach-head.   At the end of August for twenty four hours after the liberation of LISIEUX the great volume of traffic which had to pass through the bottleneck formed by this town produced a very serious problem.   Again owing to his quiet determination and ability the situation was controlled.   In September the traffic control for the move of the whole Corps from the area of LE HAVRE to BELGIUM required the most careful planning, and that the move was carried out smoothly is largely due to this officer's efforts.   Throughout the winter in HOLLAND the military police in 1 Corps under his direction maintained a consistently high standard.   This officer has throughout set a fine personal example and by his conscientiousness, enthusiasm and quiet ability has contributed in no small way to the ultimate success of operations.
Brigadier A HQ 1 Corps District.   Lt-Gen Comd 1 Corps District.  National Archive WO 373/86.

North West Europe.   Citation for the OBE:  This officer has been the Provost Staff Officer whose duty has been the maintenance of military discipline and good order throughout the Army during its progress from the Beaches to the Baltic.   Owing to the disorganisation or absence of Civil Police forces in liberated and enemy countries, there has been added the further grave responsibility for preventing disorder among the civil population, and recently in Germany, ensuring obedience and good behavious under Milittary Government Law.   His imperturbability under exacting conditions and powers of organisation of the highest order caused a large number of suspected persons, including some war criminals, to be apprehended and an enormous displaced population to be controlled and prevented from continual looting and riot.   At one time the stealing and improper possession of WD stores in liberated countries gave cause for anxiety.   By his capapcity for careful though and hard work the larceny of petrol and rations was almost entirely stopped and Government property of enormous value was recovered for use in operations.
Col F C Drake, DPM Second Army.   Lieut-Gen Commander Second Army.   National Archive WO 373/86.

North West Europe.   Citation for MBE:  This officer has been the Provost Staff officer whose duty has been the organisation of traffic control throughout the Army Area.   Prior to D Day he trained the Coys concerned and since that date has carried the immense responsibility of ensuring the safe and timely passage of every operational and supply column from Normandy to the Baltic.   With his enthusiasm and tireless energy, he was continually out supervising the routes themselves in all weathers and conditions, and by his perseverance inspired all ranks operating under him with the magnitude and importance of their task,   Many and varied were the situations with which he has been suddenly faced during the twelve months he has shouldered this task and no praise is too high for the manner in which he has dealt with a volume of traffic hitherto unsurpassed.
Col F C Drake DPM Second Army.   Lieut-General Commander Second Army.   National Archive WO373/86.

North West Europe.  Citation for MBE:  Major GUILD has been APM during the whole campaign.   Provost resources have seldom been sufficient to cover requirements of policing and of traffic control.   By careful planning and constant attention to changing situations Major GUILD has ensured the best use of his limited resouces.   He has been out himself on all possible occasions and could usually be found directing operations where difficulties were likely to arise.   He has an extremely high sense of duty and has never spared himself in carrying out that duty.
Brigadier A/Q 12 Corps.   Lieut-General Comd 12 Corps.   National Archive WO 373/86.

Normandy.  Citation for MBE:  Capt JONES, OC 73 SIS, landed in FRANCE in Jul 44.   Since that date he has commanded his section with conspicuous success.   At a time when loss of petrol was becoming a matter for grave anxiety, his efforts were largely directed to the prevention of large scale stealing from depots and particularly from the pipeline.   This officer, by his brilliant leadership of his section succeeded in breaking the largest black market gang in FRANCE, thereby not only saving many thousands of pounds worth of goods but also recovering vast quantities of govermnment property which were urgently required.   His name is a byword in NORMANDY.   In spite of an almost overwhelming amount of work, with his section split over a wide area, never once did Capt JONES show himself unable to assist formation staffs in any new problems, however small.   His ready coopertion, his unfaliling cheerfulness, his persistence, and the unassuming manner with which he shouldered the most complex problems, have revealed an officer of great distinction and high merit.   His unswerving devotion to duty has been an inspiration to all with whom he came into contact.
Brig G S Knight Comd 21 L of C Sub Area.   Maj Gen G Surtees Comd HQ L of C.  National Archive WO 373/86.

North West Europe.   Citation for MBE:  This officer is APM, Special Investigation Branch, 21 Army Group, and has been in charge of all the Investigation Sections in 21 Army Group during the whole campaign.   I consider that Major Pollard is out-standing.   In civil life he is in the CID Metropolitan Police and is a first rate policeman and investigator.   He has been connected in many cases of crime in France, Belgium, Holland and Germany and has brought to light a great number of cases, some of considerable size and importance, the result of which has saved the country a huge sum of money.   He is most conscientious and combines energy with enthusiasm and fairness with sympathy.   The SIB, under Major Pollard, has done magnificent work and has been the cause for much comment.   I cannot speak too highly of this officer and feel strongly that he deserves recognition.
Brig Cheney Provost Marshal.   Maj Gen DAG HQ 21 Army Group.   National Archive WO 373/86.

Burma.   Citation for MC:  FOR CONSPICUOUS DEVOTION TO DUTY .  Maj LAXTON has been APM of 20 Indian Div since April 1942 when the division was raised, and has done a first class job of work throughout, during the preliminary organisation period, during the training period in CEYLON and since October 1943 in the operational area in ASSAM  and BURMA.   For the last six months he has most successfully organised the traffic control and provost duties on a very long stretch of road from PALEL to TAMU and beyond, and when the Japanese advanced in March 1944, the smooth and effective evacuation of a very great number of engineer and pioneer personnel and of a mass of stores and equipment was made possible by his untiring devotion to duty, ceaseless energy, and personal initiative.   In the latter stages of the withdrawal from MOOREH and other areas on the TAMU - PALEL road, the road was frequently shelled, mortared and sniped by parties of enemy infiltrating on the sides of the roads.   Completely regardless of his own safety at all times he was always where he was most wanted, marshalling vehicles, clearing blocks of traffic, inspecting his many and scattered control posts, and encouraging the men at them, until on the 31st March 1944 he was wounded by a shell which pitched on the road near him while he was marshalling vehicles.   Though suffering from several severe wounds, he organised the evacuation of others wounded in the area by the same shelling, and did not go to hospital until his work for the day was completed.   His devotion to duty throughout the period from April 1942 to March 1944 has been deserving of the highest praise and has contributed largely to the smoothness and security with which the many moves of the Division during this period have been carried out.
Lieut-Gen Slim GOC in C 14 Army.   Gen C in C 11 Army Group.  Maj Gen Comd 20 Indian Div.   Lieut-Gen Comd IV Corps.   National Archive WO 373/35.

North West Europe.   Citation for MC:   This WO has been right through the North West European Campaign and has been RSM of the Highland Divisional Provost Company since the end of 1944.   He has had on innumerable occasions to assume the responsibilities of an officer and at all times his courage and determination have been of the highest order.   In the midst of the appalling conditions during the operations in the ARDENNES he showed the greatest skill and endurance in handling traffic problems and he personally carried out many of the forward reconnaissances of routes which were required, under frequent enemy fire and with complete disregard for mines hidden by snow.   On the occasion of the RHINE crossing he was responsible for lighting several of the routes from the assembly areas to the river bank.   Under heavy fire he carried this out personally, checking and re-checking that the work was done meticulously and in accordance with his previous reconnaissances.   He encountered an enemy patrol which speedily dispersed, and despite many hazards the task was completed on schedule.   Throughout the sustained pursuit battle which followed he worked unceasingly day and night in the forefront of the Division dealing with the many traffic problems and making routes for the forward troops.   This WO has given quite outstanding service in the campaign.   His personal bravery and determination are beyond praise and his devotion to duty is of the highest order.
OC 51 Div Pro Coy.   Maj-Gen Comd 51 (H) Div.   Lt-Gen B G Horrocks Comd 30 Corps.   National Archive WO 373/56.
Netherlands.

Citation for MID:  Capt Elsmore was a subaltern in the 1 Corps Pro Coy early in 1944 when he was specially selected to command 244 Beach Provost Company.   he was responsible for all its final training for the assault, and this he carried out with great success.   He led his Coy into the Beaches during the first tide on D Day, and it was largely his efficiency, energy, and example under fire and bombing which enabled them to carry out successfully their difficult and arduous Beach role.  In 
September 1944 he was again specially selected to command 51 (H) Div Pro Coy, and at once earned high praise for his energy and leadership in a series of operations, often working with forward troops and in responsible positions.   Finally, in April 1945, he was promoted DAPM 1 Corps, and has done a great deal of independent Provost Staff work with the same success that he achieved previously under operational conditions.
DPM 1 Corps District.   Lt-Gen Comd 1 Corps Dist.   National Archive WO 373/91 Pt.1.

Citation for US Bronze Star:   At start  of the counter-attack in the Ardennes, it became vital that a reliable Military Police officer should be sent to American Army as Liaison Officer, and Lt. Blenkharn was detached from 120 Pro Coy on the 17th December 1944.   From 17th December 1944 Blenkharn liaised with HQ 9th US Army until 25th December 1944 and from 26th December 1944 until completion of the offensive on 20th February 1945 he liaised with 1st US Army in the Advanced Zone of Communications.   During the period he was detached to US Army he did invaluable and untiring work during very involved operations tying up American and British troops.   More than this, from his previous large practical experience as RSM Guards Armd Division Provost Coy he was able to afford the Americans every material assistance which they were pleased to record when his attachment to them ceased.   Lt. Blenhard distinguished himself by this meritorious service.
Capt T Clark OC & DAPM 120 Pro Coy CMP.   Col W J Humphrey Comd GHQ Troops.

Citation for the CBE:  Brigadier Wieler has given unsparingly of effort to keep the Corps of Royal Military Police and Military Provost Staff Corps at a high pitch of efficiency.   He has had an uphill struggle against shortages both of officers and other ranks;  but, morale has not fallen and the standard has been maintained and this is due, in no small part, to Brigadier Wieler's enthusiasm and determination.   British Military Police have a world-wide reputation and have been accepted as a pattern by other countries.   Brigadier Wieler has worked and is still working at high pressure to maintain and if possible enhance that reputation.   He demands a high standard in every respect and is, in himself, an outstanding example to a Corps on which the Army is so dependant.   He is fully deserving of the award for which he is recommended.
Maj Gen Director of Personal Services.   National Archive WO 373/157.

Citation for Belgian Chevalier of the Order of Leopold II with Palm & Croix De Guerre 1940 with Palm:  In October 1944 during the course of operations to open the ports of GHENT and ANTWERP to Allied shipping 52nd (L) Division was committed to a two-pronged assault of the SCHELDT islands of WALCHEREN and BEVELAND.   One arm of this assault entailed sea crossings white the other was dependent solely on a single road axis of very limited capabilities.   The success of the operation may largely be attributed to sound planning, co-ordination and supervision of the very complex traffic problems involved.   Major WREN, as APM of the Division upon whom the satisfactory solution of the very complicated traffic problems so largely depended, was indefatigable in surmounting all difficulties.   his planning was sound and efficient;  he obtained the best results from his subordinates by the high standard of example which he set;  and he was constantly to be found in forward areas of considerable danger, personally supervising the avoidance and clearance of traffic bottlenecks.   As the battle progressed, Major WREN was faced with the further problem of dealing with the evacuation of large numbers of enemy prisoners of war amounting to a total of over ten thousand.   The presence of so many enemy prisoners of war in the forward areas might have proved of considerable embarrassment to the forward units had Major WREN not so efficiently organised their rapid evacuation despite the limited resources available.
Comd 52 (L) DivisionLieut-Gen G I Thomas Comd 1 Corps Dist.   National Archive WO 373/111/2 Bundle 1.

Italy/NW Europe.   Citation for MBE: Major ALEXANDER has been APM 5 British Infantry Division since March 1944.   Joining the Division in the ANZIO  Beachhead he soon showed that he had exceptional qualities and powers of organisation.   These powers he has used to the full throughout his service with the Division in ITALY and GERMANY and his efforts have time and again deserved the highest praise.   In the moves which the Division undertook from Italy, both in and out of action and until the final stages of the war in North West Europe when it crossed the River ELBE, Major ALEXANDER's superb traffic arrangements were invaluable.   By his personal endeavour and unflagging energy he was an example to the whole Divisional Provost Company and to all others with whom he came in contact.   In the maintenance of discipline as APM, Major ALEXANDER has been a tower of strength, and his traffic organisation has been a very material factor in the Division's success during its operations.
Maj-Gen R A Hull Comd 5 Brit Inf Div.   Lt-Gen Comd 8 Corps District.   London Gazette WO 373/86.
Recommended for OBE awarded MBE.
Italy.

Italy.   Citation for MBE:  Capt BENNETT has served with 56 London Div Pro Coy since 26 Feb 43.   The high standard of discipline and leadership set by Capt BENNETT is abundantly shown in the very efficient duties carried out by the Div Pro Coy both during active operations and during the extended approach movements preceding them.   Capt BENNETT is quite untiring and completely disregards his personal safety in his efforts to ensure that operational and maintenance routes are clearly marked and controlled right up to the rear of the forward troops.   The battles of CAMINO, GARIGLIANO, ANZIO and the recent operations in the GOTHIC Line have all presented great traffic difficulties.   These were smoothed out almost entirely by the continual reconnaissance and quick decisions of Capt BENNETT.   Such operations must be largely dependent on traffic organisation and in the Divisional sector the untiring efforts of Capt BENNETT were a major contribution to the successful results achieved.
Maj-Gen Comd 56th (London) Div.  Lt-Gen C F Keightley Comd 5 Corps.   National Archive WO 373/72

Italy.   Citation for the award of the US Bronze Star:   NEVILLE M. BLAIR, 52831, Lieutenant Colonel, Middlesex Regiment, British Royal Army, Deputy Provost Marshal, Headquarters Second District, Central Mediterranean Forces, for meritorious achivement in connection with military operations in Italy from 10 March 1944 to 10 January 1946.   As Deputy Provost Marshal at Bari and Foggia, Italy, Lieutenant Colonel Blair rendered invaluable service to the Fifteenth Air Force and the Adriatic Base Depot in cooperating with the American Provost Marshal Section in accomplishing the gigantic task of successfully directing traffic and furnishing security for troops and supplies sorely needed for the American Forces in that area.   He accomplished outstanding results in supervising traffic and police problems in Northern Italy.   The smoothness and effectiveness with which the combined British and American Provost Marshal Sections functioned reflect the efforts and willingness to cooperate on the part of Lieutenant Colonel Blair.   Entered service from London, England.

Italy.   Citation for MBE:  As Officer Commanding 77 Section Special Investigation Branch of the CMP, Captain DAWSON is responsible for all criminal inquiries throughout the Eighth Army.   For the period 1 Sept 31 Dec 44 and previously throughout the spring offensive in Italy from the Gustav Line onwards, this officer has conducted a very considerable number of highly intricate and involved investigations, bringing many of them finally to a successful conclusion.   His prowess as a criminal investigator in the field is outstanding, particularly in view of the difficult and often hazardous nature of the work and the almost complete lack of the normal scientific aids to police investigation.   On 10 Nov 44, FORLI fell to the Eighth Army and Captain DAWSON entered the town with a small detachment.   Information had been received that the enemy had committed atrocities on a large scale in the form of mass executions.   Although investigation of War Crimes is outside the normal scope of his duties, Captain DAWSON undertook immediate inquiries.   His work on FORLI airfield, carrious out with relentless tenacity under the most nauseating and appalling conditions made a great impression on the civilian population, to the general benefit of British Military Administration.   By his acumen, the application and thoughtful employment of his men, and above all by his own personal untiring example, he has not only brought a great number of military and civilian delinquents to justice, but has overcome the great administrative difficulties affecting his small unit that might well have nullified many of his Section's efforts.   The success that has attended the work of his men, has in a very large measure, been due to his own encouragment, leadership, wisdom and guidance.
Lt Col J R Archer-Burton OBE.   Brig DAQMG Eighth Army  Lieut Gen Eighth Army.   National Archive WO 373/73.

Indian Distinguished Service Medal Citation.
Italy 
The vital task of Indian police patrol on the Divisional maintenance track from CERVARO to CAIRO, and on the ambulance track from PORT LYA to HIGHWAY 6.   He had orders to take particulars of vehicles knocked out by shell-fire, to assist drivers pass shelled areas and to police ambulances so that priority against the various traffic circuits would get wounded men back to the M.D.S. in quick time.   He preferred to tackle the job alone in his Jeep and for two days and nights, his untiring efforts and personal energy under constant enemy shell-fire, and in appalling weather conditions, undoubtedly assisted the forward movement of food and ammunition, and rearward movement of wounded soldiers from the line.
On the 7th February, during this patrol, a Jeep was knocked out by a shell about fifty yards in front of him near VILLA, and whilst on the way to give assistance to the British soldiers in the blazing Jeep, was himself seriously wounded.
Havildar Sher Khan, although twice wounded in battles of the Western Desert showed a complete disregard for his personal safety, and was an inspiration to the Indian soldiers of the unit who regard him as a worthy battle veteran.
Awarded an immediate IDSM.
Recommended by APM 4 Indian Div Maj Cook And Lt Gen B. G Reyerg GOC NZ Corps.   National Archive WO 373/6.	
This was the only IDSM won by CMP (India).

Italy.   Citation for MBE:   This officer was posted by me  on 20 Nov 43 to be responsible for the road from TORINO M.R.445985 (sheet 108-iv 1/50,000 ITALY) to South Bank of River SANGRO M.R. 402971.   His duty was to ensure the forward flow of traffic, which could only move under cover of darkness, in preparation for the assault crossing of the R. Sangro.   Lieut. Rowe with 2 secs of 101 Pro Coy under command, carried out all duties with outstanding efficiency from 20 Nov until 3 Dec 43 when relieved.   During first four days of this period Lt. Rowe was constantly on duty on roads which were being shelled by enemy artillery.   Vehicles hit and set on fire on one occasion, were cleared under supervision of this officer.   As a result of his continual alertness, all traffic was given necessary protection from enemy observation on the forward slopes approaching SANGRO River, thereby saving life and valuable equiment from certain destruction by enemy fire.   At all times Lt. Rowe was outstanding in courage and initiative, under the most difficult circumstances, and his work was a material contributory factor to the success of crossing the SANGRO River.   Since being relieved  of above duties Lt. Rowe has been in charge of PROVOST, LANCIANO, M.R. Sq 320-3.   In this busy town during advance, this officer has been an example to all ranks, and his efficiency, cheerfulness and devotion to duty are beyond all praise.
Recommended for a periodical MC, awarded MBE.
Lt Col APM 5 Corps.   Brigadier DA & QMG 5 Corps.   Lt General Comd 5 Corps.   National Archive WO 373/71 pt.3.

Italy.  Citation for Bronze Star Medal:  RICHARD CHARLES LOUIS LIMBERT, 291650, Captain, General List, British Army, for meritorious achievement in connection with military operations against the enemy in Italy from February to December 1944.   Captain Limbert, as an experienced police officer, was placed in charge of the evacuation, care and organization of the masses of refugees pouring through communes newly liberated by the United States Fifth Army.   First at Sessa Arunea, where he cared for 7,000 refugees in the refugee centre established there, and later at Venafro, Captain Limbert set up and supervised a chain of refugee posts which served to clear strategic highways and road networks of refugee traffic.   His cool courage in the face of danger several times acted to prevent serious disturbances among the distraught civilians, as in the case of the bombing of Venafro, where Captain Limbert assisted in calming 300 panic stricken refugees.   Refugee centres also were set up at Ausonia, Lenola, Vetralla, Ponsacco and other small towns.   Following the liberation of Florence, Captain Limbert opened a refugee centre, the largest attempted on the Italian mainland, where 16,000 refugees were cared for.   Processing as many as 4,900 refugees a day, Captain Limbert opened a hospital to care for the sick, a school for the children and a nursery for babies, as well as a dis-infector, shower bath, club room, theatre, and other facilities to solve rehabilitation and occupation problems of the refugees.   His outstanding services are in keeping with the highest traditions of the military service and reflect great credit upon himself and the Allied Nations.
National Archive WO 373/148.
Middle East.
Cancelled in LG 40023 page 6369, 20/11/1953

Italy.   Citation for MBE:  Since the capture of ANCONA and during the subsequent build up for Eighth Army operations, throughout very bad winter conditions, the traffic problems have made heavy demands on Provost.   And in this area where troops from all parts of the British Empire and Allied Nations are operating to maintain good discipline, with good feeling and a strict check on sabotage and pilfering in the Port and Depots, have called for unremitting energy day and night on the part of the APM.   This officer has never spared himself and has set a splendid example to all.   On several occasions when carrying out raids against armed bandits, he has shown great courage and resourcefulness.
Brig Fullbrook-Leggatt Comd 61 Area.  Maj-Gen Heydeman Comd No1 District CMP.   National Archive WO 373/73.

Acts of Courage Extracted From The Corps Order books.
P/2174 LANCE CORPORAL F AITKEN
MILITARY FOOT POLICE ROUEN
Corps Order Book No22 Page 116
Extract from Base Routine Orders, Rouen, dated 15/5/17
No2508 Acts of Courage.   At Rouen on the 9 May 1917, a pair of run away dray horses were galloping down the road from the camps.   As they approached him, No P/2174 L/Cpl Aitken F, MFP sprang forward and seized the bridle of one of the horses, being carried along for a distance of about 200 yards.   The Base Commander desires to express his appreciation of the pluck and endeavour of the above named NCO shown in this instance.   A record of the above will be made in the Regimental Conduct Sheet of L/Cpl Aitken in accordance with KR para 1919 (XIV).

MFP.   Act of Courage Extracted from Corps Order Book.
P/1419 LANCE CORPORAL R ARMSTRONG
MILITARY FOOT POLICE
Corps Order Book 21 Page 7
The following is a certified true extract from Routine Orders of Lieutenant General JJ Asser, CB, Commanding Lines of Communications area, dated 26/12/16 re P/1419 A/Cpl R Armstrong.
The General Officer Commanding Lines of Communication area, wishes to express his appreciation of the prompt and plucky conduct of P/1719 Lance Corporal R Armstrong, Military Foot Police, at the Advanced Base, on the 12th December 1916.
No138744 Pioneer A Booth and No138718 Pioneer J Parsley, 271 Railway Company RE, slipped over the steep bank and fell into the canal after dark.   They were in immediate danger of drowning when their calls attracted the attention of Lance Corporal Armstrong who, divesting himself of only great-coat and revolver, plunged into the canal, and succeeded in saving both men.
A record of the above will be made in the Regimental Conduct Sheet of this NCO, in accordance with Para 1919 (XIV) King's Regulations.
Signed Charles Wood
Lt Col AAG.

Acts of Courage Extracted From The Corps Order Books.
P/1117 ACTING CORPORAL F PRIDHAM
P/1475 LANCE CORPORAL C BAILEY
MILITARY FOOT POLICE
Corps Order Book 22 Page 116, 24/8/17.

Extract from IX Corps Routine Orders by Lt General A. Hamilton Gordon CB, Commanding IX Corps, dated 3/7/17
CRO No 214 Gallant Conduct.   The Corps Commander wishes to express his appreciation of the gallant conduct of No P/1117 A/Cpl Pridham F, and No P/1475 L/Cpl Bailey C, MFP, under the following circumstances:-   On the 19 June 1917 a fire broke out at Schaexkei.   Cpl Pridham and L/Cpl Bailey un-daunted by the fire managed to remove a major portion of the contents, and subsequently exerted every effort to put out the fire, Cpl Pridham remaining inside the building until the beams began to fall.   He then mounted a ladder and assisted by L/Cpl Bailey poured buckets of water on the burning roof.   During this time L/Cpl Bailey was badly cut on the head by a falling tile.   The fire was undoubtedly prevented from spreading to the neighbouring buildings, owing to the resource and energy of these two NCO's.   An entry of this action will be made in the Conduct Sheets of these NCO's in accordance with KR para 1919 (XIV).
Signed H de C Marlelli Lt Col
For DA & QMG 9th Corps.

MFP.  Rouen.    Acts of Courage Extracted From the Corps Order Books.
P/3559 LANCE CORPORAL G FOX
MILITARY FOOT POLICE
Corps Order Book 22 Page 116
Extracted from Routine Orders by Brigadier General C L McNab Base Commandant Rouen, on 23 June 1917.
No2636 Act of Courage.   The Base Commandant desires to express his appreciation of the plucky conduct of No P/3559 L/Cpl Fox MFP, who on 31 May 1917, when a pair of mules had bolted with a wagon and were  galloping down the Rue Elboeuf, ran out, seized the bridle of one of the mules and after being dragged along for about 40 yards succeeded in stopping the mules and then rescued the driver who had been thrown on the load pole.   A record of the above will be made in the Regimental Conduct Sheet of L/Cpl Fox in accordance with KR para 1919 (XIV).   HQ Rouen Base No J7008/6.-   Died France & Flanders buried St. Sever Cemetery, Rouen.

Extract from Fifth Army Routine Orders dated 16/8/1917. 1352 Gallant Conduct.   The Army Commander wishes to express his appreciation of the following act of courage on the part of No. 6055 L/Cpl Park, MFP, Traffic Control, under the following circumstances:
At about noon on the 30th July 1917, whilst on duty at Lille Gate, Ypres, L/Cpl Park observed a team of five horses attached to an ammunition limber, bolting towards his post.   There were no drivers with the team.   He immediately ran out and with considerable difficulty succeeded in bringing the horses to a standstill.   The presence of mind and courage displayed by L/Cpl Park undoubtedly avoided a serious accident from occurring in the town, towards which the horses were bolting.   A record of the above will be made on the Regimental Conduct Sheet of L/cpl Park in accordance with King's Regulations para 1919 (xiv).

Corps Order Book No 23 Page 173
Extract from Routine Orders by General Hon J G Byng KCB Commanding 3rd Army dated 1st October 1917.
1127 Act of Courage.   The Army Commander wishes to express his appreciation of the following act of courage on the part of No P/2013 L/Cpl H Breese, MFP.   On the 16/9/17 a horse, ridden by an officer, ran away in the Rue St Aubert, Arras.   The officer was unable to release his left foot from the stirrup and was being dragged along the ground.   L/Cpl Breese, with great courage and presence of mind, dashed forward and caught hold of the reins of the runaway, and brought it to a standstill after being dragged some distance.   The plucky action of L/Cpl Breese undoubtedly saved the officer's life.   A record of the above will be made.

Acts of Courage Extracted From the Corps Order Books.
656 ACTING SERGEANT F G ANDREWS	
MILITARY MOUNTED POLICE
Mentioned by Lt General Sir John Monash, KCB. VO in Australian Corps Routine Orders No. 44 dated 30/8/18 for:-   On August 14th 1918 a dump of  gun ammunition caught fire, this NCO with great presence of mind and gallantry removed the camouflage and put out the fire, though not before two of the cartridges had exploded.   His gallant act was the means of  saving considerable quantities of ammunition and possible casualties.
He was awarded the Military Medal for this act.

Acts of Courage Extracted From The Corps Order Books.
P/9207 LANCE CORPORAL C WHITEHURST
2 TRAFFIC CONTROL COMPANY 
MILITARY FOOT POLICE
Extract from 4th Army Routine Orders 2457 dated 2/9/18.   The Army Commander wishes to express his appreciation of the following act of courage:-
On the 21st August 1918 a pair of mules, harnessed to a GS wagon took fright and bolted without their driver;   No P/9207 L/Cpl Whitehurst of No2 Traffic Control Company, who was on duty at a cross roads, saw them approaching and running towards them, succeeded in clinging to the reins of the near mule.   Although dragged for about 100 yards, he brought the mules to a standstill just before they reached the cross-roads, where a continuous stream of traffic was passing at the time.   By his prompt and courageous action he undoubtedly prevented a serious accident.
A record of the above will be made in the Regimental Conduct Sheet of L/Cpl Whitehurst, in accordance with KR's para 1919 (XIV)  Authority:- OC No2 Traffic Control Company dated 17/9/18   (AFO 1810 BEF, MFP, No 42 dated 21/9/18).

MMP.  
Acts of Courage Extracted From The Corps Order Books.
472 ACTING/SQUADRON SERGEANT MAJOR M W HEALEY
MILITARY MOUNTED POLICE
Extract from V Corps Routine Orders dated 13/2/18.
The Corps Commander wishes to express his appreciation of the following act of courage on the part of No. P/472 A/SSM M W Healey, MMP.
On the morning of the 10th inst, a pair of horses attached to a wagon bolted down the road.   A NCO made an attempt to stop them but failed, A/SSM Healy with great promptitude and at much personal risk dashed in and seized the reins of the near horse and hung on until he had brought the runaways to a standstill.   The road was used by a considerable amount of traffic and the prompt action of this Warrant Officer averted what might have led to a  serious accident and damage to a pair of Government horses and the limber.   A record of the above will be made in the Regimental Conduct Sheet of this Warrant Officer in accordance with para 1919 (XIV) of King's Regulations.

Acts of Courage Extracted From the Corps Order Books.
P/1680 LANCE CORPORAL G COLLIER 
MILITARY FOOT POLICE
Extract from Army Routine Order No; 1539 dated 27/9/17.   The Army Commander wishes to express his appreciation of the following Act of Courage on the part of P/1680 L/Cpl Collier G MFP, under the following circumstances:-   At about 12.10pm on the 19th Sept 1917, this NCO was returning from duty in a certain town, when he saw a team of six horses attached to a limber wagon , galloping in his direction.   These horses were bolting and there were no drivers with them.   L/Cpl Collier, after getting traffic clear, with considerable presence of mind and courage, seized the bridle of one of the leaders and brought it down.   Owing to the speed at which they were going, two of the other horses also came down.   L/Cpl Collier then extricated the horses from the harness and handed the team over to the drivers who came up shortly afterwards.   By this NCO's courageous act a serious accident was undoubtedly averted.   Entered in accordance with KR's para 1919 (XVI).   (Extracted from AFB 122 of P/1680 L/Cpl Collier G. MFP).

MFP.   Acts of Courage Extracted From Corps Order Book 21, page 77, 5/9/16.
LANCE CORPORAL J CANNON
3 OX & BUCKS LIGHT INFANTRY
ATTACHED MILITARY FOOT POLICE
The following act of gallantry is reported:   On August 15th 1916 whilst on duty near the Rue de L'Union L/Cpl J Cannon, 3rd Oxford & Bucks Light Infantry attached as Military Foot Police, endeavoured to stop a runaway horse which was travelling at great speed.   The NCO was thrown to the ground, dragged a considerable distance and succeeded in bringing the horse practically to a standstill.   But for the NCO's prompt action, a serious accident would probably have occurred.
The Commandant GHQ Troops congratulates
 L/cpl Cannon on his courage and initiative.
(Extract from GHQ Troops Orders No576 Dated 25-8-16 by Colonel A B Dasterville CMG - Commandant GHQ Troops.)

P/2461 L/Cpl E Hulley MMP.   The under mentioned extract from Alexandria District Orders No 300 dated 1st Oct 1916, issued by Brig Gen R C Boyle CB Comdg Troops Alexandria District (Egypt), is published in accordance with Para 1919 (XII) KR.
The GOC Alexandria District has pleasure in recording his appreciation of the gallant conduct of P/2461 L/Cpl E Hulley MMP under the following circumstance:   At Chatby Alexandria on the 29th Sept 1916 P/2461 L/Cpl E Hulley MMP swam out to sea to a man in difficulties and succeeded and assisted in successfully bringing him safely to shore.   Owing to the heavy swell at the time the man would probably have been drowned but for the action of the above mentioned NCO and several others.
The GOC Alexandria District directs that the above be recorded as laid down in para 1919 (XIV) Kings Regulations in the regimental conduct sheets of the NCO's and men concerned.

Territorial Army.   Queen's Birthday Award.   Captain Gordon Sydney Pearson Stead (444350) Corps of Royal Military Police, 42 Div/Dist. Pro Coy, RMP. Territorial Army.
Citation:   Captain STEAD joined the Army in 1936 and his outstanding ability and devotion to duty quickly earned him promotion.   He transferred to the CMP in 1938.   He later saw active service in both World War II and KOREA when his personal example and leadership was of the highest order.
     In 1958 he became the PSO fo 42 Division Provost Company since when his high standards of devotion to duty have been reflected in every activity of the unit.
     He is a tremendously popular man yet one to be feared by the idle and incompetent.   He is intensely loyal to his unit and its members and never spares himself in his efforts on their behalf.   Indeed his devotion to duty and reliability far exceed that which is required or expected of him by regulations, and he and the unit he serves have become a byword throughout the 42nd Division.
     He identifies himself very closely with the units in the Division and District and plays a most important part in coordinating their Provost arrangements.
     Without doubt Captain STEAD is an outstanding example to inspiration to all who work with him and know him.   His long and devoted service well merits recognition and I strongly recommend that he be awarded the MBE.
Reccomended by: Lt/Col. PRH Turner, AA & QMG 42 (Lancashire) Div/District TA.   GOC Western Command.
t
Nigeria, on load to the Government of the Federation of Nigeria.
New Year Honour.  Berlin Airlift.

United Kingdom.   Citation for BEM:  CQMS Stewart joined this unit on 3rd May 1948 and has been unfailing in his attendance both at Camps and normal bi-weekly drills since this date.   This unit does not carry a regular CQMS on the staff and therefore the Administration from the "Q" point of view would be extremely difficult if I was not fortunate in having the services of CQMS Stewart at my disposal.   He puts in long hours in excess of normal drills in order to keep abreast of the growing volume of work in his department caused by a steady increase of volunteers over the years and a proportionate greater increase of late months due to the arrival of National Service Men.   At the Annual and Week-end Camps he has attended (and he has never missed one yet) I can count on his deparment functioning perfectly.   The "Q" side of any unit is perhaps the least glamourous and provided much routine work of an uninteresting nature but unless this be done satisfactorily and indeed with enthusiasm the unit will never be an efficient one.   CQMS Stewart is utterly reialble and his keeness is a byword in the unit.   I therefore have much pleasure in recommending him for the award of the BEM and trust that most urgent and sympathetic consideration be given to this recommendation.
Maj RAW Whitby OC 56 Armd Div Pro Coy.   Maj-Gen H E Pyman GOC 56 (Lon) Armd Div.   Gen GWRTempler GOC in C Eastern Command, Hounslow.   National Archive WO 373/179.

Italy.   Citation for MID:  This officer was serving with 115 Provost Company on the date of the initial landing of 10 Corps at SALERNO, and remained with that unit during all the actions in the field until 3 Jan 44.   During this period his work was of the highest order which was inspired by his intense devotion to duty.   He was appointed DAPM, HQ 3 District on 23 Oct 44.   His appointment coincided with a considerable increase in administrative responsibilities of the Provost branch, the burden of which additional duties was borne by him.   The high degree of enthusiasm, zeal and efficiency which he displayed was much more than might be expected from him in the normal course of his duty.   Largely as a result of his efforts it was possible to surmount the most difficult obstacles, many of them of a delicate nature, and thus avoid any hitch in administrative machinery during what may be considered a very difficult period..
Recommended for MBE, awarded MID.
Lt Col Mc Nally DPM 3 District.   Maj Gen Comd 3 District.   National Archive WO 373/909 Pt.3.

Italy.   Citation for MBE:  For outstanding ability and devotion to duty.   This officer took over command of the company in February 1945, having previously been 2 I/c.   At all times he has kept the men under his command at the highest pitch of efficiency, by his energy, enthusiasm and example.   During the move from the mountains to the Po Valley and again from the Senio River to Trieste, it was due to his untiring work and efficient organisation that a smooth flow of traffic was ensured and that the moves were completed quickly and with complete success.   His untiring energy, cheerfulness and devotion to duty has been an inspiration to the success of the provost work at all times.

Burma.   Citation for BEM:  During the period under review, 16 May to 15 Aug, this NCO has carried out the duties of AFRICAN CSM to the Divisional Provost Coy:   During this period the Provost Coy; has been fully employed on policing and controlling the moves of the Division and maintaining good relationship with the civilians.   By this NCO's personal example and leadership he has gained the respect and confidence of all ranks and was largely responsible in maintaining a high level of morale which has enabled this company to carry out its many tasks.   Throughtout the operations in the KABAW VALLEY this NCO showed initiative and devotion to duty which encouraged all AFRICAN ranks to carry out their many duties under trying circumstances.   
Maj WG Atkin  APM 11 (EA) Div.   Maj Gen W a Dimoline Comd 11 (EA) Div.   C in C Allied Land Forces SEA.   National Archive WO 373/82.

Italy.   MBE citation:   This Officer assumed command of the CMP Depot & TE (Training Establishment). At OTTAVIANO in March 1944, shortly after the Unit's arrival from NORTH AFRICA.   The training capacity of this Unit was then 120 and the accommodation available both dilapidated and inadequate.   By his personal enthusiasm and initiative and in the face of very considerable administrative difficulties Major PRICE has now produced a first class Establishment with a present feeding strength of 1,000.   This is the only permanent Police School in CMF and trains British, Canadian, South African, Indian, Polish and Italian Military Police in all branches of Police work including Criminal Investigation, and has dealt with approximately 2,664 students and probationers in the last 12 months.   The machinery to deal with such a number of students and to produce such a high standard of training is entirely due to the outstanding efforts of the Commandant and is largely responsible for the high standard of efficiency of CMP personnel in the Theatre and for the excellent spirit of co-operation and friendship which exists between UK, Dominion and Allied Police.   Col. Provost Marshall AFHQ. A. D. Ward Maj-Gen A/C of S, AFHQ.   National Archive WO 373/73.

BEF.   This officer arranged and established, with a small organization of men of the A.M.P.C., the main traffic control post at LANDIVISEAU for the forward advance of the Canadian Division from Brest and the subsequent evacuation.   This was no easy task and if it had not been efficiently organized and supervised the main road would have been hopelessly blocked and the evacuation of personnel could not have been carried out successfully.   His tactful and untiring effort both with the French civilians and the troops in transit, made a success of this part of the evacuation.
Brigadier G Rasch, Commanding Rennes Sub Area.

Italy.   General List CMP.   From Sandiacre.   66 Section SIB.  MBE Citation:   During the period Oct 44 to Feb 45 armed highway and other violent robberies affecting Allied interests and attributable to gangs of deserters and civilian desperadoes were rife in Southern Italy.   These gangs, highly organised along professional lines, terrorised the civilian population in many areas.   They were well armed, equipped with a variety of stolen transport and in addition had the advantage of a good local intelligence system.  Lt. FINNEY with the squad under his command were instrumental in breaking up and arresting these gangs finally resulting in the virtual disappearance for this type of crime.  This success entailed unremitting hard work, detailed investigation and the exercise of initiative and considerable daring.   He performed very dangerous duties in arresting many criminals whose usual mode of resistance was small arms fire at close quarters.   Lt FINNEY'S leadership on the occasions when these armed men were brought to justice during this period showed outstanding gallantry and conspicuous devotion to duty.   Lt Col H V McNally DPM 3 District.   Maj Gen Commander 3 District.

France,Belgium.   Citation for the Belgian Order of Leopold II with Palm and Croix de Guerre 1940 with Palm.  Major (then Capt) Stirling landed in Normandy on D + 3 in command of 16 Coy CMP (TC).   He was responsible for much of the early organisation of the very heavy TC in the Second Army railhead area round BAYEUX.   Working with the minimum of police he was very successful in producing better order out of the terrific congestion resultant on the early operational phase.   As the battle moved on, his area of responsibility and the police under his command increased until he was controlling traffic over 2,400 sq miles of Normandy, including the vital roots of the L of C tree.   Though his work was mainly TC, much Provost work, anti-looting etc, also came his way and was most faithfully perfomed, both then and later in Belgium.   At the end of 1944 Capt Stirling was transferred to TOURNAI in Belgium, and he remained there for four months, controlling L of C traffic and the incoming Divisions from Italy in a large area of Belgium.   From there he went th GHENT for a month on the same type of work.   In both cases a great deal of organising and putting existing improvisations onto a permenant footing was required, and this was achieved with marked success.   During the ten months he worked in France and Belgium, Capt Stirling's work was not spectacular but was very heavy and of great value;  always performed and carried out with perseverance and devotion to duty, and crowned with real success.
LIEUT Col DMP 1 Corps District.   Lt Gen G I Thomas Comd 1 Corps District.   Nationa Archive 373/111/2 Bundle 1.

BEM Citation:   On the 5th July, 1943, a fire broke out in a petrol truck on a railway siding about 50 yards from a Military Prison and Detention Barracks.
    Sgt Rickards and Kirby after assisting the Regimental Sergeant Major to clear the prison of all its occupants, rushed to the railway station to offer what help they could.   They noticed attached to the blazing petrol truck, other trucks loaded with petrol, bombs and small arms ammunition.   Sergeants Rickards and Kirby with the assistance of an American lorry driver uncoupled these trucks and pushed the further down the siding out of danger.   Their actions with no regard to personal safety, greatly reduced the damage and averted what might have been a major disaster.   WO 373/68 Pt.1, Sheet 11

MPSC.   North West Europe.
Citation:  Regimental Sergeant Major Davies has been with No.3 Military Prison and Detention Barracks since August 1944.   During the period 1 Feb 45 to 30 Apr, 45 he has been an example to both the staff and soldiers under sentence by his outstanding and ceaseless devotion to duty.
     His inspiration, advice, help and guidance to many of those men who found themselves for the first time in detention, has been the means of their earning suspended sentence and taking their places again in operational units.
Recommended by: Commandant No.3 MP & DP,  Brigadier, Commander 17 L of C Sub Area, Maj Gen Commander L of C.

MPSC.   North West Europe.
Citation: WOI (RSM) DAVIES, has been with No 3 Military Prison & Detention Barracks since August 1944.
During the whole of this period he has earned and unfailingly held, the loyalty and support of the Unit Staff by his personal example of rigid discipline coupled with scrupulous fairness shown at all times.   Moreover, the qualities of RSM Davies were also acknowledged by the majority of the soldiers under sentence who respected rather than feared him.   His advice and guidance given, particularly to many men who found themselves in Detention for the first time in their Army careers, and his ability to differentiate between various types and characters has contributed in a very large measure towards the soldiers under sentence, earning a suspension of Sentence in the shortest possible time and his consequent rehabilitation to a more usefull role in operational and service Units.
This valuable service has resulted from RSM Davies' unflagging zeal and outstanding devotion to duty.  
Recommended by Commandant, No.3 MP/DB, Brigadier R H R Parminter Commander 11 L of C Area, Maj Gen G Surtees, Commander L of C.
