Awarded as 14337552 Cpl Roy William Thomas Love, 7 Somerset Light Infantry.   North West Europe.
Citation:   7 Somerset Light Infantry, 43 Wessex Division, 30 Corps.
     On 9 Aug 44, in the attack on Hau AU RoI 8342, Cpl. LOVE's section was leading his platoon when the Coy came under heavy machine gun fire.   The Platoon Comd. was wounded.   Cpl LOVE attended to his wounds, arranged for fire support from a tank and the led his section up a hedge row in which the enemy were.   Throughout he showed marked coolness and daring and contributed in no small way to the elimination of the enemy.
Recommended by: Lt/Col. J W Nicol CO 7 Somerset Light Infantry.   Brig. 214 Inf Bde, Maj/Gen 43 Div, Lt/Gen. 30 Corps.

Burma.   Maj (temporary) Carly Howard Palmer (71396) Royal Regiment of Artillery (Crowborough), 94/95 Field Battery, 18 Field Regiment, RA.
Citation:   This officer has commanded 94/95 Fd. Bty, RA with outstanding ability and dash throughout the campaign from Dec. 44 to May 45.
     At all times he has shown a complete disregard for his own safety, and his cheerfulness and devotion to duty have been an inspiration to the whole regiment.
     On many occasions he has shot his guns with great effect under shell and small arms fire at almost point blank range.
     At KIME on 27 March when one of his Troop Command Tanks was hit and all the crew wounded he went forward on foot and saw to their safe removal, under small army and A/Tk. fire.   He finally drove the damaged tank back himself to a position under cover in spite of a fire in the turrett, which was causing the amm. to explode.
     He commanded the Regt. during the Irrawaddy crossings of 20 Ind. and 2 Div. in my absence as CCRA's rep.   When the position was heavily shelled on the night of 15 Feb he set a high standard under very difficult conditions showing an example to steadiness in circumstances which necessitated the greatest  care and accuracy owing to the close proximity of our own troops to DF SOS.
Recommended by: Brig. C Goulder, CCRA, 4 Corps,  Maj/Gen IV Corps.

New Year Honours.   Lt/Col (Temporary) Carly Howard Palmer, MC. (71396), School of Artillery, Royal Regiment of Artillery.
Citation:  I personally visited the team at Fort Bliss in Sep 1956 and saw the Corporal fired by the British Team.
There is no doubt whatever in my mind that the high morale, the excellence of their state of training and the high regard the US Army held for the British team, which was told me by General Gavin when I visited the Pentagon, was a direct result of Lt Col Palmer's personal leadership.
I strongly recommend this officer for the award of the OBE.
Recommended by: Brig. Commandant, School of Artillery, Col. J P MacD Haslam, Chief Instructor in Guided Weapons, School of Artillery, Maj. Gen Director of Artillery, War Office.

Citation.   6398237 WO I Herbert Burden.  31/8/1955 to date.
     WO I Burden has been RSM at the Depot and Training Establishment, Royal Military Police, since 31st August, 1955.   He is in every way the most excellent RSM and carries out his duties in the highest traditions of the British Army.
     His loyalty and devotion to the Army, the Corps and to this Depot always come before his own interests.   He is respected and held in high esteem by officers and men alike, throughout the Corps.   He is a strict disciplinarian but a very fair one.   He is particularly good in his dealings with young soldiers, many of whom have benefited from his advice and experience.   Similarly his advice has helped many warrant officers and sergeants.   His bearing, turn out, conduct and devotion to duty are an outstanding example to all ranks.
     He runs a first class Sgts' Mess in which he has made many improvements and has helped to foster and excellent spirit.   In the same way his management, as president of the Corporals' Club, had produced very fine results.   His liaison with WOs and Sgts of other units is very good and does much to foster good relations between the military police and the rest of the army.
     He is an active committee member of the Depot branch of the RMP Association and as such puts in a lot of extra work.   As a result the branch is very successful and popular and a record number of new members have joined since RSM Burden's arrival.   As a member of the RMP Association committee itself and of the RMP Central benevolent fund his advice and comments are sound and shrewd.
     His enthusiastic support for all unit sporting activities has permeated to all ranks.   His is particularly good as a MC on military boxing occasions.
     In the example he sets, in zeal, enthusiasm and devotion to duty and in the way he conducts himself, this Warrant Officer has bar exceeded the standard normally expected of a regimental sergeant major.
Recommended by: Lt Col D V W Wakely, MC. RMP.  Commandant D & T E,RMP.   Brig R H L Oulton, PM War Officer & Maj Gen C E A Firth Director of Personnel.
Queen's Birthday Honours.   23244240 Sergeant Richard Herbert Poole, RMP.

Awarded MBE as a WOI .   Citation:  During more than eight months in Northern Ireland, Regimental Sergeant-Major Poole set a splendid example to soldiers, police and civilians alike.   On 27th June 1970, he exposed himself to great danger in a clash between rival factions which resulted in the death of several persons.   Unarmed and unprotected except by a steel helmet, which was dented during the action, he made several arrests and assisted in others.
On 28th September 1970, during serious rioting, he saw a vicious crowd attacking two Royal Marines.   One Marine had been kicked and beaten unconscious; the other had his back to a wall fighting to retain his rifle.   Though he risked being shot if they obtained the rifle, RSM Poole ran alone into the mob, dragged them off the Marine with the rifle and, standing astride the unconscious man, held off the attackers with his pistol until help arrived.   There is no doubt that he saved the men from grave injury.
Throughout the period he exerted a steadying effect wherever he appeared and by his bold and courageous action averted clashes on numerous occasions.
 Number shown as 2324440 in MBE.    Later Capt and Maj.   Officer No 488703.

Captain Peter Stock (408049), The Queens's Own Royal West Kent Regiment,   Seconded to the 2 Malay Regiment. Perak as Adjutant.   Jan 51 - Dec 57.
Citation:  Captain Stock has been on active operations against the Communist Terrorist Organisation in Malay since January 1951.   During this period he has served as Intelligence Officer, Company Second-in-Command and, for the last two years, as Adjutant in the 2nd Battalion The Malay Regiment.   In all those appointments he has shown the same tireless enthusiasm and devotion to duty no matter what problems or difficulties he has had to face.   In a Battalion that is continuously deployed on operations over a wide ared, with the Command Post seldom less than one hundred miles from the main battalion base, he has had to assume responsibilities far above his rank and normal course of duty.   He has cheerfully and enthusiastically accepted those responsibilities and carried out every task in such an exemplary manner that the Battalion has received un-stinted praise from every formation, unit and individual with whom he has had to deal.
     He works tirelessly and for long hours be it for the Battalion, the Garrison, School Cadets, the Volunteer Forces or any other unit or organisation but he still makes time to visit the troops on operations and play a leading part in the operational activities of the Battalion.   His devotion to duty is quite outstanding and beyond all praise.   Due to his tireless efficiency, organisation and control of the main Base he has relieved the Command Post of a great admin load which enables the maximum concentrated effort to be made against Communist Terrorist Organisations in the field, safe in the knowledge that every demand on the main base will be promptly and efficiently at any hour of the day or night.
Recommended by: CO 2 Malay Regiment, Brig. Ipoh, Maj/Gen. GOC Far East Land Forces.
The above can be found in WO 373/135/3 and WO 373/135/219.

Citation.   Malaya.
Lt Peter Hugh Surtees (440174), The Royal Lincolnshire Regiment.  On the 8th May, Lieutenant Surtees set out with his platoon to lay an ambush in the area to the south-west of Penang.   Early on the following morning, after a long and arduous approach march through mountainous country he located a small camp on the side of a steep hill in which he saw that there were five terrorists.   His approach to the camp  was over the mountain behind it enabled the platoon to avoid the terrorists' sentry but Lieutenant Surtees could see that the communist  terrorists were making preparations to leave.   He rapidly made his plan, placing two sections on the flank of the camp an prepared to assault with the remainder.   The re-allocation of weapons and the preliminary moves were skilfully carried out in complete silene   Although the terrorists had a dog with them, they were not alterted.
     Lieutenant Surtees led the assault on the camp with complete disregard for his own safety.   His gallantry and  determination were and inspiration to his men.   The assault was successfully pressed home with the result that one terrorist was killed and two others wounded and captured.   Thus a severe bow was dealt to the terrorist organisation in this part of Negri Sembilan.
     The complete success of this operation, skilfully out over difficult mountainous country was mainly due to the resourcefulness and inspiring leadership of Lieutenant Surtees.

New Year Honours.   Captain (Acting Major) Michael James Hyslop. TD. (479544).   Royal Regiment of Fusiliers.   Awarded whilst employed as GS0 2 TAVR Training HQ North East District, York.   July 75 to date.
Citation:   Major Hyslop, a Volunteer Officer, has served as GS)" (TAVR) Trg at HQ North East District for the past three years.
     A newly promoted Major with no previous staff experience he early on impressed with this keenness and enthusiasm for the job.   This in strict terms entailed co-ordination of, and advice on, TAVR trg with the Regular G Trg Staff and filling appointments on exercises.   With an enormous capacity for work and his great dedication he quickly assumed greater and greater responsibilities.   not content with waiting for staff tasks he has been instrumental in starting many new projects for TAVE trg.   Notably among these he personally organised and ran a comprehensive series of weekend coursed for the TAVR covering a variety of subjects not covered by Army courses for the TAVR covering a variety of subjects not covered by Army Schools and difficult to teach in units.   This entailed much forward planning and liaison with regular establishments for instructors and equipment.   In the last year these courses catered for over six hundred students.   In addition he organised and ran two highly successful helicopter training weekends each catering for over five hundred men from a variety of units.
     This successful work demanded a great deal of effort and expertise far beyond what one would normally expect from an officer of his military experience and age.   it has greatly lightened the workload on a busy G Trg staff and indeed without his endeavours and driving force much of what he has achieved might not have taken place.
     In addition to this he assists in the organisation and running of District major training events and exercises all of which demand a great deal of extra time and effort.
     This is from a Volunteer Officer, newly promoted to a responsible job with the Tees and Hartlepool Port Authority, entirely in his spare time.   He has devoted upwards of one hundred training days to this service  in the past year.
     His tremendous enthusiasm, great organising ability and sheer hard work has made his name a byword and an inspiration throughout the District and his conduct and zeal are in the highest traditions of the volunteer spirit.
Recommended by:Lt. Col. GSO1 Trg. HQ North East District.   Maj. Gen. GOC North East District.   Gen. C in C UKLF.

Queens Birthday Honours.  24041150 Staff Sergeant (now Warrant Officer Class 2) John Hendry O'Brien Collins Dougall.  SIB/RMP Belize.   July - Nov 1983.
Citation:   Since July 1983 Staff Sergeant Dougall has been the sole representative of the Special Investigation Branch in Belize.   he has been responsible for the investigation of all crimes and serious incidents within British Forces Belize.   In carrying out his duties he has been faced with unusual difficulties.   Belize is an operational theatre in which British Forces are dispersed over wide areas of inhospitable terrain with very poor communications.   The climate is oppressive and working conditions primitive.   In particular, the overall attitudes of the native population and the sensitivities of a suspicious and autocratic Police Force are major obstacles to effective military police work.
     In the face of these problems Staff Sergeant Dougall's achievements and the long hours he has worked are remarkable.   Undeterred by the difficulties he has displayed unusual zeal and professional skill to complete a series of complex investigations.   his results, in the form of clear and accurate reports, have proved invaluable and have made a significant contribution to the effective policing of the Forces in Belize.
     In particular he has masterminded one very large and sensitive investigation for which the whole RMP Detachment had to be mobilised.   he produced a most detailed guide to assist the young RMP Corporals.   This ensured that the truth was not hidden, and that a balanced statement was produced for each interviewee.   This investigation, due to operational demands, was completed within a matter of days.   He then, single handed, processed 250 statements to produce a clear presentation of the facts.
     His calm efficiency, his dry humor and the balanced maturity that he shows in his approach to disciplinary problems are unusual in a man of his rank and experience.   That many of his investigations have been carried out amongst  an unscrupulous civil community, with the attendant physical risks and temptations is a tribute to his dedication, integrity and moral courage.   As a result the reputation of the Royal Military Police amongst both the local population and British Forces Belize has never been higher.   This outstanding performance of Staff Sergeant Dougall is worthy of formal recognition.
recommended by: Maj. Deputy Chief of Staff, Belize.   Commander Belize.  Chief of Staff, UKLF.   Gen, C in C, UKLF.

The individuals named below have been brought to notice for brave conduct when their ships encountered enemy submarines, aircraft, ships or mines:- John Madle, Gunner.
ITC Dorset Regiment, Part II Order 50 published 11/3/1941.   
Acts of Gallantry.
1. The Director of Trade Division, Admiralty, has notified that No. 5730551 Pte. J E Madle, "E" Company, Infantry Training Centre, The Dorsetshire Regiment, has been awarded a "commend" for his conduct when MV "Cheapeake" was attacked by enemy aircraft on 20/11/1940.
2.  The following is the official account of the action:-  "When an aircraft dropped bombs near the MV "Chesapeake" and opened fire with a machine gun Pte. Madle, though wounded in the eye, promptly opened fire with his Hotchkiss and first diverted and then drove off the plane.   Fragments were seen to fly from the plane, showing that Private Madle's aim was accurate.
He went on firing through bleeding badly, and is considered to have saved the ship and crew.
3.  The GOC in C directs that an appropriate entry be made on the Conduct Sheets of Pte. Madle, in accordance with para 1718 (b) King's Regulations, 1940.

C in C London District Commendation.   5730511 L/Cpl John Edward Madle, CMP.  Your name has been brought to my notice.   I am authorised to signify by the award to you of this Certificate my appreciation of good service which you have rendered.   I have given instructions that a note of your devotion to duty shall be made on your Record of Service.   N C Lloyd, Lt-Gen. GOC, London  District 11/2/1946

Maj. (temporary) John Gordon Hodges (2581650) Royal Army Service Corps. (Beaconsfield)
Citation:  For distinguished services and constant devotion to duty as Transport Major to CRASC, Eighth Army Troops during the period 1st April 1945 to 2nd May 1945.   This officer was responsible for the control and co-ordination of operating transport in the clearance of maintenance trains arriving at RIMINI, FANO, CESNA, FORLI and FAENZA as well as all that engaged in third line duties providing for the entire Army's requirements of petrol, supplies, ammunition, Ordnance and EFI Stores to different Roadheads.   The period in question was an unusually difficult one, due to the complex and ever changing nature of the Supply situation and to changes in the course of a few days, of both CRASC and second-in-command.   The operational control of task vehicles fluctuated from a minimum equivalent of 7 GT Companies to a maximum equivalent of 27 GT Companies, involving a total of more than 3,000 vehicles.   The units included British, Indian, Polish, Polish ATS, Palestinian and Italian Coys, together with a substantial addition of transport drawn from many RA and other first line sources.   The efficient and economical operation of such a heterogeneous collection of transport, the prompt clearance of Railheads, the rapid stocking of Army Depots.   This Officer has served continuously overseas for 4 1/2 years with Western Desert Force and Eighth Army and although aware that he was due to repatriation under PYTHON in early May allowed himself no relaxation whatsoever until his task was completed two days prior to his departure from the HQ.
Recommended by CRASC 8th Army Troops, DA & QMG. 8th Army
France & Flanders.   542956 CQMS (actg. WO II (CSM)) S Matthews.

Italy.   P5694V WS/Lt. Roeioff Andries van Rensburgh Olivier.
For Gallant Leadership and Distinguished Service in the Face of the Enemy.
     During the period 1 September to 31 December 1944, WS/ Lt. R A van R Olivier has commanded the section of the 6 South African Armoured Division Provost Company attached to the 12 South African Motorised Brigade with outstanding leadership and gallantry.   From the point of view of traffic control this period was noteworthy for the fact that it produced the most difficult and complex problems any Provost officers could have been called upon to solve.   In the days preceding the battle for MONTE STANCO and during the battle itself he organised, established and maintained control so effectively over six miles of the single jeep track available that the Brigade was able to build up for and carry out the attack successfully.   This track was so narrow that except at established "sidings" it was "one-way only to jeeps";  large sections of tit were in appalling and muddy condition and under almost continuous shellfire, and, in addition to the Brigade Group, it served as the only maintenance route to three other battalions.
     Thereafter, in the battles for MONTE PEZZA, Point 806 and Point 826 which followed during the succeeding weeks he continued continued to establish and maintain control of this jeep track right forward to the leading infantry elements, thereby ensuring the smooth flow forward of ammunition and supplies and the evacuation of casualties.
     For over two months since the operations became static, he and his men have maintained traffic on similar jeep tracks, during which time track conditions have varied from deep mud and slush, to snow and slippery iced surfaces.   An outstanding feature of this period has been the maintenance of a traffic control post in GRIZZANA where he and his men have cheerfully and determinedly carried out their tasks under enemy observation and continuous shellfire, thereby ensuring the smooth flow of traffic over the section GRIZZANA - MONTE STANCO, known as the "Mad Mile", where traffic is subjected to direct, observed shellfire.
     The manner in which Lieutenant OLIVIER has carried out his onerous duties has been exemplary and has revealed high qualities of leadership, devotion to duty, and gallantry in the face of the enemy.
Recommendations: OC 6 SA Div Pro Coy. Brig. 12 SA Mot. Bde.  GOC 6 SA Armd Div.

BEF 1940.   France & Flanders.
Citation: 6203625 L/Cpl J Burton. 1/7 Middlesex Regiment.
     For conspicuous gallantry and devotion to duty in the Field.   L/Cpl BURTON took over command of the section to which he belonged at WERWICQ on May 24 when all the senior NCOs had been wounded.   Though wounded himself and under heavy shelling mortar and machine gun fire he personally superintended and led all the wounded out to the position.   He then returned to find that the guns were out of action and the two remaining men had been mortared out of position.   He crawled forward, remounted the guns and kept them in action, inflicting severe losses on the enemy.   By his example, the morale of the section was completely restored and they were able to inflict further casualties to the enemy.
Recommended by: Lt/Col B B Rackham.

Police Review 20/4/1916 page 190. 
Brave South Shields Constable.
     Lance Corporal Whitehead, of the South Shields Police, who is serving in France with the Military Mounted Police, has earned by his bravery the warm praise of his commanding officer.   In a report the latter wrote:- His example of absolute fearlessness and calm under very trying conditions undoubtedly helped to prevent panic among a large civil population and assisted materially the work of the Army.   Lance Corporal Whitehead was proceeding down -------- road to relieve Corporal Westropp when shelling commenced.   He went to Westropps assistance and helped him in the duties he performed.   He also patrolled shops, the windows of which were broken, exposing goods, and moved soldiers standing outside the shops away from them to prevent either looting or charges of looting.   He investigated and reported to APM a case of looting involving the theft from a damaged shop of 400 francs which had been in a cash box, but the troops were not in any way involved.
     The Chief Constable of South Shields is very gratified that one of his force should have so distinguished himself, and he brought the report of Lance Corporal Whitehead's commanding officer before the Committee, which put on record their appreciation of his exemplary donduct.

Police Review 20/4/1916 page 190. 
Brave South Shields Constable.
     Lance Corporal Whitehead, of the South Shields Police, who is serving in France with the Military Mounted Police, has earned by his bravery the warm praise of his commanding officer.   In a report the latter wrote:- His example of absolute fearlessness and calm under very trying conditions undoubtedly helped to prevent panic among a large civil population and assisted materially the work of the Army.   Lance Corporal Whitehead was proceeding down -------- road to relieve Corporal Westrop when shelling commenced.   He went to Westrops assistance and helped him in the duties he performed.   He also patrolled shops, the windows of which were broken, exposing goods, and moved soldiers standing outside the shops away from them to prevent either looting or charges of looting.   He investigated and reported to APM a case of looting involving the theft from a damaged shop of 400 francs which had been in a cash box, but the troops were not in any way involved.
     The Chief Constable of South Shields is very gratified that one of his force should have so distinguished himself, and he brought the report of Lance Corporal Whitehead's commanding officer before the Committee, which put on record their appreciation of his exemplary conduct.

Act of Courage - The General Officer Commanding wishes to express his appreciation of the following act of courage on the part on No. 2163 Lance Corporal Johnson, Military 'foot Police attached to the Town major's establishment ------- (France).
     About 2 pm on the 20th December 1916, at -------, two horses attached to a GS wagon took fright and bolted down the Rue de Haillcourt. (probably Barlin)  Lance Corporal Johnson, who was on duty at the Crucifix, seeing the horses galloping up the road with no one in charge, at once ran towards them and at great personal risk, running alongside the horses, succeeded in catching hold of one of the reins and in bringing both horses to a standstill.
     "This NCO's prompt and plucky action probably averted a serious accident, as further along the road, in which the wagon was proceeding, there was a considerable number of farmers carts.   A record of the above will be made in the Regimental Conduct Sheet of this NCO, in accordance with Paragraph 1918 (XIV.) Kings Regulations."

3 Grenadier Guards, Malaya 28 May 1949,   Leading an Infantry Section.
Citation: On 28 May 1949, Sjt Clutton was ordered to take his section by a circuitous route to the edge of the jungle in SUNGEI KANTAN near KAJANG, with the object of cutting off the retreat of a gang of 20 well-armed bandits who were known to be in the this rubber in the area.   The plan was for the Police to drive the enemy into the fore of the 3 sections who were acting as stops.
     Sgt Clutton succeeded in manoeuvring his section into a concealed position in tall Lallang Grass, astride what he considered would be the bandits' line of withdrawal.   The speedy taking up of the position required a good and quick appreciation of the ground and as soon as the section were in position bursts of fire were heard, indicating that the police were already engaging the bandits.
     15 of the enemy appeared, making straight for Sjt Clutton's two Rifle Groups.   he held his fire, hoping that they would continue on until he could kill them all.   However, the bandits then saw movement from another direction of the thick rubber and at once became suspicious and ran back to cover.
Immediately Sjt. Clutton saw that the surprise was lost and that now was his only chance, he ordered his section to open fire even though the range was long.
     Four bandits were hit and fell, and under cover of automatic fire the enemy withdrew into the cover, dragging their wounded.
     Sjt. Clutton following up the blood trail for 400 yards, eventually came upon a bandit lying in a gully.   Ordering his section to cover him, Sjt Clutton then went forward himself to investigate.   As he approached the bandit exploded a grenade which seriously wounded Sjt Clutton and blew himself up.
     Regardless of his wounds Sjt Clutton continued to urge his section on to follow up the remaining bandits and would not submit to medical attention until he was satisfied his section were continuing the pursuit.
     Throughout the action Sjt Clutton set a very fine example to is men of leadership, bravery and devotion to duty and he is deserving of the highest praise.
Recommended by: CO 3 Grenadier Guards, Brig, 2 Guards Bde, Maj-Gen. Malaya District, C in C Malaya Command.

22795542 A/Cpl. Henry Anthony McKenzie, Green Howards attached to 1 Duke of Wellingtons' Regiment.
Korea, 1/1/1953 to 30/6/1953, Section Commander.
Citation:   Over a period of many months Cpl McKENZIE has shown himself to be an NCO of outstanding courage and determination.   As section commander he has instilled offensive spirit and enthusiasm into his men, whilst as patrol leader he has invariably carried out his task coolly and intelligently.   his bravery has been demonstrated on numerous occasions.   Once he led a small raiding party behind the enemy lines to attack an isolated post suspected of being occupied.   On finding it empty he proceeded, on  his own initiative, along the communication trench, to investigate the main defences.   By approaching to within 20 yards of the enemy he was able to obtain important information which proved extremely valuable for future operations.   again, when taking part in a daylight assault on a strongly held enemy tunnel, Cpl McKENZIE displayed great audacity by exposing himself to heavy small arms fire whilst covering his patrol commander's approach to the entrance of the tunnel.  Thus protected, the patrol commander was able to silence the enemy garrison and subsequently to blow up the tunnel.   On many other less important patrols Cpl McKENZIE has always shown the same courageous spirit.   By his leadership, example to the NCO's and men of the battalion.
Recommended by: Lt/Col, 1 D of W Regiment, Brig, 28 Commonwealth Bde, Maj Gen. 1 Commonwealth Division.

25 Field Regiment, 4 Indian Division, 13 Corps.   
Citation:       On the afternoon of the 23rd Nov 41, No. 786873 Lance Bombardier McQUEEN was OP Assistant to the FOO with the 4/16 Punjab Regiment in their attack on LIBYAN OMAR.   The OP had been moving forward with A Company under a heavy fire and by night fall the Company was pinned to the ground and isolated.
     It was essential to obtain touch with the Battalion Headquarters and Lance Bombardier McQUEEN volunteered to find his way there in the darkness and across ground covered by continuous Machine-gun fire.   This he succeeded in doing, thereby providing vital information regarding locations of the forward troops.
     Later, when given an opportunity to rest, he assisted in the evacuation of Sepoy casualties from the forward area.
     Throughout these operations Lance Bombardier McQUEEN has displayed outstanding bravery, initiative and boldness which were an inspiration to all those around him.
Recommended for the immediate award of the MM.
Recommended by: Brig. RA 4 indian Div, Lt/Col. Commanding 25 Fld Regt. Gen. Middle East Forces.

Black Watch attached to Kings Own Scottish Borderers.   Place KUMGONG-NI- (4266)- Map Sheet 6626 IV, 21/5/1951.
Citation:  On 21st May 1951, 6 Platoon, B Company, of which Sergeant HAYE was Platoon Sergeant, had been given the task of exploiting forward to feature Point 432 at KUMGONG-NI, on capture of feature Point525 (4368).   The leading section of 6 Platoon, having advanced 100 yards beyond Point 325, came under light automatic fire at close range and one man of the sectio0n was wounded.   Without waiting for orders, Sergeant HAYE immediately seized a Light Machine Gun and with this weapon and his Sten gun rushed forward alone and killed single handed three Chinese, who were dug in behind a small hill 100 yards ahead of the leading section.
     Sergeant HAYE's complete disregard for his own personal safety, coupled with his own prompt action and skill, were not only an inspiration to his platoon, which immediately continued its advance, but were probably instrumental in saving further casualties.
Recommended by : CO, 1 KOSB, Brig. 28 Commonwealth Brigade. Gen. 1 Commonwealth Div.

For services in connection with the disturbances in Kenya.   Platoon Sgt. and Patrol Commander.   Aberdare Forest, October to December 1953.
Citation:   Cpl BARKER has been a patrol commander and acting platoon Sergeant for the last 5 months.   He has led his patrol with great dash and has shown an outstanding determination to seek out and engage the enemy in the forest.
     On 16 November 1955 Cpl Barker led his patrol from a forest base up the Gura river, searching the area for a suspected Mau Mau camp.   He directed his trackers with skill and led his patrol in an immediate charge into the camp.   Cpl Barker firing his Patchett personally killed one of the gang leaders and wounded 2 others who escaped.   From the camp 7 rounds of Dum Dum .303 bullets, two Simis and all the gang documents and dairies which were of intelligence importance were recovered.
     On the 2nd December 1955, Cpl Barker led a patrol from MUNYANGE Camp and picked up tracks of 3 Mau Mau at the forest edge.   He followed these tracks for some 5 miles including a crossing of the GURA River.   Cpl Barker happened to be leading the patrol when he saw a Mau Mau coming down the track towards him.   Cpl Barker shot him dead at 25 yards range.   He immediately led his patrol at speed back tracking this Mau Mau.   As the patrol was proceeding along a very steep hill , Sgt Mitchell, the Kenya Regiment Sergeant, attached to his patrol for liaison duties and as an interpreter, slipped and fell down the steep hill and accidentally shot and wounded himself in the leg.   This was about 1530hours.   Sgt Mitchell was unable to walk and was about six miles from the camp.   Cpl Barker immediately organised his evacuation and gave him medical attention.   Having got Sgt Mitchell half way back to this patrol base, Cpl Barker ran on ahead with only a tracker with him to get help and organise the rescue.   Cpl Barker's patrol carried Sgt Mitchell all night through very difficult forest and across the fast flowing mountain river Gura.   Sgt Mitchell reached the coy base after dawn the next day.
     Cpl Barker and his patrol, performed a great feat of non stop physical endurance during that 24 hours.
Recommended by Lt/Col. CO 1 Devons, Brig, Sagna, Kenya, Gen, G Erskine, Kenya.

Trooper Francis Scott, Lovat Scouts, 18 Lorried Infantry Brigade, 3 Carpathian Division, 2 Polish Corps,  Italy.
Citation:  On Nov 23rd 1944 Mountaineer SCOTT was sent out with Mtnr. Hawthorn to repair a signal line connecting the HQ of the Lovat Scouts with the HQ of the 6th Lancers.   As this regiment was operating on the extreme left flank of the Eighth Army the only other link with the 6th Lancers went back through many higher formations to Fifth Army ans so forward again and accordingly the signal line was of great importance in maintaining co0operation.   The line party of two was consistently and persistently shelled on the open ground South East Of MODIGLIANA (M.2309) but both linesmen never slackened their efforts and spent over two yours under heavy shell and mortar fire - much of it observed - repairing the new breaks in the line which the shellfire was constantly causing.   Some of the work had to be done standing waist deep in the river in full view of enemy O.Ps on the opposite hills.   Finally the shelling ceased and the pair mended the last break and reported their work completed.    Mtn. Scott acted throughout with great courage, coolness and devotion to duty.
Recommended by: Maj. Commanding Lovat Scouts,   Lt/Col, commanding 18 Lorried Infantry Brigade,   Brigadier Commanding 26 FLU,   Lt/Gen ?,  Field Marshal , Commanding 8 Army.

Antsirane, Madagascar, 29 Independent Brigade, Force 121, 1 Royal Scots Fusiliers.
Citation: This NCO throughout the operation showed outstanding powers of leadership.  
     He showed great coolness and ability whilst under constant and heavy fire, and throughout the period attended to the wounded without any thought of his own personal safety.
   His general behaviour under fire won the admiration of all.
Place: Antsirane, date: 6th May 1942.
Recommended b: Lt/Col J F Armstrong, MBE.  Commander 19 Independent Brigade Group/

1 Canadian Pro Coy RCMP, 1 Canadian Division, 5 Corps.
Citation:   Throughout the Italian Campaign Corporal STEWART has done outstanding work.
     On numerous occasions he has been under heavy artillery, mortar and small arms fire.   Nevertheless he has remained at his post and with the greatest coolness and determination has continued to exercise control of traffic at the vital points at which he has been stationed.
     Shortage of personnel has put a great strain on the Provost available, necessitating long hours on duty without relief.   In spite of this, Corporal Stewart has at all times and in all weathers performed hid duties cheerfully and supremely well.
     By his courage, efficiency and devotion to duty, he has set a most inspiring example to all serving with him and has helped materially to maintain the morale and efficiency of 1 Canadian Provost Company at the highest level.
Recommended by: OC, 1 Pro Coy, RCMP, APM 1 Canadian Divis1on, Commander 5 Corps,

Found in Guards Armoured Division Pro Coy War Diary WO 171/390
Citation for the Belgian Croix de Guerre with Bronze Star to L/Cpl Parry CMP: At approximately 18.00 hrs the Military policeman, who was on point duty where tanks were crossing the main road EAST of RANVILLE, was killed on his point.  (L/Cpl Stead)  L/Cpl PARRY was detailed to take over this point.   In spite of intense enemy shelling L/Cpl PARRY proceeded to control the traffic as though the situation was perfectly normal.   There is no doubt that the steadfastness and imperturbability of this L/Cpl was an source of inspiration to the drivers of all passing vehicles and his courage enabled a considerable congestion of vehicles at this point to be avoided.
Not found in London Gazette or National Archive.

49 (West Riding) Division Routine Orders, 3/4/1918.
Act Of Courage.
The Divisional Commander wishes to bring to the notice the gallant behaviour of No. P/12899 L/Cpl G Melrose, MMP
     On 5th March 1918 this NCO was on duty on the MENIN road when two four horse teams attached to 2 GS Wagons galloped down the road towards YPRES.   L/Cpl Melrose seized the off leader of the leading wagon and although dragged for about 50 yards succeeded in bringing the horse to a standstill.
     The GOC directs that an entry to be made of this gallant act in L/cpl Melrose's Conduct Sheet in accordance with KR 1919 (XIV).

Citation: As DAPM of the 48th Division he showed the greatest initiative in organizing the movement of traffic when it was vitally important to prevent blockage of the roads.
He showed exceptional powers of command under fire and was always to be found on stretches of the road where shelling or bombing was heaviest thereby giving the traffic control personnel an admirable example of coolness and devotion to duty.
Recommended for OBE awarded MC.
Recommended by Commander 48 Division.

Chief Constable, City Police, Edinburgh, 5/1/1920.
     This is to certify that L/cpl Frederick J Cooper, Military Foot police, has been stationed in this City during the past two years and seven months.   During that period ha has frequently come under my notice in the discharge of his duties and otherwise.   he is a mart, intelligent officer, and on many occasions has rendered valuable assistance to the Civil Police.   My officers likewise speak of him in terms of the highest praise, and I feel sure he will give satisfaction whatever sphere of life h may be placed.   R Ross, Chief Constable

25/3/1920 from OC 1 Depot Battalion, Machine Gun Corps, to APM Shorncliffe.
I wish to bring to your notice the following facts.   for some time past I have suspected that illegal sales of by-products have been taking lace from out cookhouse bur we have been unable to trace them.   On the 16th instant, No. P/16029 L/cpl C H Fox, MFP very cleverly caught one of the cooks in the unlawful act of selling dripping to the swill contractor.   The Contractor, Mr E Brooks, has been convicted and fined in a Civil Court and the cook remanded for Court Martial.   I consider that Lance Corporal Fox should be commended for this smart capture.   E A de Salis, DSO, Commanding 1st Depot Bn., Machine Gun Corps, Napier Bks, Shorncliffe, 25/3/1920.
Also in his army record a letter from the DPM Eastern Command stating that the letter will be forwarded to the O/I/C Records,Corps of Military Police to be attached to his documents.

Capt. & QM (T/Capt.) Henry Charles Hunt, Corps of Military Police.
Edinburgh Gazette.

For Gallant & Distinguished Service, Palestine, No. 6979148 Fusilier Peter Coleman, 2 Bn, Royal Irish Fusiliers, (Princess Victoria's).
Citation: British Forces Palestine - Trans Jordan.   2 Battalion Royal Irish Fusiliers, 18 Infantry Brigade.
On the morning of the 25th November 1938, when a column of the 2 Battalion, The Royal Irish Fusiliers, encountered a gang of from 15 to 20 bandits in the hills near AMQA, Fusilier COLEMAN was one of a handful of men who dashed forward at once with Lieutenant MORRIS to get to close quarters with the band.   When a party of enemy attempted to break back through them to the cover of a wadi, Fusilier COLEMAN engaged them at close quarters and by his coolness and determination prevented them doing so, himself killing three of the enemy.
Recommended for the Military Medal by the Commander 16th Infantry Brigade and Lt/Gen. GOC, British forces in Palestine & Trans-Jordan.

     For conspicuous gallantry during operations he led his bombers against the enemy's trench under severe machine gun fire.   It was largely due to his cool pluck that the enemy were driven back and 340 yards of trench captured and held.

201572 Cpl. L A Cripps, Ox & Bucks LI (Oxford).
Citation:- For conspicuous gallantry and devotion to duty in command of two Stokes mortars covering the front line,   On the enemy attacking he at once got his guns into action and fired continuously until cut off from all other troops.   He then with two men succeeded in forcing his way back and joining a party of infantry.   With these he counter attacked and regained the front line, but was again forced back.   Finally he regained possession of one of his guns and immediately restored its position.   Throughout he displayed great courage, determination and skill.

Citation:- 11079, Cpl. T G Cooper, 1st Bn  Kings Own Royal Lancaster Regiment.
   For conspicuous gallantry and resource on the 2nd May 1915, north-east of Ypres when the Germans, under cover of gas, having captured a house in which w has a patrol, Lance Corporal cooper, from a neighbouring trench, collected his party of about ten men and on his own initiative counter attacked, drove out the Germans and re occupied the house.  (5.8.15)

Citation: For conspicuous gallantry on 9th August 1915, at Hooge.   he was sent with messages three times from near the crater to Battalion headquarters under heavy fire and although wounded returned each time.   he carried back an Officer and showed the greatest bravery and coolness throughout the day.
